text:
Advertising is concerned with informing and influencing the public, through paid space or time in any of the media of mass communication, to patronize certain goods or services or to support persons or policies. Illustrations, letterings, format layouts, or designs by visual artists are generally employed in print media (like newspapers and magazines) or in outdoor media (like billboards and posters) to draw attention to the product, activity, or idea being endorsed.

Line drawing and artistic lettering dominated print-media advertising before lithography and photography became technically and economically practical. Withthe development of color printing in newspapers and magazines, painting techniques and color photography have been employed for the sake of realism as wellas to attract readers and viewers. Photography has not completely taken over the function of painting and drawing in printed advertisement, there being instances when products are better rendered in paint or pen-and-ink than through photographic means. Neon and electrical signs were earlier used in outdoor media for advertising purposes before they became appropriated as postmodern art trends.

The earliest advertisements appeared in newspapers. The Registro Mercantil de Manila, 1824-33, was the first newspaper in the country to advertise local products by publishing the precios corrientes or current prices. La Esperanza, 1847-50, featured the first boxed announcements. By 1848, as could be seen in Diario de Manila, 1848-52, local newspapers were filled with boxed notices announcing sales, auctions, lost and found cases, and the arrival and departure of ships. La Ilustracion Filipina, 1859-60, began featuring illustrated advertisements, generally simple vignettes representing the products. It was El Comercio, 1869-1938, which began the practice of devoting pages to advertisements, mainly boxed notices. In its first years, El Comercio also featured an advertisement with a full illustration—that is, the edifice of Botica Zobel. In 1892, La Pavera contained more artwork in its advertisements.

In the early 1900s, business establishments flourished due to the more liberal policies of the Americans. Improved commerce promoted print advertising for clothes, hats, shoes, cigars, beverages, phonographs, and sewing machines. Advertisements frequently contained copy in both Spanish and English and were trilingual in Tagalog newspapers. The artists employed to illustrate these announcements, perhaps still not adjusted to the impersonal nature of their job, signed their names. This was common in Spanish or Filipino-owned publications, like Excelsior, 1905-41, and Renacimiento Filipino, 1910-15. Similarly identified were the advertising illustrations of Luis Viejo y Morera, staff artist of both the secular Excelsior and the Jesuit-owned Cultura Social, 1913-41,and of JorgePineda, Renacimiento’s frequent cover illustrator.

Advertising illustration was influenced by current styles in painting and design. The works of Viejo and Pineda had art nouveau borders or frames consisting of sinuous lines often adorned with fruits, flowers, and leaves enclosing both the illustration and copy. An example is the advertisement for the Quiapo Saloon by Viejo—a watercolor rendition of Uncle Sam, flanked by the interior and facade of the saloon, holding a weighing scale (the left containing a big coin, off-balanced by the right containing glasses of beer) before a crowd of men with arms extended toward the potables, recalling earlier icons showing souls in purgatory.

Pineda’s drawing for the advertisement of Talleres de Fotograbados y Zincografia de Renacimiento Filipino recalls his genre paintings. The announcement shows a watercolor of a female assistant in profile—understood to be the symbolic muse of the newly emancipated photographic art—pouring developing liquid over a picture. As in the genre paintings for which Pineda was known by then, the dainty damsel in the advertisement wears loose, long tresses, and delicately embroidered sleeves. She is set off by a glass-paned window instead of a dark room. Pineda did another version with the girl simply holding a picture. Among products for which Pineda designed advertisements are the Kati-Alis ointment for skin irritations and the Balsamo Milagrosa ointment for muscular pains.

American advertising agencies emphasized the impersonality of the announcements. The signature of the artists who executed them seldom appeared intheir works; hence, although FernandoC.Amorsolo was the chief artist of the Pacific Commercial Company, none of his advertising illustrations bear his signature. Other artists employed by Pacific Commercial Company were Zozimo Dimaano, JoseEsperanzaCruz, IrineoMiranda, PabloAmorsolo, and JoseV.Pereira. After Renacimiento Filipino closed down, Pineda became chief artist of Carmelo and Bauermann Incorporated.

Amorsolo is best remembered for his vignette of Saint Michael crushing Lucifer, which adorned the label of San Miguel gin, a product of La Tondeña. Amorsolo himself was one of the earliest media celebrities to grace an advertisement, perhaps antedating movie stars as advertisement models. His photograph of himself holding a palette before a canvas was juxtaposed beside the picture of Buick’s Marquette car.

Most of the American firms in Manila in the first two decades of the 20th century simply had an advertising manager to handle advertising requirements. The Pacific Commercial Company was an exception. It had its own department exclusively for advertising. In 1921, H. Edward Bullis established the first advertising agency, Philippine Publicity Service Inc (PPSI). Advertising historian Isabelo T. Crisostomo described the PPSI as a clearing house for advertisements coming from the United States. In 1925, the first Filipino-owned agency, the Philippine Advertising Bureau, was created by Florentino Garriz. Among the artists who worked there was the watercolor painter of costumes Ricardo Gloria. The closure of American agencies after World War II led to the emergence of locally owned advertisingoutfits that employed, among others, HernandoR.Ocampo and CesarT.Legaspi, later National Artists. After Irineo Miranda’s earlier efforts, LauroA.Alcala, more popular as a cartoonist, spearheaded the establishment of a fine arts degree program majoring in advertising art at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines, in the 1960s.

With the development of advertising as trade and industry, outdoor advertising in the form of posters and billboards came into vogue. It was also common practice to insert slide images of advertisements in between movies. Most of these were unimaginative in design, if not totally inspired by American examples.

In the “peace time” era, mobile advertisements, such as those posted in the tranvia, and radio advertising came into widespread use. The most active advertising practitioners were Antonio Lagos of Hales Shoe Company, Frank J. Herier, ManuelBuenaventura, Jorge Revilla, Luzon Ocampo, and AlejandroRocesSr. Procter and Gamble Company, an international American firm that acquired Philippine Manufacturing Company in 1935, launched the first truly corporate advertising scheme.

Comic stripadvertisement became popular in prewar years. AntonioVelasquez created various characters to personify products. Among his well-loved cartoon heroes were Isko for ESCO shoes, Tikboy for Tiki-Tiki, Capitan Cortal for the popular analgesic, and Nars Cafe for Cafiaspirina. He also drew advertisements for Plymouth sedan, Milkmaid, Kanebo, Peoples’ Shoes, Chrysler, and Might in Shanghai perfume. Other print advertisements of the period were text heavy and in English, with supplementary line drawings or photographs that promoted an Americanized lifestyle.

Post-World War II advertising marked the return of American firms. Although they dominated the industry and the culture projected through advertisements, many Filipinos put up their own advertising business or entered into joint ventures. D. L. Brodt, an American, opened the first postwar advertising agency, which later was named Philippine Advertising Associates, the precursor of J. Walter Thompson Company (Philippines). In 1945, Gene Hubilla founded Commercial Advertising Company. Among the first purely Filipino-owned agencies were Philiprom founded in 1945 and Pan Pacific Advertising founded in 1946. The Andres Soriano group also put up the Advertising Association. By 1949 the first full-color print advertisements were published. This established the trend of using photography as basic medium instead of text. The influence of Hollywood and the use of local movie stars as come-ons were standard practice. Grant Advertising, a branch of one of the biggest advertising firms in the United States, established an office in Manila. Ace Advertising Agency was founded by the Ramon Araneta Companies.

From the 1950s, field advertising—that is, billboards and vehicle posters with soundtrack—became more popular. Cinema advertising developed. Family-owned workshops for hand-painted movie billboards on canvas, such as the Sagmit Advertising in Tondo, employed self-taught artists who painted promotional images utilizing aesthetics found in komiks. These outdoor billboards measure 12 ft by 12 ft, and were usually found in Quiapo and Cubao. In the mid-1970s, the billboards with the copy “Put a Tiger in Your Tank,” displayed along Philippine highways, were painted by Quirino Hipol.

Package designing became lucrative. Full of vitality was retail advertising, such as Aguinaldo’s, Berg’s, and Oceanic. Among the artists in the print-advertising field during this period were HernandoOcampo and CesarLegaspi. The Philippine Association of National Advertising was organized in 1958 to professionalize advertising practices and solve ethical problems.

Advertising became a highly technical and competitive field. The television, which was introduced in the Philippines in 1953, soon became the country’s most popular advertising medium. Color printing became too expensive; thus the trend was to use black-and-white studio photography. Fashion advertising also attained sophistication. Company investments in advertising tripled in the mid-1960s. While there were only 15 advertising agencies during the previous 15 years, there were 48 by 1960. Western campaigns and norms as syndicated by multinationals were the cultural realities with which to contend. This stunted the imaginative growth of local advertising art.

The use of creative photography in advertising started to develop. Nonetheless, there were some breakthroughs. The Philippine Advertising Counsellors dared to popularize local scenes and language in their campaigns, like those for San Miguel Beer and Banco Filipino. With the introduction of new trends in layout photography and art rendering, advertising art attained professionalism. Edwina Koch Arroyo’s designs rejected Caucasian models for brown-skinned beauty queens. Instead of using studio photography, she set the trend by employing the talentsof well-known photojournalists DickBaldovino, Evaristo Nievera, and Sonny Yabao. These were refreshing, relevant, and intimate ways of capturing consumer attention. The advertising industry was generally in a slump during the martial law period (1972-86), although the government’s numerous development programs made tremendous use of advertising schemes and skills.

In the atmosphere of anti-imperialism and nationalism in the 1970s, more and more Filipino values and ideals were projected in advertising images. Himlayang Pilipino, a memorial park, promoted Philippine legends, such as “Si Malakas at Maganda” (Strong and Beautiful) and FloranteatLaura (Florante and Laura), as well as national heroes like Tandang Sora, Emilio Jacinto, and Gabriela Silang.

There have been rapid technological changes in the field of advertising in the past 40 years. Black-and-white print ads in the 1960s, for instance, eventually transitioned to the use of color advertising and billboards from the 1970s and beyond. The rise of animation, cable TV, and other electronic forms of mass media was witnessed in the 1990s. While television still remains the main medium for advertising, over radio and print to date, new media such as the use of LED billboards, digital advertising, and the Internet have been considered as new frontiers since the 2000s.

The influx of multinational advertising companies and the growth of small local agencies since the 1960s eventually gave rise to the need for self-regulation and coordination within the sector. More industry-based organizations emerged after the founding of the Philippine Association of National Advertising in 1958. Some organizations, such as the Advertising Club (1947-51) and the Advertising Standard Council in the 1990s, were short-lived, while others such as the Association of Accredited Advertising Agencies of the Philippines (4A’s) remain active. A major federation was the Philippine Board of Advertising, founded in 1974 during the early years of martial law. It later changed its name to the Advertising Content Regulatory Board (AdBoard).

In addition to the University of the Philippines, more private and public tertiary institutions opened their respective fine arts, visual communications, or advertising programs, including the University of Santo Tomas, St. Paul University, Technological University of the Philippines, Philippine Women’s University, and the University of the East. Graduates of these courses supplied the growing local demand for designers, art directors, visualizers, and other professionals. Since the 1980s, advertising professionals have also sought employment as overseas Filipino workers, especially in countries within Southeast Asia.

A number of advertising practitioners also pursued parallel practice in the fine arts. Among the painters and sculptors who also work in the industry are Edwin Wilwayco, Pete Jimenez, Pablo Biglang-awa, and Cid Reyes.

The founding of new institutions within the advertising industry gave rise to broader avenues of professional validation, such as the rise of local awards and competitions for design and advertising since the 1980s. The 4A’s has organized the annual Creative Guild of the Philippines Awards since 1987, renaming it as the annual Kidlat Awards in 2008. The AdBoard held its first AdBoard Recognition Awards (ARAW) in 1995, while an offshoot, the ARAW Values Advertising Awards, was launched in 1998. Other newer competitions have surfaced since, such as the Tambuli Awards of the University of Asia and the Pacific held since 2005 and the adobo Design Awards held since 2010. A number of these awards, such as the ARAW, have emphasized a wider range of formats and the practice of values-oriented advertising.

Philippine agencies and designers also participate in international awards, such as the Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity, Clio Awards, Mobius Advertising Awards, and the New York Festivals International Advertising Awards.

Many of the successful campaigns and advertisements over the years incorporate strong emotional values and humor. However, from the 1980s to the present, values that set back progressive ideas have continued to proliferate, such as Caucasian endorsement of local products (clothes, beverages, cigarettes), stereotyping of gender roles (laundry and cooking products), nuances of racism, degrading of women as sex objects to sell unrelated products (liquor) or services, overtly sexualized portrayals of minors and models, stereotyped portrayals of homosexuals, distortion of history, and the promotion of particular standards of beauty (skin whitening products). Controversies arising from the use of such advertising strategies have continued to hound the industry from the year 2000 up to the present. Increased amounts of spending for political advertisements also remain a controversial issue during the national and local election seasons.

The struggle for advertising that conveys nondiscriminatory, truthful, and progressive messages has continued from the 1980s up to the present. A positive phenomenon to counter this is the trend toward cause-orientation. Since the 1980s, developmental advertising has become the commitment of more and more companies led by the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP), the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT), and Nestlé Philippines. DBP has dramatized positive traditional values and virtues, such as family unity, respect for elders, industry, and dedication. PLDT has focused on livelihood, self-sufficiency, and excellence. Nestlé inculcates individual and community discipline as values for national development. Many product campaigns have since emulated these.

Another development since 2000 is more collaborations between ad agencies, companies, nongovernment organizations, and contemporary visual artists. These gave rise to award-winning campaigns, such as Pilipinas Shell and Pacific Paints’ (Boysen) Project EDSA (Everyone Deserves Safe Air) in 2011, where a series of murals using air-purifying paint were produced along Epifanio de los Santos Avenue (EDSA) in Manila and DDB Manila’s collaboration with women’s rights group Gabriela on ‘Bruise’ outdoor ads on the issue of violence against women in 2010.

Advertising has also played a major role in the promotion of local and international tourism with the Department of Tourism (DOT)’s campaigns, “WoW Philippines” and “It’s More Fun in the Philippines” in 2012, both developed by BBDO Guerrero.

Innovations in high-tech animation, photography, computer-generated graphics in outdoor advertising, neon signs, illuminated poster advertisements in shopping malls, use of mascots, total product improvement, and total corporate promotion have made local advertising even in an energy-strapped economy, a lively, complex, and globalized industry. The sense of social commitment and nationalism, and the high morale and level of excellence of the country’s advertising practitioners are being strengthened—for advertising, more than an industry, is a powerful educational and cultural tool. Written by Santiago A. Pilar and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Lisa Ito-Tapang

text:
Assemblage or “putting together,” a term adopted by French artist Jean Dubuffet in 1953 for a series of lithographs that he made from paper collages, is a relief made of pieces of paper, wood scraps, sponges, found objects, and other debris. Spanish painter Pablo Picasso was one of its earliest practitioners, using found objects and discards. While assemblage may include collages and small constructions, in its more recent development, assemblages have been put together using larger elements and actual objects from stuffed animals to toothbrushes. An American phenomenon in the mid-1950s, it reflected the brashness of contemporary American society. American pop artist Robert Rauschenberg made assemblages of an aggressive character, one with a stuffed goat enclosed in a rubber tire, and another in an actual mattress dripped over with paint. Assemblages often break down the distinction between two-dimensional and three-dimensional art or between painting and sculpture.

In the Philippines, a number of artists, throughout the 1960s to the early 1970s created assemblages from various objects and embedded their creations with a distinctive character or narrative flavor. LambertoHechanova and EdgarDoctor did three-dimensional works with machine parts to build torso-like constructions. J. Elizalde Navarro’s mixed media assemblages combined found objects and metal parts in a variety of forms.

Practitioners in this medium who emerged in the 1980s are Moralde Arogante and Gabriel Barredo with their playful, highly imaginative works. Arogante explores the use of recycled copper wires, brass wires and components, and other mechanical discards while Barredo combines assemblages from metal, wood, and found objects to produce kinetic installations. The assemblage Erding Erdrayb at ang Kanyang Palasyong Agaw-Tanaw (Driver Erding and His Now-You-See-It-Now-You-Don’t Palace), 1981, by JoseTenceRuiz aka Bogie combines objects and images that capture a jeepney driver’s mindset of mixing the sacred and the profane. Decorating the movable panels, these objects and images evoke talismanic faith juxtaposed with allusions to a Japanese anime robot, and the fusion of local and global contexts. Using a discarded pay telephone box transformed into a torso of a man, the work explores the Filipino worker’s plight in the streets of Manila or as an overseas Filipino worker in Saudi Arabia.

RobertoFeleo has also brought out new aspects in assemblage. His works, called Sapin-Sapin (Multilayered), show a conglomeration of pop, traditional and historical images, objects and icons, both made and found. Santiago Bose was among the early pioneers of incorporating indigenous materials in art. He used found matter as materials for his paintings, collages, and assemblages.

Social themes are present in many assemblage works of artists emerging from the 1980s to the 1990s. Rey Paz Contreras and Tala Isla-Contreras both integrated discarded hardwood forms such as travieza (ironwood from old railroads) and pinagtrosohan with textiles, bead jewelry, and bones to produce works related to land, nature, and the people connected to it, eventually forming the Daambakal Sculptors Collective from such explorations. Norberto Roldan combines texts, images, and found objects from everyday life to explore themes such as history, collective memory, and contemporary socioeconomic conditions. William Gaudinez combines retablos (altarpieces), multi-paneled urnas (urns), inlay, and images from archival sources to examine themes such as history, myth, and folklore.

The rising patriotic and feminist consciousness in the visual arts is also reflected in the acrylic on assemblage works of Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, who included materials such as sawali textiles, and papier-mâché figures in her “Sawali” period in the mid-1980s and in works such as Balabal ni Lola Minggay (Grandmother Minggay’s Shawl), 1995-96.

From year 2000 to the present, many Philippine visual artists continued to produce assemblages in addition to other media such as painting and installation. For instance, artists such as Pacita Abad and Nona Garcia experimented with paper and photo assemblages, respectively, alongside producing works in painting. Others have explored how assemblage can also cover the dimensions of space and sound; examples are the works of Noel Soler Cuizon who makes interactive assemblages, and Lirio Salvador who combines everyday discards and industrial materials to produce musical instruments.

Assemblage remains a potent media for artistic expression and is increasingly intertwined with installation art and larger forms. The Philippine Pavilion at the 56th Venice Biennale in 2015—the country’s second time to participate in this event since 1964—included as one of its three contributions a massive metal, wood, and velvet assemblage by Tence Ruiz, titled Shoal, for the exhibit Tie a String around the World, curated by Patrick Flores. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, Santiago A. Pilar, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Lisa Ito-Tapang

text:
Bamboo art refers to works made of bamboo, which may have a functional as well as aesthetic value. Depending on the variety and age, bamboo can be put to several uses. It may be usedin constructing the bahaykubo (nipa hut), ritual structures, theater platforms, fiesta decorations, as well as containers, personal accessories, tools, musical instruments, writing materials, furniture, and works of art. Thick bamboo is often used for house posts, ritual and theater structures, fiesta decor, containers, furniture, and writing materials. Thin bamboo is used for personal accessories and musical instruments. Works of art may use any kind of bamboo.

Working with bamboo involves cutting and cleaning it, peeling off its smooth outer layer, cutting it into sections, and splitting, stripping, or weaving it. Decoration involves incising, burning, carving, and dyeing.

Bamboo is widely used as posts, framework, and floors for the bahay kubo and various indigenous houses. Bamboo may also be stripped, plaited, and woven as sawali, or carefully flattened out to serve as sidings and walls. The use of bamboo creates a cool airy effect and allows the circulation of air through the slats of the floor and the sides. Bamboo is also made into detachable ladders, window supports, papag (beds), chicken coops and nests, and fences.

Bamboo for ritual includes platforms and altars for offerings. Altar s may be elevated platforms decorated with leaves, like those used for the pagdiwata (dealing with the spirit) rituals ofthe Tagbanua. They may also be as simple as the tambara built by the ethnolinguistic groups of Davao. To build a tambara, a single bamboo pole is cut to about 90-120 cm, then split halfway. The split section is opened so that a flat object, like a plate, can be laid on it. On the plate are ritual offerings. A raft-likeplatform is made for the Ibanag healing ritual called atang-atang. On this platform are placed food, drinks, cigarettes, and a chick for the spirits. The whole structure is decorated with paper cutouts.

In many provincial towns, bamboo is also used as framework for the balconies called kubol, on which the girls stand as they sing “Hossana Filio David” and shower the priest with flowers from their baskets on Palm Sunday. Bamboo is also used in the galilea, the four-posted structure under which, during the Easter morning salubong (meeting), the images of the Virgin Mary and the Risen Christ meet. From under the structure which is decorated with coconut leaves and papel de japon (japanese paper) cutouts, the angel is lowered so she can remove the Virgin’s black veil.

Bamboo has been used for the posts and frameworks of stages for theatrical performances since the Spanish period. For these platforms, big bamboos are tied together to serve as principal posts; smaller bamboo is used for the divider (later covered with curtains or leaves), the horizontal frames from which telones (backdrops) are hung, the benches backstage, the railings on the sides and back, the stairs at the back, and the prompter’s shell in front. In multilevel stages, catwalks may also be made of bamboo. All bamboo pieces are tied with rattan strips or doweled with bamboo pins. In San Dionisio, Parañaque, the framework and catwalks of the three-level facade of komedya palaces, which featured balconies and many rows of arched windows as well as parapets and flagpoles, used to be made entirely of bamboo. Both the bamboo and the labor for these structures were offered as donations and prayers to the patron saint San Dionisio.

Bamboo is similarly ubiquitous in fiesta decorations. Bamboo posts and rounded arches are used for the arco or ceremonial gateways through which the procession of the patron saint passes. During the Spanish period these triumphal arches could be elaborate woven and painted structures with arches, pillars, pediments, statuary, and bas-relief designed by architects in various European architectural styles. The folk version of the arco consists of a number of bamboo poles supporting a lintel, above which a pediment may be suggested. The poles may be decorated with winnowing baskets, flowers, leaves, paper cutouts, and drawings. Poles may also be linked by elaborate crisscrossed patterns. The pediment of the arco may be decorated with paper and shaped to form crowns and triangles with cross finials. All the parts are profusely ornamented with bunches of flowers, fruits, vegetables; town products, such as hats; gold and silver foil; and colorful buntings that create a festive atmosphere. In the towns of Santa Maria, Malolos, and San Miguel in Bulacan, the arco tradition is called singkaban. A photo of the inauguration of the Republic of Malolos on 23 Jan 1899 featured a singkaban triumphal arch. Singkaban is used during festive occasions in Bulacan towns. In this art, Francisco Eligio is considered a master artist. He employs the processes of pagkakayas (shaving) in creating the designs of rayos (rays), abaniko (fan), dinanglay (letter Y shaped design), and flower garlands.

The ancient way of writing on bamboo called surat Mangyan is still practiced by the Hanunuo Mangyan of Oriental Mindoro. Using a stylus or knife, the traditional ambahan poetry is etched on the skin of the bamboo. In 1993, Ginaw Bilog was given the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (National Living Treasure Award) for preserving these traditions.

Bamboo furniture is made in towns like Angono, Rizal, and Pangasinan province. In recent years, bamboo furniture and sala sets have gained popularity in many households both for their light organic character and pleasing design, and relatively low cost. Designs can use bamboo for the seat or backrest, or the furniture piece as a whole. Geometric patterns can also be incised with dyes on the bamboo surface, or the material can be used in combination with abaca, steel, or other materials. Sometimes the entire root system of the bamboo plant can be integrated into the design. Bamboo for housing and furniture has to be harvested when it is sufficiently mature or taga sa panahon so that it is hard and can resist termites. The traditional bamboo furniture artist is exemplified by Vicente Villaluz of Angono, Rizal. An innovative designer of modern bamboo furniture is Budji Layug.

Manygroups, such as the Mangyan of Mindoro, use bamboo to make betel-nut or lime containers incised with geometric and stylized designs and fitted with a lid attached to the body with twine. In the north, cut lengths of bamboo are used as water or salt containers. These are usually darkened with spot and entwined with fiberfor design and ease in carrying. The Maranao use a piece of bamboo to make lakub (tobacco containers). These feature colorful geometric designs using crepe paper as dyes. There are, of course, baskets made of bamboo in different shapes and sizes for various functions. In these, bamboo can be combined with other materials, such as vines. Bamboo baskets include the labba of the Ilocos, the bakul of Pangasinan, the bakid of Laguna, and the balugan of Lanao.

Manyother household and personal objects are made of bamboo. The Tboli, Mangyan,and Aeta make well-crafted bamboo combs decorated with geometric and stylized incisions, as well as with vines, brass, or beads. Lice pickers of bamboo are shaped like pointed knives and incised with traditional designs.

Bamboois widely used for musical instruments in the form of flutes, zithers, harp and buzzers. The Tinguian bungkaka, a split-bamboo percussion instrument, is incised with chevrons and other figures, darkened with soot to make the figures emerge, and decorated with bands of woven vine. The Maranao kubing (jew’s harp) is decorated with okir incised into the bamboo and colored with dye.

Abamboo tool that doubles as a musical instrument is the Bukidnon planting stick. A bamboo pole is cut—the lower end to be pointed like a spearhead and the upper end slit to create sound. The whole pole is ornamented with strands of folded buri leaves. As the pointed end of the pole is struck on the ground, a hollow thumping sound is made by the other end.

During the Spanish colonial period, the most famous bamboo instrument made by Filipinos was the Bamboo Organ of Las Piñas, Rizal. Designed by the Recollect Diego Cera in 1824, the organ has pipes of bamboo and metal. The PangkatKawayan orchestra includes the angklung, xylophones, and percussion entirely made of bamboo.

Bamboo as a medium of sculpture has been explored recently. An example of bamboo sculpture is FranciscoVerano’s BambooFugue, 1972. Inspired by the dap-ay, a sacred ritual ground, RobertoVillanueva’s maze titled UmatiBiag (Garden of Life), 1989, used bamboo and runo poles to evoke the mysteries of birth. Impy Pilapil’s artwork with hanging bamboos called Chime Halo, 2008, produces pleasing sounds when struck against each other. Other artists who have used bamboo for their installations are SantiagoBose, PazAbadSantos, Junyee, and Alwin Reamillo. Written by Alice G. Guillermo and ReneB. Javellana, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

text:
Basketry is the art of fashioning containers by weaving, plaiting, or braiding organic materials from leaves, vines, midribs, and boles into hollow three-dimensional shapes that fuse design and function. More than any other folk art, basketry reflects its social matrix, the tropical environment, and the occupations of the folk that draw from the resources of land, river, and sea. There are basically three kinds of baskets: carrying baskets, storage baskets, and trapping baskets. The Cordillera groups, which have one of the basketry traditions in the country, have carrying baskets for grain or food, such as the pasiking (backpack); the hunter’s takba with its cover of tiered fibers for carrying meat; the chagee for the transport of fruits or vegetables, also worn with short straps around one’s back; and the conical kayabang, supported by a sash around the forehead. They also make tapered standing baskets with strong supports for carrying rice and vegetables on the narrow trails of the terraces. The flaring or tapering sides are not merely for decorative effect but also for accommodating areas of greater stress. For instance, the backpack with its tapering shape is so constructed that the weight will not be concentrated at the base but distributed along the sides supported by thehunter’s back. The Luzon Aeta make strong double-walled carrying baskets combining nito, bamban, and rattan. The round bilao can also be considered a carrying basket used for winnowing rice.

Inthe Visayas and in Mindanao, the Tiruray, Bagobo, Tboli, and Mangyan fashion finely crafted baskets and bags for carrying personal objects, which also serve as colorful accessories to their costumes. Baskets may be ornamented with tufts of animal hair, broad and colorful panels of woven beads, and brass bells. Compared to the lowland folk, the ethnolinguistic groups show a freer and uninhibited approach to material.

All regions have their own storing baskets. Among these are the bakul or the lowlandgrain baskets of Pangasinan; the Ilocano labba; the Bontoc round oval akob, with its close-fitting lid to hold cooked rice or camote for lunch in the field; and the koppit, with its several close-fitting sections. The lowland bulligan is used for rice storage in Laguna. From Bulacan are egg baskets of split bamboo in which acurving base secures the eggs firmly in place. Palawan groups make household baskets, big and small, with geometric designs playing on different materials and fitted with covers. Examples of these storing baskets are the lusong and tingkap of Palawan, reinforced at the foot with a heavy piece of bamboo. The rectangular and lidded rambit are seed baskets of the Palaweño. In the south, the Maranao, Maguindanao, and Tausug have also brought the art of basketry to perfection with an added note of color. The marigai are rice containers in bird shapes, single or tiered, made of flattened pandan leaves dyed in vivid colors. Maguindanao baskets are made of soft sea grass dyed in magenta, violet, green, and yellow pigments, giving them a distinctive character.

There are not only baskets for trapping animals and catching fish but baskets with more specific functions. Catching fish in the rice paddies requires the salakab, made of bamboo stakes curving out from a single node of bamboo. There are creels and traps for eels, shrimps, snails in the paddies, as well as bobo, which has an inner cone to catch small river fish. Cordillera folk make baskets adapted to the work of farming in the rice terraces. Agawin, made of fine rattan, are baskets used forcollecting snails in the rice paddy. The Ifugao butit is an open-cage basket used for collecting locusts or grasshoppers. Pangasinan folk make fish creels with high shoulder points worn tied to the waist. An example is the hasang, with a flexible cone at the mouth used for catching and retaining fish.

Basketry exemplifies the creative use of materials from the environment. Bamboo is gathered from dense groves, then cut and split into strips for coiling and weaving, the outer skin acquiring a yellow sheen with age and use. Bamboo rapidly grows into tall and slender boles with vigorous, spiky leaves springing from the nodes; thus bamboo as a material has a finesse and purity, combined with resilience and strength. Coconut midribs make for strong structure, and they are often used to reinforce other materials. Also made into baskets are large leaves, dried and flattened, from the crown of the bun palm and anahaw with its light broad fronds that suggest a natural fan or instant sunshade. Vines, such as the dark nito and the reddish sigid, also come into use as they are valued for strength and decorative potential; their dark tones are used in contrast with lighter-toned materials. Folk ingenuity has made use of materials from bark, leaf, vine, bamboo, rattan, fern, pine needle, and pine cone. The use of such a wide range of materials implies an intimate understanding of their natural properties so that these can be enhanced and brought to full use.

Forornamentation, naturaldyes are sometimes used, as in Maranao and Maguindanao baskets. But the very shapes themselves are aesthetically pleasing in their interplay of form and function, as basketry is highlighted not only as artifact but also as process and performance continually renewed by the folk artist. Likewise most of the ornamentation has to do with light and dark contrasts produced in the same material by alternating inner and outer skin, or in the use of different materials of contrasting tones that are woven into geometric designs. Color often plays only a secondary role, since natural dyes would little withstand the daily wear and tear of domestic or occupational use to which the baskets are subjected. Besides, their natural hues, ranging from very light brown to black, preserve the organic vitality of the materials and the precious sense of the basket having been produced from within the bosom of nature.

Originally,basketry and its related forms—for example, matweaving, hat weaving, and the craftingof personaladornments, such as anklets, with their rich geometric motifs—had a communal meaning and function. This function was to mediate between humans and nature in an animist worldview where the hunter, the farmer, and the fisher continually communed with the spirits of field, river, sky, and sea for survival and daily sustenance. On another level, these motifs and stylized natural forms signify human beings as part of nature through which they share the common vitality of all living forms.Written by Alice G. Guillermo

Sources

de los Reyes, Roberto. 1975a. Philippine Designs: Ceramics and Traditional Art Forms. Quezon City: Alemars-Phoenix Publishing House.

———. 1975b. Traditional Handicraft Art of the Philippines. Manila: Casalinda.

Guillermo, Alice G. 1988. Art, Man, and Society. Quezon City. University of the Philippines.

Lane, Robert. 1986. Philippine Basketry:An Appreciation. Manila: Bookmark Incorporated.

text:
Book design is the artistic structuring and proficient reproduction of bound pages of text and images protected by cardboard, cloth, or leather-bound covers. The creative and integrative use of images, not merely as illustration to a text, have produced the category of “book art” in the history and practice of book publication.

Many Filipino cultural groups, like the Tagalog, llocano, Pampango, and Cebuano, had a syllabary and a system of writing before the 16th century. This writing was done on pieces of bamboo or palm leaves, which may be considered the first “books” in the Philippines. The Mangyan of Mindoro and the Tagbanwa of Palawan use a native syllabary, which they etch on bamboo nodes or bamboo slats.

At the onset of the Spanish colonization, the members of the native aristocracy strove to learn the Spanish language and Roman alphabet; by the first quarter of the 17th century, they had become escribientes or escribanos (scribes or amanuenses). When the friars established presses, some of these scribes, like Luis Beltran, Tomas Pinpin, Diego Talaghay, Domingo Lagos, Jacinto Magarulao, and Raymundo Mag-isa, were trained to be printers and bookmakers. Since then, Filipinos have trained and become involved in book production, whether in the form of the more rudimentary and personal handwritten codices, or in the more impersonal product of the handpress, the printed book.

In the Spanish period, scholarly priests illuminated their writings or hired scribes to rewrite them, and painters to decorate them with borders, illuminated letters, and images. Book collectors who wished to have copies of texts, published or unpublished, similarly commissioned scribes and illuminators.

In Osario Venerable (Venerable Charnel House), Fr Agustin Maria de Castro’s compilation of biographies of Augustinian clerics in the Philippines through 1780, is found Manuel de Gracia’s painting of the adoration of the Santo Niño. Another artistic manuscript created by de Gracia is his transcription of Father de Castro’s Historia del Insigne Convento de San Pablo de Manila (History of the Noble Convent of Saint Paul of Manila), 1770, in which he painted an image of Nuestra Señora de Gracia.

Anales Ecclesiasticos de Filipinas (Ecclesiastical Annals of the Philippines), on the other hand, was commissioned by a book collector whose initials F. D. (Francisco Durano) are inscribed on the manuscript. The text, originally written in Spanish and Latin by various church scribes, chronicles church history from 1574 to 1682 through reports, appointments, and letters of correspondences. Anales, which was probably written in the late 17th century, is in the orthography and decorations of the late 18th century. Consisting of 479 folios, the Anales is replete with illuminations reminiscent of the spontaneous medieval style. For example, a report on the death of Don Fernando Montero de Espinosa, the seventh archbishop of Manila, used the letter “D” for an illustration of the dead archbishop wearing his ecclesiastical robes and headdress while lying on a funeral bier.

As 18th-century works, both de Gracia’s creations and the Anales were influenced in their layout by printed books of the same period. As manuscripts, they were, however, less rigid and regular. Other finely designed manuscripts, dating later and known to still be in existence, chiefly dwell on the pasyon, magical incantations, and local history. They continued to be visible until the 1930s, as seen in painter-poet Hernando R. Ocampo’s book of love poems.

Printing was also introduced by Spanish colonization. Initially, printing from woodblocks was used by the earliest printers, who were Chinese immigrants. At least nine works were impressed through this method until 1607, including the first books published in the country—the Wu-chi Tien-Chucheng-Chiaochen-Chuan Shih-lu (Testimony of the True Religion), a treatise on the Christian faith and other matters, 1593, and Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Española y Tagala (Christian Doctrine in the Spanish and Tagalog Languages), 1593. Both pamphlets featured illustrations on their title pages, cut from blocklike text. The layout observed a single-rule border. The text of the Doctrina was printed in the Roman alphabet in gothic type except for the translations into Tagalog, which used the old Tagalog script.

Typography came about in the early 1600s with the Libro de los Quatro Postrimerias (Book of the Four Deaths), 1604, regarded as the first material printed in this method. The printer was Juan de Vera, a devout Chinese convert. The Dominican historian Diego de Aduarte credits de Vera with “achieving everything necessary to do printing.” An analysis of the fonts as represented in local books showed that the types were cast locally, apparently identical with those from de Vera’s foundry. The punches were cut and the matrices struck in Manila. Early books were called folio or quarto to indicate their sizes depending on the number of times the sheets were folded (Buhain 1998, 8). Folio sheets, for instance, were folded once to make four pages while quarto sheets were folded twice to make eight pages. Smaller editions of books came out toward the end of the 18th century (Buhain 1998, 8). The most commonly used paper during the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries were papel de arroz or rice paper, linen paper, papel de hilo or papel de china. Book paper exclusively came from China until the late 19th century, when it was also imported from England. Binding and book covers were also very rudimentary until the mid-19th century.

The elegance of locally printed books was judged primarily by the regularity of the typesetting and the finesse of the layout. The friars, enraged by typographical errors, scolded both careless typesetters as well as scribes. The most common ornaments consisted of arabesques struck from types arranged into bands that often formed the borders of the title page. Other types of ornaments included asterisks, crosses, eggs, darts, hearts, and tendrils. In the breaks between chapters could be seen woodcuts or copper engravings of cherubs, vases of flowers, and other motifs. Important publications featured engraved illustrations. The presence of the coat of arms of a noble house or symbols of a religious order indicated their involvement with or endorsement of the contents of the book.

After 1593, the religious orders, such as the Augustinians, Franciscans, Dominicans, and Jesuits, established their own presses. By 1800, and after the expulsion of the Jesuits in 1768, only three presses remained: those of the Colegio de Santo Tomas owned by the Dominicans; the Convento de los Angeles in Sampaloc owned by the Franciscans; and the Conciliar y Real Seminario de San Carlos, which the Jesuits purchased from the Augustinians in the mid-1700s.

Published in 1713 by the Franciscans was the first book featuring illustrations complementing the text, Ang Infiernong Nabubucsan sa Tauong Christiano (The Hell That Opens for the Christians). Serving the didactic purpose of evangelization, the book presented an image of hell as a place where people burn as punishment for refusing to be converted to the Christian faith. Its pictures were engraved on copper by the Franciscan Francisco Rodriguez. In 1760, Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay, then manager of the Jesuit Press, printed Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Caloloua nang Tauong Naghihingalo (Prayers of Guidance for the Soul of the Dying). The title page was artistically adorned with type ornaments. The book also contained several copper engravings by de la Cruz Bagay himself, Francisco Suarez, and Luis Suarez. The most ornate title page was that of La Razon en las Medidas (The Reason in Measurements), a book justifying measurements used in the galleon in which the bibliographic particulars were framed within an elaborate triumphal arch drawn and engraved by Lorenzo Atlas.

With the arrival of the four-cylinder and rotary press in the 19th century, printing became more technically proficient and fast, but the personal imprint of bookmaking of the previous period vanished. The friars who were the first chief writers of both scholarly treatises and local church history, which encompassed the geography and culture of their flock, shifted their energies to censorship. Books became increasingly secular in subject, with the insulares or Spanish immigrants becoming more involved in book publishing and in supervising the press.

The most artistically designed, locally produced book in the 19th century was the Discurso Pronunciado por M.R.P. Fr Hypolito Huerta (Speech Delivered by the V.R.F. Fray Hipolito Huerta), published in 1851 by the Imprenta de Diario de Manila. The title page features a gothic arch framing the bibliographical details, constructed out of type ornaments. The most profusely illustrated locally produced book was Milicia de Jesucristo (Army of Jesus Christ), a handbook for the use of the Third Order of the Dominican Order. This was by Fr Francisco Gainza and was published in 1859. It contained some 30 engravings by Felipe Monteclaro and Carlos Borromeo.

The secularization of printing press ownership began in 1814. The first private printshop entrepreneur was Manuel Memije, proprietor of Imprenta Filipina. Modern printing presses using new letter types and involving more manpower were established in the country in the late 1840s. These were owned by Establecimiento Tipografico del Diario de Manila, which published the first daily newspaper. In 1858, Manuel Ramirez and Baltazar Giraudier established Imprenta y Litografia de Ramirez y Giraudier, which led to the publication of the illustrated magazine Ilustracion Filipina, 1859-60 and 1882. Although the book design tended to be formal and impersonal, the type design and layout were more professional. Botanical illustrations, such as Flora de Filipinas (1877-83) by Augustinian friar Manuel Blanco, documenting Philippine flora through detailed drawings of plants, underscore the transition of art production in the late 19th century from religious subject to secularization of content.

With insulares and foreigners taking over the publishing business, the indio (Christianized native) and Chinese mestizo printers opened smaller printing shops publishing mainly novenas and calendars in the vernacular. Publishers of vernacular newspapers in the provinces also printed novenas, awit and korido (metrical tales), and other printed materials. These often featured on the cover an illustration depicting the saint to whom a novena is dedicated, or a scene from the awit or korido. These pamphlets were mostly functional but not artistically or technically outstanding. Color printing was introduced in the 1890s, as seen in some extant issues of the newspaper El Pajaro Verde. The same period would also usher in photography and its usefulness in documenting everyday life in the then Spanish colony.

The American period introduced technology that is responsible for the characteristics of Philippine modern book design: glossy pages, leather or clothbound covers, colored photographs, and graphic design featuring colors and stamping in silver or gold. These artistic elements are seen in special publications, like yearbooks, anniversary issues, and school annuals. Excellently lighted pictures were reproduced in the photogravure process done mainly by Antonio Garcia Granada, professor of engraving at the University of the Philippines School (now College) of Fine Arts since its incipience in 1909. Printing the most glossy publications up to the 1960s, Carmelo and Bauermann Inc supplanted the Establecimiento Tipolitografico Ciudad Condal de Chofre y Ca, which was founded in 1880 by Salvador Chofre.

Literary materials were complemented by artistically designed book covers. Important painters, like Fernando Amorsolo and Jorge Pineda, designed book covers like that of Cantos del Tropico (Songs of the Tropics) by Manuel Bernabe, showing the Philippine muse in color. Amorsolo drew many illustrations for books, ranging from novels like Parusa ng Diyos (Punishment of God) by Severino Reyes to primary readers like the Philippine Readers by Camilo Osias, the latter printed in the United States. A locally printed, elegantly designed book was Fifty Philippine Birds by Dr Canuto O. Manuel, 1936, featuring beautiful drawings in color by Macario Ligaya.

In the 1950s, the new commercial interest in print media and advertising greatly increased enrollment in editorial design and graphic reproduction courses in fine arts schools. The proliferation of imported art posters and art books in the market contributed to a consciousness of contemporary book design. However, artists were still generally limited to design and layout of calendars, exhibition catalogues, corporate annual reports, yearbooks, posters, souvenir programs, and other promotional items. Limited editions of poetry books were published in the 1960s.

In the 1970s, illustrated books, also called coffee-table books, came into vogue. Most of their designs tended to be trendy, following modes taken from Western graphic annuals. In the following two decades, a substantial output of these expensive books have tackled a variety of topics, such as art, tourism, advertising, food, fashion, and history.

The 1974 publication Beyond Art, written and designed by Rodolfo Paras-Perez, demonstrated the many imaginative possibilities of book design even for such a scholarly topic as a treatise on the history and development of a single work of art. Paras-Perez’s other books on artists’ lives and works are Tolentino, 1976; Manansala, 1980; Sanso, 1988; and Zobel, 1990—all landmarks of book design. With himself as author and designer, there is total unity of visual design and textual content as Paras-Perez carefully elucidated the philosophy, feeling, and changing style of each artist. He also designed Epifanio San Juan’s English translation of Balagtas’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), and illustrated this with woodcuts printed from his original woodblocks.

In 1978, the book Turn of the Century, planned and produced by publisher-fictionist-essayist Gilda Cordero-Fernando and book designer Nik Ricio, was published. A recipient of international book design awards, Ricio’s excellent reinterpretation of Philippine art nouveau so strongly appealed to nostalgia and national pride that it attained the widest patronage ever for illustrated books. Perhaps the most prolific of all book artists, Ricio’s other outstanding designs are Being Filipino, 1981, History of the Burgis, 1987, The Soul Book, 1991, and The Body Book, 1993, for GCF Books.

Frey Cabading’s design for the two-volume Philippine Atlas, published by Fund for Assistance to Private Education, won a citation in the Frankfurt Book Fair in 1974. His design for Nick Joaquin’s Almanac for Manileños, 1979, received an award from the 1980 International Graphic Biennale in Czechoslovakia. He also did Felice P. Sta. Maria’s Household Antiques and Heirlooms in 1983.

The book designs of Paras-Perez, Ricio, and Cabading are exemplary not necessarily because they are concerned with what is new in the international graphic scene but because they are able to present the topics or themes of a book as conceived by the author, rendering them with distinctive visual character and impeccable reproduction. Other notable contemporary book designers are Edwina Koch Arroyo, Margarita Simpliciano, and Frances Viana, who use very simple but cosmopolitan approaches to book design. The underground press during the martial law period contributed to the spirit of protest art, as exemplified by Ulos, the cultural journal of the National Democratic Front. Artists who were members of Artista and Manunulat ng Sambayanan worked in illustrating essays, drawing comics, and collaging of images, related to issues on human rights, and the search for social justice in the Philippines.

Children’s book publication through Adarna House ushered in the collaboration of writers and visual artists. Spearheaded by Virgilio S. Almario, later National Artist for literature, flipbooks and storybooks that emphasized Philippine culture were illustrated by artists such as Marci Dans Lee, Katti Sta. Ana, Jess Abrera, and Mariano Ching, among others. Visual artists also worked for and with graphic novel publishers, such as Zines, Visprint, and Excelsior, thus combining their personal art practice with art for mass distribution.

In the late 1980s, desktop publishing came into vogue with the popularity of PCs and software such as Pagemaker, which made small-scale publishing more accessible to a wider public, including do-it-yourself mode of publication (Guillermo 2014). The computer also introduced the e-book as a new book format. E-books in portable document format (PDF) became popular because they were downloadable and did not take up too much space. In the 2000s, readers like Kindle and the iPad ushered in a new format for book design. In this format, such as that used in e-Pub, the basic unit of design is a single page as it appears on the screen. The book is a text file that is designed to be malleable, allowing freedom for readers to manipulate the font size, highlight parts, bookmark pages, and write notes. Unlike printed books and PDF files where the text is fixed, the settings in ePub can be adjusted, eventually affecting the flow of the text. In the Philippines, publishers such as Flipside and C & E books started marketing e-books to the public in late 2000. While e-books are gaining popularity, many readers still prefer the sensory lure of printed books. A 2012 National Book Development Board (NBDB) readership survey revealed that there were three million e-readers in the Philippines but that 90 percent of the 80 percent of Filipinos who read books still preferred their books in print with original covers (Lapeña 2012). The high prices of electronic reading devices have also made e-books unreachable for many. In order to attract readers to e-books, many layout artists design these to look like the physical copies in an attempt to provide readers with almost the same experience of reading a printed book.

From the 1980s to the present, various institutions have given recognition to book designers for their outstanding works. BG Y. Hernandez and Fidel Rillo are among those who have received recognition from the NBDB and the Manila Critics Circle. The Philippine Board on Books for Young People through the Alcala Prize also annually awards talented and exceptional illustrators of children’s books and books for young adults. Among those who have received the Alcala Prize are Ferdinand Doctolero, Mariano Ching, Yasmin Doctor, Hubert Fucio, and Ferdinand Guevarra.Written by Santiago A. Pilar and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Helen Yu-Rivera, with notes from Lisa Ito-Tapang and Gilbert C. Torres

Sources

Buhain, Dominador D. 1998. A History of Publishing in the Philippines. Quezon City: Rex Book Store.

Lapeña, Carmela G. 2012. “The ebook: Still in Its Early Days in PHL, But a Growing Option.” GMA News Online. Posted 26 Aug. Accessed 29 Sep 2014. http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/271256/lifestyle/.
