text:
Dress refers to the garments or articles of apparel worn by individuals or groups of individuals in a given society and at a given time. Dress is usually complemented by specific accessories and hairstyles for each group, community, or nation. If a particular type of dress becomes popular at a specific era and location, it becomes the “fashion” of the time. When the dress for past historical periods are recreated for the present whether for theatrical performances, religious rituals, or social occasions, it is usually called a costume.

Dress may differ according to gender (male, female, others), class (slave, free person, noble, lower class, middle class, or upper class), age (child, youth, adult, or elderly), civil status (single, married, or widowed), occupation (peasant, merchant, soldier, teacher, priest, and others), rank (governor-general, bishop, or mayor during the Spanish colonial period), and personal taste of an individual. Variations may also occur because of differences in climate (lowland or highland); foreign relations (open to influences from other countries or isolated from all other nations); cultural influence (colonized by a Western nation for many centuries or exposed to the mass media of today); and indigenous, regional, or organizational identity (uniform patterns, cuts, and colors used by one ethnolinguistic group to distinguish themselves from other groups, whether ethnic, lowland, or modern urban).

More than any other form of culture, dress reflects the dominant traditions as well as the emergent values and aspirations of a given people. To trace the shifting silhouettes of Philippine apparel, therefore, is to discern the structures of as well as the major changes in Philippine society from the indigenous to the Spanish, American, and post-World War II periods.

The Living Indigenous Tradition

The precolonial dresses worn by the indigenous peoples of the archipelago are similar to many of those worn by other indigenous groups in Malaysia and Indonesiaand are typified by the attires of the late 16th-century Tagalog. Tagalog males wore loose waist-length, collarless baro or shirts, which had short or long sleeves. These shirts could be of cotton, linen, or muslin, and were usually blue or black for commoners but red (called chininas) for chiefs. To cover the lower half of the body, the Tagalog had the cotton bahaque or bahag, a strip of colored cloth passed around the waist and between the legs reaching halfway down the thighs (Morga in Blair and Robertson 7:75-7). Tubular skirts, like today’s sarong, could also be passed between the legs and tucked onto the front of the waist or worn crossed over the shoulder, the other end under one arm. Accessories included a balarao (short sword) hanging from the waist; a long and narrow putong folded in many fancy ways around the head; and jewelry-like gold-chain necklaces, gold armlets called calombigas, chainlets worn from the calf to the knees, rings of gold and precious stones, and bracelets of gold or ivory. The Boxer Codex, circa 1590, provides the earliest visual documentation of the male and female dresses of the Tagalog, Visaya, Zambal, Cagayanon, and Aeta.

Tagalog women covered the lower part of the body with a barrel skirt like a sarong, which was knotted at one side. On top of this skirt was sometimes wrapped a kirtle of silk decorated with gold embroidery on the fringes. For tops they wore small, loose, collarless jackets with short or long sleeves and reaching to the waist. Called varo or baro these could be made of all colors, and embroidered around the neckline and sleeve ends. They wore neither shoes nor underwear but were laden with (mostly gold) jewelry, which included huge hoop earrings, several necklaces, bracelets, rings with precious stones, and anklets. Hair was usually anointed with oils and perfumes, tied up in a knot and decorated with ribbons or flowers (Morga in Blair and Robertson 7:77-8). Upper-class females may even wear golden diadems.

Dress similar to those of the precolonial Tagalog continued to be worn by other ethnic groups in the islands, specifically among the five percent who were not substantially changed by Spanish and American colonization. Similar to the Tagalogbahag is the wanes or G-string of the Bontok male. This long piece of woven cloth, approximately 20.32 cm wide and 2.13 m long, is passed once between the legs and several times around the hips, leaving its two end panels hanging freely on the front and at the back. Naturally dyed in red, black, and white, the G-string may be decorated with patterns of horses, snakes, lizards, spears, and shields. Round hats with feathers, pipes, necklaces with fertility pendants, bolo hung from the side, or wraparound blankets for the cold may complement the Bontoc male apparel.

Bontok females wear a traditional wraparound rectangular skirt, called lufid or gat-teng, which has three versions: the knee length, two-panelled skirt called kinarchago, which is for working in the fields or the house; a longer three-panelled skirt called the inorma or pinagpakan, for special feasts and occasions; and the dark-colored kayin worn only by the dead. To fasten the lufid, the Bontok woman wears a long white sash or belt, provided with fringes at both ends. Called wak-es or bakget, this sash is tied twice around the waist and over the skirt, and secured by a knot at the back. Before World War II, most women woreno blouses but only exquisite tattoos on their arms, breasts, and necks. The hair was held up by strings of beads or with dried snake vertebrae, a talisman against lightnings and angry anito. Blankets serving as pockets were slung over shoulders to hold babies, vegetables, or rice seedlings.

Thetraditional Bagobo apparel likewise recalls the old Tagalog. To this day, Bagobo males wear, for special occasions, the knee-length breeches of woven abaca cloth held up by a belt, and the long-sleeved abaca jackets, which are open in front. The dark patterns of the waxed abaca cloth are enlivened by small beads and shell sequins sewn onto both the pants and jacket in dense complex patterns. Similar to the Tagalog putong and Visayan puron, the Bagobo tangkulo is a large piece of red cloth decorated with beads and tassels at the edges, and folded in many ways to crown the male’s head. A long bolo hanging from a belt on the side, bags trimmed with tassels and bells, bracelets, necklaces, and anklets are the usual accessories.

Bagobo women’s traditional costumes are the ankle-length barrel skirt of handwoven abaca fiber, which is folded in front of the waist and secured with a belt, and the long-sleeved, collarless, waist-length blouses, which used to be of abaca but are now usually of commercial cotton. Blouses are decorated with beads, sequins, and embroidery. Hoop earrings, several bead necklaces, brass bracelets from waist to elbow, and several anklets with bells complete the Bagobo female costume.

Aside from the typical dress for males and females of the tribes, each tribe had special garments for the different classes like the nobility, freemen, and slaves, as well as key personalities like the datu and the shamans. Their clothes were distinguished by the kind of materials used (imported silks or damasks) or the amount and quality of jewelry worn all over the body.

As a whole, the indigenous attires of native Filipinos reveal an intriguing complex of meanings. Through their clothes, the natives came to terms with nature. In extracting threads from cotton and abaca and color from native plants, the nativesharnessed nature toward their own needs. In embroidering and weaving suns, stars, snakes, lizards, flowers, and birds into their clothes and snake vertebrae into their apparel, they established harmony with nature. In wearing loose, collarless garments made of natural fibers and wearing light and minimal clothing, they conquered the tropical climate by opening up to it.

Moreover, through their clothes, the indigenous Filipinos reaffirmed the priorities and values, as well as the hierarchies, of the ethnolinguistic group. In glorifying the warrior who wore the most number of tattoos among the Bisaya and the red or embroidered putong among the Tagalog, bravery was enshrined as one of the most important values in the tribe, and one essential to its survival. In allowing the shaman to vest himself or herself in special clothes (sometimes female garb for male shamans), they underscored the importance of the native priest as the medium to the gods, who must be placated to ensure a good harvest, victory in war, health for the infirm, prosperity and well-being for the newly born, the newly baptized, the newly wed, and a comfortable afterlife for their beloved departed.

Finally, through their apparel and the material culture that went with them, the indigenous people underscored and secured its identity as a group separate from others. This identity served as a rallying point against invaders, both local and foreign. Thus the Tausug insisted on wearing their turbans in face of the European cultural onslaught,just as the Tinguian refused to give up their G-strings in spite of the Spanish orders and threats of incarceration. Dress, like the native animism, were an antidote to colonization.

The Hispanic Tradition and Local Transformations

In 1565 Miguel Lopez de Legazpi started the systematic colonization of the islands. Pueblos founded by the Spaniards became the centers for the propagation of Christian and Hispanic culture. After burning the vestiges of what they called the pagan culture of the natives, the Spaniards set themselves up as the model for imitation in everything, from religion to dress.

In the 18th century, the indio or colonized man donned garments that began to show some European influence. The Tagalog male wore knee-length breeches called salawal; a baro or native shirt, now with collars, cuffs, and cravat, but worn untucked; a square putong that could be used as a headpiece or a handkerchief; and for formal occasions, the lambong gathered and draped across the torso from one shoulder.

The india or colonized woman still wore her precolonial baro (blouse), saya (barrel skirt), tapis (overskirt), and a kerchief. For gala occasions, however, a square pañuelo was folded diagonally and placed over the woman’s shoulders and modestly crossed over her breasts. Slippers or shoes, rosary necklaces, and scapulars began to take the place of indigenous bead or gold necklaces. Significant was the introduction of strings to draw the upper part of the barrel skirt tight around the woman’s waist. The 18th-century dresses of native males and females are documented in the vignettes that Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay etched around the Murillo Velarde map of the Philippines in 1734.

With the opening of the islands to world trade in the 19th century, the new agricultural export economy brought untold wealth to the mestizo families whose lands were planted to abaca, copra, sugar, coffee, and tobacco. This new economic and political elite sought to be equal to the Spaniards—in religion, education, language, cuisine, and fashion.

In the beginning of the century, upper-class males sported striped or plain, loose silk pantaloons called saya-saya, which were embroidered at the hem. Over this was worn a shirt of transparent, embroidered piña (pineapple fiber) or jusi (pineapple fiber mixed with banana fiber) with collars, cuffs, and cravats. Top hat, shoes (but no socks), and handkerchiefs underscored the costume’s European aspirations. Lower-class males continued to wear the knee-length breeches of the previous centuries, and a loose long-sleeved shirt with a collar.

At the same time, wealthy ladies reinterpreted the baro-saya-pañuelo ensemble according to the silhouette of the Napoleonic era. In the 1830s mestizas wore the empire-waisted saya with short, tight-fitting baro and small pañuelo, complemented with piña veils, handkerchiefs, and slippers; or the normal saya gathered tight with a tapis, and a baro with long, tight, cuffed sleeves, worn with wide shawls and Spanish veils. The fashions of the 1830s are amply documented by the tipos del pais (inhabitants of the country) albums of Damian Domingo.

By the 1850s, informal wear for rich mestizos included European-type pants and shoes, and the baro of handwoven piña or jusi. Plain or striped, the baro had a European-type collar, cuffs, and buttons in front, although it remained untucked, even when a frac or coat with tails was worn over it for formal affairs. 100"> Embroidery decorated the shirt. For weddings, fiestas, and other formal affairs, the elite could opt for completely European ensembles. Top hat, cane, and handkerchief embellished a gentleman’s costume. Males of the lower classes now wore light colored cotton pants with drawstrings at the waist, and long-sleeved, collarless shirts that fell to the middle of the thighs, and the putong resembling a large kerchief.

By the 1860s, Victorian crinolines started to invade Manila. The saya began to flare out from the waist down with the help of several petticoats, while the baro adopted the wide Victorian angel sleeves, and the pañuelo interpreted itself as a European fichu. Baro, pañuelo, and saya came in bright colors and usually in stripes big and small, but the tapis tended to be dark in hue. Combs, hair pins, earrings, necklaces, rings, bracelets, and slippers completed the attire of the affluent classes. Women of the lower classes still wore the baro of sinamay with sleeves that had started to widen. Over this chemise was worn an alampay (big kerchief), either folded diagonally and thrown over both shoulders or folded horizontally and thrown over one shoulder. Cotton saya in bright checks or stripes were covered tight with silk tapis from Baliuag. Tapis and alampay were usually matched. Small criolla earrings and scapulars were used by the lower classes. Mid-19th-century apparels are recorded in the albums and paintings of Jose Lozano and C. W. Andrews.

By the end of the century, male formal fashions from the upper class caught up with the European, especially because the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869 facilitated both the arrival in the Philippines of more Europeans, European goods and magazines, as well as the travel of Filipinos to Europe. By the end of the century, another type of suit became popular among students. Made of white linen or cotton, the americana cerrada from South America featured a white coat that was buttoned in front, all the way up to the upright collar.

By the end of the century, the loose, collarless, long-sleeved baro or shirt of the lower-class male began to have buttons in front and was called the camisa de chino (Chinese shirt). This could be made of local or imported material—plain, printed, or embroidered—with or without a pocket. Cotton pajama-like pants continued to be used by the working class, but more formal occasions called for the long European-type pantalon (pants). The putong now became a panyo or handkerchief, and salakot (wide, round hats) of gourd or nito vine were embellished with silver ornaments to distinguish the native cabeza. As demanded by urbanized society, even indios now began to subject themselves to the ordeal of wearing slippers at mass or for visits with the upper class.

By the end of the century, the European bustle ensemble, which drew the skirt up to the derriere and allowed it to fall behind in a sumptuous train, inspired the skirt ofthe so-called maria clara. Named after the heroine of JoseRizal’s novel NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not), 1887, this ensemble consisted of a gala skirt that flared out in a rounded cola or train at the back. The skirt was usually made of imported Chinese silks, velvets, or satins, used whole or cut into alternating gores. The saya could now be worn de suelta or loose, meaning without a tapis in imitation of French fashions. The baro had wide sleeves, whose design often matched that of the sloped pañuelo. The piña or jusi of both baro and pañuelo could be dyed in pastels or dark colors (the latter for old people or for widows), but dyed or not, both always flaunted the labor (embroidery) of flowers, birds, butterflies, as well as the names and monograms of the owner. A short- or long-sleeved, round-collared undershirt called chambra modestly covered the torso under the transparent baro and pañuelo, while salawal (drawers), medias (stockings), and enaguas (long slips) were wornunder the saya. Jewelry included peinetas (gold combs) and agujillas (hair pins); aretes (earrings) of sinampaloc (tamarind-like) or rosita (roselike) design; necklaces of the alpahor (flat chain) or tamborin (round, filigree beads) type with pendants of crucifix or oval relicario (reliquary) called agnos or gold-embroidered scapulars hanging from golden chains; pulseras (bracelets) and singsing (rings) of many designs and stones; an alfiler (brooch) for the pañuelo; a porta abanico or abaniquera chain for the imported fan, and a llavera (key holder) for the household keys.

A drastic reorientation of Philippine dress occurred during the Spanish period. First and foremost, dress served to reflect and reaffirm the highly stratified structure of colonial society. The descending order of the economic, political, and social hierarchy corresponded to the diminishing degrees of Hispanization in dress, with the Spaniards, both the peninsulares (born in Spain) and the insulares (born in the Philippines), insisting on the European attires in formal, and even not so formal, occasions; the mestizos, both españoles and sangleyes, wearing mainly native ensembles but interpreted according to the fashionable silhouettes from Europe and garnished with imported European accessories; the indios or colonized natives donning the least Europeanized and most practical clothes; and everybody else outside the hierarchy, including the Chinese, Muslims, and lumad, wearing their indigenous attires underscoring their lack of Hispanization.

Second, most notable among the mestizos is the phenomenon of Hispanization that to them was requisite to or accompanied political assimilation of the colony and its representation in the Madrid government. As mestizos worked for equal rights with the Spanish, so they vied with one anotherto acquire the latest food and furniture, ditties and dances from Europe. In fashion, some wealthy half-breeds even imported European clothes, not only from Madrid but from Paris, even as they reshaped the baro-saya-pañuelo ensemble to evoke the empire, the crinoline, and the bustle silhouettes of 19th-century Europe. Hats and shoes, coats and cravats, as well as crinolines, corsets, bustles, and petticoats were imported to underscore the level of “civilization” of the nouveaux riches. Furthermore, to divide the indio cabezas from the mestizo gobernadorcillos and delegados, the former were required to wear the native salakot, while the latter could wear European top hats or bowlers.

But Hispanization was not the only goal of these ensembles; for Hispanization also underscored the values of class and gender that the new landed elite espoused. Since the importation of clothes and accessories presumed extraordinary wealth, their use immediately set off the wearer as belonging to a class that was different from the ordinary powerless indio. Jewelry, embroidery, nipis (finest piña material for baro and panuelo), and brocades distanced the ilustrado (educated) from the uneducated masses, and awed the peasant into openmouthed admission of the superiority of the class that owned the lands he tilled and had the ear of the powerful friar. Similarly, the Hispanic dress emphasized the concept of woman that fitted in perfectly with a system of patriarchal landownership. In this system, woman was treated as prime property whose virginity had to be guarded under layers of clothing to ensure a “correct” marriage, and as the extension of a husband whose will she must follow, whose children she must bear, and whose reflection she must be.

No matter how hard the ilustrado tried, however, they could never be completely Hispanized—whether in politics or in fashion—for many conditions precluded the complete acceptance of European fashions. For one thing, the tropical weather necessarily modified or eliminated certain silhouettes—for example, corsets and petticoats were unbearable in a Philippine climate. Moreover, the ilustrados could only import so much dressing material. More often than not, they had to make do with locally woven fabrics like piña, jusi, sinamay, and maguey, which when used for European cuts like the empire, just did not “work.” Similarly, motifs for embroidery were drawn from the gumamela, sampaguita, anahao, as well as banana and coconut trees of the immediate surrounding; color combinations—checks combining red-oranges with canary yellow and aquamarines—related more to ethnic colors and tropical vegetation than to European aesthetics. The result was, happily enough, dress indigenized for local use, foreign in ambition but clearly native in general feel and function.

The American Tradition and Local Transformations

By the end of the century, industrial America, coveting bigger markets and raw materials, expanded its territories. It co-opted the leaders of the Philippine Revolution, established itself as the new ruler of the island, and embarked on an Americanization process that was effected through a national network of schools and a cultural occupation that became more powerful with the coming of film, radio, and, after the war, television.

In fashion, America soon replaced Europe as the fashion capital for the Filipino. In the first three decades, informal wear for upper- and middle-class males consisted of the americana abierta (north American suit), whose silhouette changed (sleek or wide, tight or loose) through the decades as dictated by Hollywood movies. Balls called for formal Western tails or dinner jackets or the chaquetilla (a waist-length formal jacket) and their corresponding ensembles. For everyday casual wear, both the upper- and the lower-class males would wear the camisa de chino or the barong tagalog. By the late 1930s, President Quezon had elevated the barong as national male costume with he himself wearing it as president of the new Commonwealth of the Philippines. This barong, which is embroidered with the Commonwealth flag crisscrossed with the United States flag, was called the Commonwealth barong tagalog with the Tydings-Mcduffie motif. In spite of this endorsement, however, Western attire continued to be used by university students, professionals, businessmen, and government officials, mainly because Western dress was associated with enlightenment and efficiency taught by Western or Westernized tutors.

The baro-saya-pañuelo ensemble continued to be the main dress ensemble for lower- and upper-class women in the first three decades, its contours now taking their cue from American fashions. In the first two decades, the bell skirt and leg-of-mutton sleeves and the general silhouette of the Gibson girl were reproduced by stiff saya of pinukpok (beaten abaca) or starched cotton prints that flared out through the serpentina or mascota cut. In the first, the saya was fashioned straight from the waist to a little below the knee, where it was then cut in serpentlike waves, to which were sewn on the bias, a wide bottom panel of the same material. In the second, the cut at the knee was straight all around, to which were attached upright triangles of the same cloth sewn onto the upper skirt on the bias. To approximate the fullness of the leg-of-mutton sleeves, women starched their sinamay baro, while pañuelos stiffened to create triangles framing the women’s delicate necks. Long scarves or feather boas sometimes replaced the pañuelo for less formal occasions. In this and the succeeding periods, Pacita Longos and Pura Escurdia were the modistas much sought after by the elite.

By 1925, a new costume had evolved, drawing inspiration from the Vionnet gown, which was elegant, softly curved, and slender waisted. It had a baro, whose sleeves were shortened to allow freedom of movement, and a pañuelo of the same material and design as the baro. The saya was elegantly straight, with a long pointed cola that could be tucked onto one side of the waist while walking or held with one hand when dancing. Because the design of the saya was appliquéd or embroidered, sinuksok-style, on the pañuelo and the baro, this three-piece matching ensemble is popularly known as the terno. By the late 1930s, Ramon Valera combined the baro and saya into one gown with a zipper at the back, raised and stiffened the butterfly sleeves, and made the pañuelo optional and, later, dispensable. This new version aimed for the comfort of the single-unit American gown of the period.

But considerations of practicality in the urban setting began to erode the popularity of the baro’t saya ensemble especially in urban centers and among the new generation of American-educated Filipinas in the city and the countryside. These modern Filipinas preferred to wear the the vestido or knee-length Western dress, which can be considered as the most important contribution of America to Philippine fashion. First worn by the students of the Philippine Normal School in the 1910s, the dress caught on and eventually eclipsed the terno as everyday wear, as more and more women began to study and work as professionals and adopt Americanized ways. Two silhouettes of the vestido became popular. In the 1910s to the 1920s, the dress with a dropped waistline, with long or short sleeves, closed or open necked, sometimes with collar or bib, was worn by girls and young ladies. The hemline fluctuated between knee and ankle level. In the 1930s, the Vionnet dress, which had a slender waist and emphasized gentle curves and slinky fabrics, became the formal mode. Stockings, shoes, and handbags were imported from the United States for both ensembles.

American fashions were introduced to the Philippines by local and American magazines, and most especially through the movies from the late 1920s to the early 1940s, which featured American actors wearing these suits, dresses, gowns, accessories, hairstyles, and makeup. Print media and cinema conspired to create in the Filipino artificial needs for American-type clothes and accessories. As Teodoro M. Kalaw observed, because of the “Americanization of our wants and needs” we “find ourselves unnecessarily forced to use foreign objects, or to prefer the foreign to our own, on account of the failure of our own ways” (Tiongson in Nograles-Lumbera 1982).

But even as Filipinos strove to follow American fashions, these fashions could not help but be adapted to the Philippine situation. Native fabrics, local motifs, and a folk sense of color came into play in the design and construction of these attires, thereby changing and modifying the original look and silhouette from the United States.

Significant in Philippine fashion and culture is the adoption by Filipinas of the American vestido, which introduced a whole new set of values for women. For many Filipinas who were previously encased in the terno, which hampered movement and discouraged spontaneity, the vestido meant “liberation” because it allowed a woman to turn, bend, tilt, sway, stretch, and relax; corollarily, it encouraged her to feel, think, speak, and act on her own and as she pleased. Although the acceptance of the vestido may be seen as another evidence of colonial imitation, it may also be read as both result and proof of the development of women as professionals and workers wanting to be as efficient and mobile as the men in the workplace. Interestingly, in the American period and the post-World War II era, the American philosophy of casual and practical dressing helped to erode colonial and class standards and even to break the indiscriminate imitation of the icons of fashion, whether local or foreign.

The Philippine Dress 1946-2016

Post-World War II Philippine fashion continued to be dominated by the vagaries of American modes, as these were encountered in movies, television, and fashion magazines. The male fashions for formal and everyday wear as well as the terno and the more casual vestido or dress, continued to reproduce American silhouette, especially in the 1950s and 1960s.

In the 1950s, the fashionable male wore white sharkskin suits, with flamboyant silk ties, Ray-ban glasses, and pointed tango shoes. The more casual wear, however, were simple, long-sleeved trubenized shirts tucked into high-waisted, deep-pleated wide pants.

The Dior A-line was popularized in the Philippines by Grace Kelly movies. The “new look” was interpreted in a one-piece dress or in a two-piece ensemble with puffed-sleeve blouse, both with the signature wide flaring, below-the knee skirt. In the same decade, the same balloon skirts were “deflated” and began to hug the figure in the new line called the “pencil cut.” Both silhouettes are reflected in three female ensembles of the 1950s: the “A-line” terno whose skirts flared out with multiple layers of petticoats and tulle; the “pencil cut” figure-hugging, ankle-length lame or velvet terno; and the “mermaid” terno, which was “pencil cut” to the knee, and “balloon” from the knee down. For “wienie roasts” and “barn dances,” pedal pushers were preferred. Skin-tight toreadors, which were so tight they had to be held down by stirrups, appeared at the turn of the decade.

An important breakthrough for the barong tagalog happened in the term of President Ramon Magsaysay who wore the barong tagalog to his inauguration, and thereafter to all occasions, formal and semiformal, in keeping with his image as a “man of the masses” and as a conscious strategy to dissociate himself from the Quirino administration, which became known for its luxurious lifestyle. From then on, the barong tagalog was worn by all classes for all kinds of occasions, acquiring legitimacy and dignity in the eyes of all Filipinos. This, however, did not happen to the terno, which became the favorite of socialites who wore them in different couturier versions to the grandest balls in the 1950s and 1960s of the Kahirup, the Mancomunidad Pampangueña, and the Club Filipino. For ordinary female folk who could not afford the terno, it was the short balintawak as well as the kimona and saya that were used for formal wear and everyday clothes, respectively.

In the 1960s, men’s formal wear made them disappear in the dark, because it invariably was a suit of imported dark material like marzotto, worn with a small-collared trubenized shirt, a nondescript tie thin as the coat’s lapels, and a tiny tie pin. Less formal wear meant long-sleeved shirts, polo shirts, and Banlon T-shirts. Later in the decade, blazers or Edwardian coats came into fashion even as pants began to bell-bottom.

The early 1960s saw the shift and sack dress becoming popular, especially with matrons. But no sooner had the shift established itself than the tent dress came to the fore, with haltered neck and no sleeves, sporting a line most appropriate for the young. By the mid-1960s, the miniskirt invented by Mary Quant took the Philippines by storm, the way the Beatles did. Skirts went so high special minipants had to be invented as a safeguard against wanton winds and eyes. The mini was matched by twiggy makeup, haircuts, shoes, and accessories.

The 1970s saw everyone turning more and more to casual clothes that allowed freedom of movement or “character” clothes that allowed one to be one’s self and to “do one’s own thing.” With the rise of activism, dressing up became “burgis” (bourgeois) or plain “corny.” “Casual” or “rugged” became the rule, and this often meant bell-bottom pants and T-shirts and long hair “blowing in the wind.” Just the same, a wide range of female fashions showcased various lengths for clothes (long, maxi, midi, mini, hot), many types of attires (pants, pantsuits, caftans, kurtas, T-shirts, blouse and skirt, comfort-fit, biggie), and a wide array of “looks” (rugged, formal, hippy, way-out, revivalist). It was this decade, too, that saw gender differences erased in many articles of clothing—for example, pants, jackets, caftans, shirts, socks, shoes, bags, glasses, and underwear. The cry of the restless 1970s was equality, diversity, and freedom from all constraints.

During the martial law period from 1972 to 1986, the national dress became even more politicized as the Marcos couple, positioning themselves as the “parents” of the New Society, promoted their own brand of nationalism by emphasizing pride in what was Filipino, whether in architecture (e.g., the Coconut Palace), events (e.g., the Kasaysayan ng Lahi), or dress (e.g., Imelda Marcos’s fashion show Bagong Anyo). In 1975, Marcos proclaimed a week in June as Barong Tagalog week. Most of all, the first family took to wearing the barong tagalog and the terno in official portraits and most formal occasions. While the barong tagalog, in the 1970s and 1980s, became the object of experimentation by designers who wanted it to become haute couture (e.g., the Cardin barong of 1971, which was tapered, buttoned in front, with simple cuffs and less embroidery), now it sported simple geometric designs associated with the modern Marcos style. Marcos himself wore the traditional barong in all formal occasions and the shirt jacket version in all other occasions. In the 1980s the informal, office-type polo barong, of polyester material which was buttoned in front and could be long-sleeved or short-sleeved, with or without pockets, began to rise in popularity. On the other hand, Imelda Marcos decked herself in eye-catching ternos (without pañuelos) by leading couturiers not only for state events but almost all events where she guested including derelict barrios, mesmerizing the commonfolk with attires that recalled the aesthetics of jeepney art or okir panolong. Like Asian royalty, she was shielded from sun and rain by a wide umbrella carried by a statuesque aide. Because of her ubiquitous ternos and immense powers, Imelda was called the “Iron Butterfly.” Thus were the national costumes used to project a benevolent patriotic image for the couple even as they plundered the economy through their conjugal kleptocracy.

In the aftermath of the Aquino assassination in 1983, the emphasis turned to commonsense dressing in the midst of political crisis. T-shirts and denims were the rule, and these were often used to identify political camps (yellow for Cory and Ninoy; red, white, and blue for Marcos and Imelda; and red for the forces of the Left) as well as to communicate messages, like “Marcos Pa Rin” (We’re Still for Marcos), “Hindi Ka Nag-iisa” (You Are Not Alone), or “Kung Hindi Tayo Kikilos, Sino ang Kikilos?” (If We Do Not Act, Who Will?). After the fall of the Marcoses in 1986, President Corazon Aquino replaced the formal terno associated with Imelda Marcos, with the wide-sleeved, collarless, and embroidered kimona (in jusi or piña) worn over a long sleeveless gown of the same or other materials. The focus was still on the Filipino but with emphasis on austerity and simplicity, in reaction to the extravagance and excess that now began to be called “Imeldific” after the lady with 3,000 pairs of shoes.

This casual orientation on clothes continued to the 1990s and 2000s. Formal wear continued to be the soft-line kimona and skirt for females and barong tagalog of many designs and materials for males, especially during the decade of the centennial celebrations from 1986 to 1998. Casual wear included slacks and polo shirts and, for the younger generations, denims and T-shirts. The last even became the canvas for artistic expression as artists like Benedicto Cabrera aka BenCab, Neil Doloricon, Egay Fernandez, and Nunelucio Alvarado popularized their Philippine-themed artworks through T-shirts. For their part, Stariray, Sari-Sari, and Pidro-File came out with all types of Filipiniana designs—from butong pakwan (watermelon seeds) wrappers to the cover of the Doctrina Christiana (Christian Doctrine) of 1593. Today the growth of ready-to-wear retailers found in shopping malls has further streamlined the consumption of clothes and apparels in urban centers.

Renewed interest in the terno began to be felt in the decades of the 1990s to the 2010s. The interest took the form of more scholarly studies on the evolution of the terno, which was pioneered by Salvador Bernal and Georgina Encanto in their book Patterns for the Filipino Dress: From the Traje de Mestiza to the Terno, 1992, and further developed by Patis Tesoro ’s The Art of Embellishment, 1994, Jose R. Moreno’s Philippine Costume, 1995, Gilda Cordero Fernando’s Jamming on an Old Saya, 1995, Slim, 2009, and Gino Gonzales and Mark Higgins’s Fashionable Filipinas, 2015. Similarly, the barong tagalog and its history have been the subjects of books like Visitacion de la Torre’s The Barong Tagalog: The Philippine National Wear, 1986, which was updated into The Barong Tagalog: Then and Now, 2000, and Tesoro’s The Art of Embellishment.

Aside from these historical studies on the national costume, a new perspective on fashion as art began to gain ground with the Salvador Bernal exhibits From the Traje de Mestiza to the Terno in 1992, and Ramon Valera and the Terno in 1994, the art-fashion show Jamming on an Old Saya, which had four artist-designers interpreting the terno in 1995, and the Metropolitan Museum’s exhibit of historical ternos in 2003. The recognition of fashion in general and the terno in particular as art forms became final with the inclusion of fashion as an artistic category in the National Artist Awards and the proclamation of Ramon Valera as the first National Artist for fashion design in 2006. Today, the terno continues to be interpreted in many imaginative ways by leading Filipino designers both here and abroad, and showcased in weddings, Santacruzan, beauty contests, and formal rigodons of elite balls. However, unlike the barong tagalog, which is used for everyday and formal wear, the terno has become mainly a costume for special events. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
An effigy is an image, likeness, or representation of a person, made in order to be destroyed or burnt in protest or as expression of anger. Effigies commonly paraded and burned during mass demonstrations are considered a “striking and effective form of protest art” (Guillermo 2001).

Beginning in the mid-1970s, hundreds of effigies have been produced ranging from simple figures to life-size, elaborately designed, and moving puppets. They are made from locally available and inexpensive materials, usually from papier-mâché, cardboard, or straw. These are collectively produced by activist and artist organizations. They are displayed alongside street paintings, masks, posters, flags, banners, and other forms as a visual highlight, conveying the main theme of the protest action and complementing the repertoire of speeches, songs, manifestos, and slogans of the event. The sight of an effigy can attract members of mass media, protesters, and bystanders: eliciting attention, laughter, commentary, and even physical blows as they are paraded during the march. They are created in order to be destroyed; usually mauled and burned during or toward the end of the demonstration in order to symbolize the people’s triumph over common adversaries. The largest and most elaborate Philippine effigies have been produced for the annual rallies during the State of the Nation Address of the Philippine president or for large protests on Labor Day, International Human Rights Day, and similar events.

Historically, the form of the effigy is related to the religious and folk pageantry of the Spanish colonial era, assimilated from missionaries who encouraged the local populace to accept the new religion and foreign rule. Tall figures called higantes (giant puppets) appear in some fiestas, such as those in Angono, Rizal. With moveable papier-mâché heads and wearing peasant costumes over bamboo frames, the higantes are carried and manipulated by operators hidden inside the frames. Effigies of the Biblical apostle Hudas (Judas) have been burned or exploded in religious playlets across Bulacan, Pampanga, Panay, and Cebu. When colonial control over the archipelago shifted from Spain to the United States in the 20th century, activities such as the hanging of effigies of officials could be considered seditious acts.

The use of the effigy as a form of protest art developed considerably since the post-World War II era. By the 1960s, simple straw or papier-mâché effigies and cardboard coffins were used as agitational propaganda by activists opposing American presence in Vietnam and Cuba. They were made by artistically trained or inclined activists or by members of Kabataang Makabayan’s cultural arm, the Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista at Arkitekto, founded in 1971. The effigy, however, disappeared during martial law. Instead, activists developed forms, such as cardboard cutouts and masks that could easily be concealed and used for “lightning rallies.”

From the late 1970s to the early 1980s, the effigy resurfaced along with rising resistance to the Marcos dictatorship. The growth of the legal democratic movement through organizations such as the Bagong Alyansang Makabayan or BAYAN also produced a new patron and audience for larger forms of protest art. Organizations, such as the Concerned Artists of the Philippines and MASKARA, both founded in 1983, and Artistang Bayan, founded in 1985, responded to the visual needs of mass actions by making murals, streamers, and effigies. Theater groups also used effigies for “effigy-lantern” plays, dulansangan (street plays), and annual “Calvary of the Poor” marches appropriated from Lenten rituals.

By the mid-1980s, more effigies were made as demonstrations against Marcos grew larger and more frequent. They ranged from caricatures of political personalities to representations of American imperialism, usually through the figure of Uncle Sam. Examples would be effigies of President Marcos and Uncle Sam featured on the cover of Newsweek, 4 Nov 1985. But effigies were not always representations of the enemy. They could also convey images of a nascent nation, such as the effigy of Inang Bayan (Motherland) for the People’s Cultural Caravan in 1986. They could also represent marginalized social groups, such as the higante of workers and peasants used by the Kilusang Mayo Uno for the May Day Rally in 2000.

Since the late 1990s, more elaborate projects were initiated by BAYAN in collaboration with new organizations, such as UGATLahi Artists Collective, founded in 1992. UGATLahi has since made over 40 effigies. The group developed mechanized or “kinetic” effigies that could be made to move by using a system of pulleys and levers, as the artist-activists experimented with the use of new materials, styles, and symbols. UGATLahi’s larger and more popular effigies, such as Erapzilla , Reclining Erap, and the portrayals of cronies and government officials as in Lechon Baboy (Roasted Pigs), were made during the campaign for Estrada’s ouster in 2000. In 2013, pig effigies were used once again to protest the corruption of government officials in using the Priority Development Assistance Fund (PDAF), popularly known as the pork barrel scam.

Effigies have served as a barometer for the various issues and controversies faced by each administration. Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, 2001-10, was among the heads of state most portrayed in effigy. References to a Pandora’s Box of evils were conveyed through Gloria in a Box, 2001. She was portrayed as both parasite and predator: the giant Bye-Glo: Pesteng Pangulong Arroyo (Bye-Glo: President Arroyo the Pest), 2002, and Gloria Buwitre (Gloria Vulture), 2004. She was also represented as intent on remaining in office through Running Glo, 2003, and Kapit Tukong Gloria (Gloria Clinging to Power), 2005. Criticisms of human rights violations under Arroyo’s term were conveyed through the effigies Hitler Diktador Tuta Gloria (Hitler, Dictator, Lapdog Gloria), 2006, and Reyna ng Kadiliman, Manananggal ng Karapatan (Queen of Darkness, Violator of Rights), 2007. In the last years of Arroyo’s term, she was portrayed as a captain abandoning ship in MV Pilipinas, 2008, and as a decaying monster in Gloria Forever, 2009.

When President Benigno Aquino III assumed office in 2010, he was first portrayed in effigy as a magician conjuring promises and illusions. Noynoy Magician, however, was not burned to challenge Aquino to act on reforms he promised. In subsequent SONA protests, however, activists conveyed their disappointment with Aquino by representing him as a rotten egg in Giant PeNoy, 2011; as a two-faced monster feasting with foreign and elite powers in Two-Face, 2012; and as a giant feasting while the nation starves, 2013. Written byLisa Ito-Tapang

Sources

Guillermo, Alice G. 2001b. Protest/Revolutionary Art in the Philippines, 1970-1990. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Ito, Lisa C. 2005a. “Dissident Puppets: The Effigy in Philippine Radical Politics.” MA thesis, College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines Diliman.

———. 2013a. “Protest Puppetry: An Update on the Aesthetics and Production of Effigy-Making, 2005-2012.” In New World Academy Reader #1: Towards a People’s Culture, edited by Jonas Staal, 126-49. Netherlands: Basis Vooractuelekunst.

text:
100"> Embroidery is the art of decorative stitching, especially by hand. The high quality of embroidery in the Philippines is partly due to its history and partly due to native talent. Although it is always difficult to pinpoint the origins of an ancient art form, the Philippines’ early exposure to Chinese and Indian artistic traditions may explain the features of its embroidery.

Embroidery has been done by indigenous groups even before the coming of European influence. Among Mindanao ethnic groups, the Blaan, Bagobo, and Mandaya have highly developed embroidery traditions independent of Western trends. Clothing, whether for male or female, can be densely embroidered with colorful geometric patterns. Blouses can be lavishly decorated with minute satin or cross-stitches consisting of lozenges, chevrons, zigzags, meanders, and tumpal (steep-triangle motif found in Mindanao and Indonesian weaves). In northern Luzon, the decorative stitches of the Tinguian, primarily used to join seams of blankets or borders of clothing, are equally distinctive.

Beadwork is prominent in Bagobo clothing, known to the natives as pang-o-lo-bayan. Tutuk or decorative borders or panels on shirts or trousers are covered with fine appliqués over which are fine embroidery stitches, beads, and sequins. Among northern Luzon ethnic groups, the Gaddang are distinguished for beadwork decorations. These may be sewn to a loincloth, blouse, headcloth, pouch bag, or sash. Much of the decoration is simultaneously functional as it conceals shirt seams or weighs down the ends of a loincloth with its fringes.

Various ethnic groups use bells, pom-poms, coins, and animal hair to fringe their clothing or accessories. Occasionally, there are stones, seeds, or pieces of wood, which may function as amulets or charms.

Appliqué and patchwork is a challenging art form among the southern ethnic groups, such as the Tboli and Bagobo but especially among the Talaandig of Bukidnon. On patchwork panels made into shirts or cloth accessories are tiny lozenges, chevrons, or squares. A cotton blouse worked in appliqué is described by the Tboli as kegal kenibang. The latter word, “an adjective used to describe plants or animals that are mottled or speckled,” suggests the tedious process to achieve the desired effect. Among Sulu people, simpler forms of appliqué are done for decorative flags, buntings or tabil, a decorative cloth band of colorful patchwork used as a curtain for gatherings, especially weddings. It can also form part of the canopy hanging over a sleeping area. The bottom is fringed with colored strips of cloth and further embellished with dangling cloth flowers or beads. Among Tausug women, the gala dress would include the long-sleeved, tight-fitting biyatawi (blouse) of silk, cotton, or velvet; the loose and wide pants in cotton or silk; and the embroidered textile or habul tiyahian, slung diagonally across the body from the left shoulder. Designs of the embroidered habul include the lukis manukmanuk (bird motif), lukis kabakaba (butterfly motif), lukis bintang (star motif), and lukis ulang ulang (prawn motif).

Relative to beads are sequins, which among the Blaan and Bagobo are made of shells. These can be used so profusely on a shirt that only tiny portions of the fabric are visible. Real sequins, however, are used by other groups, such as the Maranao who use it to decorate their silk wedding canopies. Otherwise, the ancient oriental technique of chain-stitch embroidery is used.

After the advent of Spain, Western-type embroidery was introduced and later adapted by Filipinos. By the 18th century, embroidery was one of the handicrafts perfected by Filipinos. Ironically, however, Manila was then known in Europe for the mantones de Manila (Manila shawls), which were done in China and loaded onto the galleons to be sold in Mexico during the Manila-Acapulco trade from 1565 to 1815.

Although precolonial Filipinos must have been using the needle for their clothes since its introduction from China in the 13th century, formal training in sewing and embroidery must have started as the Spanish missionaries established schools for girls in the country. Such a school was Santa Catalina, founded in 1696, which was also a beaterio, a type of convent. In the 19th century the nuns of Santa Catalina taught embroidery to their students. Similarly, municipal schools for girls then were required to dedicate two hours to needlework per school day.

Throughout the Spanish colonial period, convents churned out embroidery for priests’ vestments, altar cloths, and costumes for the images of saints. Wealthy parishes could afford metal thread from Europe, which consisted of flat and narrow strips called plate, or of wire coiled around a rod called purl. These threads were used only on equally luxurious fabrics, such as satin or gold cloth. Sections to be embroidered in relief were padded with layers of cardboard or yarn. Skill and patience were required to work satin or banig (local woven sleeping mat) stitches across the cloth without passing the expensive threads underneath the fabric. The techniques of metal-thread embroidery are still practiced today by lay people, although the industry is much smaller, and genuine metal thread has become unaffordable.

In the 19th century, Manila was known for embroidery, even in Europe. Santa Ana, Ermita, and Malate were its main centers of activity. The embroidered male baro (shirt), camisa or blouse, pañuelo or shoulder scarf, children’s clothes, and handkerchiefs are painstakingly documented in 19th-century portraits of the native elite by painters like Antonio Malantic, Justiniano Asuncion, and Isidro Arceo. Whitish nipis—light, transparent fabrics, such as piña (pineapple fiber), jusi (pineapple fiber mixed with banana fiber), or fine sinamay—were embroidered with designs in white thread, thus creating a local form of whitework then popular in Europe.

Manila embroidery was distinguished for combining satin-stitched designs with calado (openwork). This usually meant applying pulled threadwork, wherein threads of the cloth are pulled together with stitches to create openwork patterns, or drawn threadwork, wherein selected threads of the cloth are cut off to create openwork areas while remaining threads are decorated with various stitches. The first step in calado embroidery is the bakbakan, which involves drawing out a specific number of threads of the warp and woof according to a pattern. The material is then worked on by an expert who joins the threads together in typical calado stitching. The next step is embroidering in the munggo, a small motif within the calado itself, such as the sampaguita.

When the calado is uninterrupted throughout the entire length of the panel, it is called ilog na calado (river of calado). Embroidery designs have their specific names: flores for satin-stitched flowers; anino (shadow) in which threads cross at the reverse of the motif for a delicate, transparent effect; britanika for heart-shaped motifs; bulon for raised knots made of threads twisted together; and tirik and bitik for variations of the herringbone stitch, creating a geometric design. All these embroidery stitches, called by the general term labor, are combined with calado.

The embroidery process itself involves at least seven steps executed by different workers. First is the drawing of the design, which is subsequently transferred on wax paper. This is perforated and printed on the cloth with a mixture of kerosene, alcohol, and blue dye. The material, set in the bastidor (hoop), is then worked on for calado, after which the embroidery designs are executed on the solid areas. The material is then stitched all around with the auherol, a scallop design for edging. It is then soaked and washed, then finally stretched on the banatan, a rectangular bastidor that evens out the material. The techniques are still used for the barong tagalog, placemats, table napkins, handkerchiefs, and other products.

Another technique requiring much skill and patience in 19th-century needlework was sombrado (Spanish, shading). Delicate, curvilinear floral or foliate patterns were cut out from white cotton cloth and applied on the reverse side of the nipis fabric to create a silhouette effect. Extremely fine, invisible stitching secured the appliqué to the fabric frequently cut out for a camisa, baptismal gown, curtain, pillowcase, bed hanging, or carroza (processional carriage) skirt. Sombrado also referred to shadow stitches that crossed underneath a transparent fabric to create a semiopaque quality.

Chain-stitch embroidery is also done by machine. It has developed into a small industry in Bulacan, particularly in Bocaue. Locally known as cadineta, it was popular as a form of decorating the butterfly sleeves of the terno in the early 20th century. Along with the first Filipino fashion designers, chain-stitch embroidery for women’s formal wear was combined with sequins, bugle beads, seed pearls, and other materials.

In Luzon, Taal in Batangas province is still known for the large floral patterns worked with slightly embossed satin stitches, and Lumban in Laguna province for delicate barong embroidery using silk thread. Frequently used motifs are kinape (coffee bean-like), sinampagita (jasmine-like), and sili-sili (resembling tiny peppers). The apak-manok (chicken’s footprint) stitch is widely used to decorate as well as bind drawn thread in calado panels.

In Iloilo province, the Asilo de Molo is an orphanage as well as an embroidery center. Here the nuns of the Daughters of Charity train orphans to do various types of embroidery. The “counted thread” embroidery, wherein straight stitches are carefully measured by the number of threads in the fabric it should cross with each stroke, is used in corners of tiny white handkerchiefs. Vignettes outlined in black embroidery thread recall the sensitive lines of pen-and-ink drawings.

As an export industry, Philippine embroidery rated well in the 19th-century piña and other nipis articles sent to Europe, and in the early 20th-century exports of lingerie, handkerchiefs, tablecloths, and children’s clothing undertaken by Philippine-American partnerships. Written bySandra Castro, with notes from Alice G. Guillermo

Sources

text:
Food art refers to the artistry in the presentation and/or packaging of food. This is not garnishing in the Western sense—that is, the addition of decorative touches, such as parsley sprigs, tomato or egg slices, to a dish or platter. This is artistic enhancement of the food itself or of the packaging in which it is served or sold. It is premised on the idea that the utilitarian need not be plain, that what appeals to the palate may also give pleasure to the eye, that the ephemeral, like the wrapping to be discarded, has its moment worth enhancing.

This art is not usually expressed on main (poultry, meat, fish, seafood) or vegetable dishes, in which the sensory appeal lies in freshness, or abundance, or the anticipation of flavor. A roast pig on a spit, for example, skin gleaming golden brown, evokes the appetite even without an apple in its mouth; so does a basketful of red steamed crabs, or a fish from the grill, crusty with coal-burnt skin, or a platter high with noodles sprinkled with crisp bits of crackling, smoked fish, and kamias sections, on a rich palabok (shrimp gravy) sauce. The visual appeal here lies in natural colors and shapes, and the flavors they promise.

Relishes and desserts are the most usual medium for food art. They are prepared much ahead of time, and thus allow time for design and decoration. For example, achara, pickle relish made of grated unripe papaya and vegetable, red and green bell pepper, purple shallots, carrots, cucumber, and singkamas or turnip—all preserved in and flavored with coconut vinegar, salt, and spices—is a prime medium for this art.

The textures lend themselves to carving into flowers, stars, leaves, words, and even figures of men and women, huts, and carabaos. The colors offer a varied palette, and so these are vertically arranged along the sides of glass jars not only in patterns of colors and shapes, but even into story vignettes: a farmer with a guitar walking under a tree, a woman traversing a field with a market basket on her head, a dancing figure, an arrangement of branches and flowers, or words like alaala or recuerdo (remembrance), or the name of the recipient of the gift bottle. Monocolor pickles, such as singkamas, ubod, or dampalit, are also carved and arranged, or given color accents, like carrots, but it is the papaya vegetable palette that is most often given visual, even narrative, embellishment.

Fruits preserved in syrup, especially in the town of San Miguel de Mayumo, Bulacan,are another area of food art. Mayumo, the Pampango word for “sweet,” proclaims the town’s specialty: sweets of many kinds. Suha or pomelo, dayap or lime, kundol or wax gourd, santol, rimas or breadfruit, balimbing or star fruit, pineapple, nangka or jackfruit, native oranges, and guyabano or soursop are preserved in a light syrup in glass jars, comprising the original, the indigenous himagas (dessert). But never are they put in plain. They are bordado or carved with flowers, leaves, rosettes, whorls, patterns. They are bottled with these designs facing outward, such that a shelf of these jars—the fruits translucent in the pale syrup, the light shining through their fancies—becomes visual pleasure promising gustatory joy. The pomelo rinds, washed in several changes of salt solution and dried, are in large bottle-high sections and can carry designs, letters, and names. The dayap rinds are tiny and rounded, therefore “embroidered” in lines and whorls. In Laguna the dayap are not usually carved but are stuffed with nata de coco (coconut jelly) before being cooked in syrup, and there is artistry in the milky white peeking through the lime green.

The pastillas de leche or sweets of carabao milk and sugar from San Miguel de Mayumo are also famous, not only for their sweet fineness but also for their wrappers. These wrappers are called pabalat (wrappings). These are of multicolored thin paper, called papel de japon (japanese paper), cut into stars, leaves, flowers (e.g., rose, cadena de amor, sampaguita), palm leaves and branches, and letters (spelling out “Pilipinas” or “Philippines,” “Maligayang Pasko” or Merry Christmas, “Maligayang Kaarawan” or Happy Birthday, or specific names of persons).

Pabalat artist Luz Mendoza Ocampo uses patterns she personally designed, such as the so-called Maria Clara motif, tinikling (dance on bamboo poles), pounding rice grains, nipa hut, birds, and various flowers. The lines of the pattern are traced into layers of papel de japon using a pencil. She then painstakingly cuts into the fragile paper following the details of the pattern by using a sharpened cuticle scissor. While some pabalat artists like Ocampo would use a pattern, others prefer the freestyle method, by cutting the folded paper with small scissors, freehand, without the use of patterns or drawings.

The pastillas, barely more than an inch long, are wrapped in the plain part of the paper, and the patterned tails float down from the epergnes in which they are displayed on fiesta tables. This fragile art is truly evanescent, since eating one such pastillas means throwing away the art that comes from the labor of many moments. The pabalat tradition in Bulacan is usually practiced by women. Well-known pabalat artists are Amparo Pengson, Rosa David, Nene Pineda, Luz Reyes, and Teresita Ramos.

The arrangements and packaging of kakanin—snacks and sweets, usually made of sticky rice—is still another area for artistry. Kakanin served in bilao (flat baskets) is often a combination of sapin-sapin, ube, biko, suman, etc, and so the colors—purple, white, pink, green, light brown—are arranged in patterns. Puto and kutsinta (cakes made of rice flour) are steamed in bamboo tubes or molds, large or small; colored white, beige, brown, or purple; sliced in trapezoids, rectangles, or wedges; and arranged in steamers, platters, or baskets.

Suman, ibus, tupig, and tamales (rice and sticky-rice cakes) are wrapped in coconut fronds, banana leaves, nipa leaves, etc, and give play to another kind of creativity. Pale young coconut fronds are wound around suman sa ibus in most places; in Obando, Bulacan, darker green ones are woven into little triangular baskets. Breakfast puto-maya is spooned into banana-leaf twists in the Bantayan market, into packets elsewhere. Tamales are steamed in banana leaves, the wrapping style varying with the area—flat or fat; tied or untied; trapezoidal in Meycauayan, Bulacan. The tupig of the Ilocos are rice cakes served on holidays, or in cockpits, where they are both aesthetic and convenient for eating during such exciting occasions.

The puso in Cebu and Cagayan de Oro are fist-sized, woven coconut leaf packages that hold steamed rice or “hanging rice”—for lunch in the market, and for traveling. Pusú (also pusó or posó) come in various shapes and designs and are also referred to with other names in other places of the country. While it is called balisungsong in Tagalog, it is also known as lambay (Waray), patupat (Kapampangan), and tamu (Tausug, Samal, Yakan) (Nocheseda 2009, 320-21).

The making of pusú is believed to date back to precolonial times. Nocheseda noted that early Spanish missionaries in Cebu, Panay, Samar, and Leyte had already commented on the rice pouches’ intriguing designs, their ability to retard the spoiling of the cooked rice, and the way this packaging was convenient for travel. Alcina, as cited by Nocheseda, also mentions the use of pusú in the paganitu (rituals), performed by priest/priestesses for the spirits. Old dictionaries and accounts written during the Spanish colonial period also reveal that there existed various pusú designs, many of which are no longer known by pusú weavers today (Nocheseda 2009, 57-8).

In Cebu, the rice pouches are woven using young coconut fronds called lukay. The pusú weaver or mamumuso fills the pouches halfway through with uncooked rice right before these are sealed. The pouches are then boiled in water until the rice is cooked (Nocheseda 2009, 60).

There are six recognizable variations of the rice pouch designs in Cebu City today, used as offertory victuals in thanksgiving rituals called hikayan, and exorcism rituals called yamyam, both performed by male shamans called tambalan (Inocian 2002, 2). These are the binosa, which resembles a wine glass; the kinasing, which is shaped like a diamond; the dumpos or pudol, a variation of the kinasing with a flattened bottom; the badbaranay, which means “unraveling” or “opening”; the binaki, which means “frog-like”; and manan-aw, which refers to a specific kind of tiny white orchid (Inocian 2002, 2). Nocheseda cites a seventh design mentioned by Inocian called minanok, shaped like a rooster, which is rarely made today (2009, 60). Other shapes that are not associated with offertory rituals are the suso or sinuso (breast-like), pinawikan (seaturtle-like), tinigib (chisel-like), binungi (like an extracted tooth), kinabayo (horselike), and binao (turtle-like).

The early morning markets where these snacks are served as breakfast with chocolate, salabat or ginger ale, or tea are the stalls that sprout outside churches during the simbang gabi or dawn Masses before Christmas, the daytime markets where the snacks become merienda or pantawid-gutom (“bridging” hungers between meals), and the baskets of itinerant vendors. These are the canvases for this art.

During feast day of San Nicolas, cookies designed in his iconography are sold outside the churches in Pampanga, and are called San Nicolas cookies. In Bago City, Negros Occidental, the alfajor cookies are made by migrant families from Panay who settled in Negros in the 1920s. With the main ingredients of rice flour and sugar, alfajor cookies are pressed into wooden molds bearing various designs, such as the insignias of the USAFFE and Boy Scouts; comic characters from Kenkoy; a mermaid motif; and hearts and flower designs associated with weddings, Valentine’s, and Christmas day. The cookies are then cooked under the heat of the sun or sun-dried.

Food art may also be found in such foods as empanadas (chicken pies), which are deliberately fluted and pleated in milles feuilles style in Silay, Negros Occidental, or panaras whose edges are pinched and patterned in Vigan, Ilocos Sur; in the building of tortas reales and castillos, sweets from the Spanish tradition; and more recently, in the decoration of cakes learned from the American tradition. In Antipolo, Rizal, one bakery is famous for its breads shaped like lobsters, pigs, turtles, crabs, and most beautiful of all, crocodiles.

It is in the presentation and packaging of native fruits and delicacies, however, that the native aesthetic is best seen. Here food art is expressed in native materials, like fruits, vegetables, and grains; in patterns drawn from the surrounding landscape; and in indigenous ways through colors, patterns, arrangements, and packaging—making the edible artistic, the gustatory visual, and the ordinary special. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz and Patricia Y. Lopez

Sources

CCP (Cultural Center of the Philippines). 2008. Hiyas: Mga Sinaunang Sining ng Bulacan. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Fernandez, Doreen, and Edilberto Alegre. 1988. Sarap: Essays on Philippine Food. Manila: Mr. and Ms. Publishing Company,1988.

———. 1989. Lasa: A Guide to 100 Restaurants. Quezon City: Urban Food Foundation.

Nocheseda, Elmer I. 2009. Palaspas: An Appreciation of Palm Leaf Art in the Philippines. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.
