text:
Furniture—also known as muebles in Spanish and kasangkapan in Tagalog from the word “sangkap” or ingredients, or kagamitan from the word “gamit” (use)—are functional and decorative objects found in a dwelling or any building, public or private. Furniture serves three practical functions: as storage and display, as support for the human body, and as surface on which to lay things. Furniture also serves as decorative piece in interiors as this comes associated with prestige and ceremonial functions that vary from culture to culture and from one historical period to another.

Furniture may be made of any material, such as stone, metal, wood, vines, fiber, glass, and leather. Furniture often relates to interior space. Certain forms of folk architecture, because they have floors of split bamboo, cannot support too many heavy objects, whereas the bahay na bato (stone house) generally has a big number of furniture pieces, most of which are made of hardwood.

The Living Indigenous Tradition

Indigenous houses are simply and functionally furnished. Daily activities are performed outdoors as residences, which have limited space, are reserved mainly for sleeping and storage.

Baskets and chests are generally for storage. Grain and food are kept in variously shaped baskets, such as the Pangasinan bakul, the Ilocano labba or laza, and the Laguna buligan. The Tagalog tampipi or the Visayan bakag is a rectangular lidded basket that stores clothes and heirlooms. A more secure container is the baul (chest), made of wood and fastened by a lock and hinges. Wooden baul inlaid with mother-of-pearl has long been used by the Maranao and other Islamic groups, although it was probably introduced to lowland groups by the Spaniards.

Like more affluent bahay na bato, the bahay kubo (nipa hut) may also have an aparador (clothes cabinet), a banggera (built-in rack) for drying utensils attached to the kitchen window, and a paminggalan or a cabinet with two slatted doors for food and utensils.

A basic appointment in the bahay kubo is the silya (chair) or the banco/bangko (bench). The banco may be attached to the wall, like that which is built into a structure of the Kankanay bauko house. The typical Kankanay house also displays different baskets for storing tools, jars, and lusong and lay-o (mortar and pestle), as well as those baskets especially designed for storing particular foodstuff, like the anggawin or round basket for edible snails.

Colorful mats and cushions, a pile of chests, and the boras (hanging bamboo screen) decorate the Tausug house. In the absence of a table, food is served on footed brass trays covered with a dome-shaped, multicolored cover of pandan leaves.

The banig (mat), although multifunctional, is most often used for sleeping. Laid on the floor at night, it is rolled and kept during daytime. The papag or papagan, a bed of bamboo or wooden slats, is found in lieu of a banig in some lowland villages. The papag has no mattress; over it is placed a mat or sheets and blankets and pillows. The sleeping area within the one-room ethnic house, such as those of the Tboli, is defined not by solid walls but by curtains or screens. The native term for table, mesa or lamesa, indicates a Hispanic origin. However, Pedro Chirino in 1600 noted that the natives used a dulang, a table that is “small, low, and round or square in shape,” which could be removed after meals. The dulang might still be found in the bahay kubo, although many have been replaced by the waist-high, Western-type table.

The Hispanic Tradition and Local Transformations

Spanish missionaries and colonizers, who first erected more permanent houses in the islands, introduced a variety of furniture. Local furniture likewise incorporated foreign artistic influences through trade; the Chinese design of ball-and-claw on the feet of tables, chests, and benches appears in many 17th-century pieces. Some pieces were adorned with mother-of-pearl, such as one presented to the viceroy of Peru. Rococo-inspired rocaille motifs, modified and flattened, mark later 18th-century examples, like the mesa altar (altar table). In the 19th century, as trade with England and the United States increased, furniture design began to manifest the French Louis XV and the English Victorian influence; gothic and art nouveau came later in the century.

The first pieces of furniture used by the Spaniards were imported from Mexico, but by 1573 Spanish trade with China delivered houseware and furniture as goods for the galleon. A Chinese-made piece from this period is the facistol (music stand) at the San Agustin museum, a three-sided ebony piece resting on a triangular base supported by crouching sphinxes. This originated from Macao and is dated to the end of the 16th century.

Mexican merchants began to settle in Manila as the galleon trade prospered. It has been hypothesized that meeting the needs of this class required the crafting of furniture by skilled Filipino and Chinese artisans under Spanish supervision. By the early 17th century, Chinese artisans were based in centers of the craft in the coastal settlements of Cebu, Batangas, Manila, and llocos.

Muebles enconchados (inlaid furniture) evolved during this period, patterned after the Mudejar-style furniture of Mexico but with Chinese features. These pieces, mostly oversized cabinets, were made of ebony and elaborately inlaid with silver and mother-of-pearl and embellished with bronze bases, mounts, and capitals. Their feet were formed as stylized lions. Furniture craft achieved a level of excellence during the 17th and 18th centuries. Central Luzon specialized in bone inlaying, while the Visayas produced deftly carved narra pieces. The native inhabitants learned from the Chinese. By the 19th century, furniture makers were producing works in Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija; Baliuag, Bulacan; Paete, Laguna; and other inland towns near rivers and forests. Other centers were Bacolor, Pampanga, and Malabon, Rizal (now in Metro Manila), where the colonial government founded trade schools. However, as late as 1886 the Chinese monopolized the finishing of pieces. More furniture shops opened with the rise of the middle class. In 1891 Manila had six shops, and 30 years hence Manila had 10 importers and manufacturers of furniture—27 retailers in Binondo and some in Santa Cruz, Quiapo, and Tanduay (Jamir 1975; Sta. Maria 1983). These furniture were often made of hardwood, like molave, kamagong, tindalo, narra, ipil, and palo maria.

Notwithstanding the spread of European styles, two distinct regional styles emerged in Luzon, called the Batangas style and the Baliuag style.

The Batangas style of Taal and Lipa appeared in the 17th century. The makers of this type of pieces, predominantly Chinese in influence, favored purple and golden-brown tindalo or rosewood, the joints of which were bound by bamboo dowels and thin wedges instead of glue and nails. Early Batangas furniture were simple, graceful, and dignified. They were characterized by flat or shallow carvings that were enhanced rather than obtruded.

Baliuag furniture came from a town in Bulacan with the same name. Baliuag furniture, most often made of narra, is identified by the use of bone inlay and caning for bed frames and seats and backs of chairs. These pieces look sturdy but are actually fragile. Bamboo dowels hold mortise-and-tenon joints for durability.

The Philippines was also receptive to fashionable European styles in the 19th century. Thus styles like the Louis XV revival, the Louis XVI revival, the renaissance revival, and the Early Victorian persist. The style locally called Luis Quince barely reflects French Louis XV furniture. The former have “turned upright supports and a motif of bunch flowers with featherlike scroll” (Fernando and Ricio 1978). Original Louis XV pieces are curvilinear; combine red, green, and yellow with black trimming; feature floral, scallop, and pastoral motifs; and use inlays and veneers of metal and marble. However, both styles have identical cabriole legs, the pied de bouche or doe’s foot, a design motif probably based on the Chinese “dragon’s foot which was first seen in Europe by European courts on Chinese imports brought in by Dutch traders” (Sta. Maria 1983). Another period style, Carlos Tercero, is of uncertain origin; the prototype may have been named after Spain’s Carlos III, who reigned from 1759 to 1788. Chairs and sofas have high backs of woven cane “framed by twisted columns with pointed finials and honeysuckle crest. While the front legs are turned, those behind are squarish” (Sta. Maria 1983). Later in the century, Philippine furniture also caught up with the revivalist trend, incorporating gothic ornamentation.

Nineteenth-century houses became storehouses of a family’s accumulated treasures, typical of Isabelina or later Victorian homes. The period was characterized by the bed, the cabinet, the dining table, and the long seat. Eduardo Ah Tay, a Binondo Chinese, was a renowned Misericordia St furniture maker of the time and was known to have produced pieces representative of the period.

Art nouveau (German, jugenstil), in vogue from 1890 to 1910, presented an alternative to staid classicism and overstuffed Victoriana. Many local artisans were inspired by this return to natural forms, particularly to native plants, like sampaguita, ylang-ylang, bamboo, anahao, and even ampalaya. The Tampincos, a family of sculptors with an atelier in Quiapo, Manila, were commissioned to do architectural details and furnishings, like valances and frames. Isabelo Tampinco localized art nouveau in wood carving, employing areca and anahaw leaves among other native elements. The painter-critic Emilio Alvero is credited for initiating the completely decorated look, binding architectural details with furniture design.

The church and its adjoining convento (convent) were prominent structures in the Spanish colonial era. Emulating Spanish lifestyles thus entailed copying the furniture in churches, convents, and also Spanish houses.

Some innovations were done on the pre-Spanish baul. These may have been influenced by the carved patterns of the tooled Cordovan leather that covered chests brought by the galleons. More common today is the household chest, which in northern Luzon is called the “Vigan chest.” “Simple and utilitarian, they are dovetailed and designed to sit squarely on the floor. The baul’s sole concession to decoration is the tonguelike drop called chapa, in one, two, or three parts; it is sometimes incised with foliate patterns reminiscent of Chinese or Indian brasswork. Two of four metal disks in parallel rows run up and down the front … Home-forged iron bales serve as handles; in addition versions sport twin drawers with rustic wooden pulls.” While the Batangas baul sits “on a separate hollow base with cutouts of Chinese clouds,” the Baliuag chest is European in tone (Sta. Maria 1983).

The aparador was a large cabinet with one, two, sometimes three doors. Church sacristies stored various utensils and silver ornaments in huge aparadores. In the 1880s, aparador meant either an aparador ropero (cloth cabinet), later shortened to aparador, or an aparador platero (showcase). Early aparadores were at least 3.048 m tall and could be from 1.82 m to 3.048 m wide. As these did not provide for hangers, clothes were folded inside drawers. When fortunes grew in the 19th century, aparadores began to have a large mirror on their doors and elaborate carvings on the crown. Pieces from Hong Kong were outfitted with mirrors, while later, cheaper American types were imported in large number in the early 20th century. The dirty-clothes hamper, simply called ropero, had a wooden framework with woven rattan sidings. It had a door on one side to ease emptying of contents. A family’s porcelain and silver tableware were displayed in a platero or platera, a cabinet with open shelves made of hardwood and glass. Across the dining hall stood the vajillera in which porcelain and glassware were kept. Some homes had a third cabinet, the cristaleria, for glassware.

Books and curios were placed in a cabinet with layers of open shelves, called the estante. An aparador de libros (bookcase) also kept books. Many convents had a special aparador de libros, which held parish records. Some are marked with “Archivo de” followed by the town’s name. To secure them during earthquakes, they were fastened down with ringholds embedded in the wall. The vitrina was a smaller and lighter variation of the estante. As its name suggests, it was an open shelf enclosed in glass. While books were earlier kept in massive built-in shelves, by the 17th century the detached bookcase was built as books became smaller. The comoda was an upright chest, with two or more drawers, for table linens and small articles. In church sacristies, long and bulky cajonerias stored altar clothes and priest’s vestments. The tops of these, wide and polished, were used by the priest as he laid out his chasuble and other accessories in preparation for mass.

An altar for household santos (religious sculptures) was found in almost every home. The mesa altar, the popularly but inaccurately used term for this piece, is a cross between a table and a comoda. It usually has two to three drawers standing on four legs reinforced by a stretcher. Some have long, slender drawers for storing candles. Early Batangas pieces, like the tables found in Chinese temples, had cabriole legs and wide flanges with the cutout wave profile of the Ming altar table. Early types had one drawer with thin brass pulls, but the more common later pieces had three drawers.

In the bedroom was the painadora, a dresser or chest with drawers and a mounted mirror. The more elaborate tremor had three full-length mirrors, two of which could be adjusted to allow a view of the user from three angles. The almario (from Spanish “almario,” or arms), originally a cabinet for weapons in Spain, in the Philippines refers to a tall, slim, four-posted bedroom piece that stored pillows, mosquito nets, rolled-up mats, and other beddings. Inspired by the Chinese open cupboard, the Batangas style almario consisted of “four square vertical pieces topped by flat rails with ends projecting outward, and a cupboard at the bottom. The front and side of the cupboard were made up of scrolled vertical slats and a solid back. The cupboard front had a sliding door of solid wood or scrolled back. There were no shelves in the upper part of the structure. The pillows were simply piled on top of the other” (Jamir 1978).

At the entrances to living rooms were hat and cane racks, often with mirrors. Called bastoneros, many such stands came from England. Among the local variations were plain, three-legged pieces and fancy art nouveau types with glass-knob hangers and mirrors. Later, deer-antler pieces and accordion-type hat racks, both hung on walls, came into use. All these hat racks served to display a gentleman’s array of hats, canes, and umbrellas.

Furniture for supporting the human body includes chairs and benches, sofas, and beds. Although chairs were part of the Chinese household, chairs in a wide variety arrived with the Spaniards and not with the Chinese (as earlier thought) with whom the Filipinos traded for centuries. Seventeenth- and 18th-century chairs were boxlike and patterned after the wainscot chair, with a wooden back panel.

Chairs were also an integral part of the church, being both practical and symbolic. The silla episcopal (bishop’s chair) was heavy and intricately carved. These used solihiya (woven rattan) or could have been richly upholstered in velvet. Several were placed by the main altar for the priests and his assistants.

The tropical butaca or sillon (planter’s chair) had a reclining back and long wide arms. The frailero, also silla frailura or silyang prayle (friar’s seat), is so named because it was supposed to be wide enough to accommodate a portly friar. The term comes from Spain itself, indicating how the cliché of fattened clerics was popular even there. The silla perezosa (lazy chair) had overextended flat arms on which one’s legs could rest during a nap. Perezosas had rockers, such as those enjoyed by British traders of the early 1800s. The seats and backs of these chairs were made of solihiya to allow free circulation of air.

Although mercedoras or tumba-tumba (rocking chairs) appeared before 1898 (bentwood pieces were imported from Austria in the late 19th century), it was the Americans who popularized them. Most vintage rocking chairs date to the 1930s and were manufactured in Binondo.

Guests or tenants sat on bancos or kapiyas (benches) on the ground floor of a house while waiting to be summoned upstairs. The kapiya (probably from Spanish “capilla,” or chapel) has its origin in the church pew. Pews were not commonly used in church; the congregation knelt or stood, according to the liturgy. Only prominent parishioners sat on the long benches along the middle of the nave, which could be plain or carved. The Santo Niño Basilica in Cebu has carved pews emblazoned with the Hapsburg eagle, while the Baclayon Church in Bohol had a pew decorated with genre scenes.

The gallinera was so named because the slatted bottom half was designed to cage roosters, while their owners transacted business with the residents of the house. The 19th-century directoire type of chair came with or without arms, and had turned and reeded front legs terminating in boots and square back legs; two horizontal stretchers formed the backrest. Many late 19th-century salas had a sofa, popularly known as the mariposa, which was derived from the Victorian horsehair sofa and named after its butterfly-shaped back. Like chairs, beds introduced innovation in the Filipino lifestyle. Beds were often of the four-poster variety, which was convenient for hanging mosquito nets. Their sleeping surfaces were made of solihiya to provide coolness and comfort.

The nuptial bed was customarily the first furniture piece owned by newly wedded couples. Some Ilocos beds dating to the 1800s were crowned with leaves and flowers, their supporting posts braided or reeded. Characteristic of the Ilocos beds is the symmetry between the head and foot board. Central Luzon beds had magnificent headboards carved from slats of narra or kamagong and inlaid with mother-of-pearl. Many turn-of-the-century beds carried a couples’ monogram, which was also carried onto a child’s first bed.

The more popular four-posters in the late 19th century were done by Ah Tay, who blended European design and tropical flora. The headboard might use an ogee arch, while stylized pineapples served as tester corners and halved squashes served as bed supports, prompting the name kalabasa (squash) bed.

Brass beds were modish but not too popular because they had to be constantly polished. Beds were usually plain with knobs or finials on top of the bed posts. Iron bed steads were also common. They were sturdy and could be easily stored. The bed posts, 1.82-2.13 m long, were usually topped with brass finials.

The traditional dulang around which Filipinos squatted during meals gradually gave way, especially among the upper class, to the higher mesa with matching chairs adopted from the Spaniards. Large families required long wooden tables that could seat up to 36 people. Not all tabletops were made of a single slab of narra, tindalo, or molave. To enlarge the tabletop, a slab was framed by thick boards 15.24-30.48 m wide; hence the name binandeja (tray-like) in Laguna, Batangas, and Tayabas in Quezon. Some tables were inlaid at the center or edges; legs and stretchers could be carved or turned. To accommodate many guests during a fiesta or other large gatherings, some dining tables had drop leaves that could be raised to increase the table’s surface area. Additional space was also provided by identical tables that could be put up end to end; or rectangular, polygonal, or half-moon side tables that could be joined to the end of the dining table.

Vestibules, living rooms, and bedrooms had consolas (side tables) and mesitas (center tables). From the 1860s, marble-topped tables were made by the same shops that specialized in tombstones and other sculpture. Molding and grooves along the perimeter gave shadows to the wide expanse of white. Although local marble quarries were known, the Rodoreda family, marble workers for government buildings, used imported marble from Japan, Europe, and America.

Writing paraphernalia were stored inside escritorios (desks) and office tables, the tops of which could be folded or rolled up. Most desks were locally made although a number were imported from Hong Kong, Europe, and the United States. Lighter in appearance was the “friar’s desk.” This had a drawer on each end of the table, a hinged slanting lid that could be raised, and cabriole legs. In the bedroom, porcelain wash basins were set on wood or marble lavaderas. The costureros (sewing tables) for hand-operated and treadle machines were also found in bedrooms.

In 1851, Michael Thonet exhibited his cane and steam-bent wooden furniture, popularly called Vienna furniture, at the Crystal Palace exhibition in London. Supplanting heavy Victorian furniture, Thonet furniture had sleek silhouettes where every line had a structural purpose. Dismantable and mass-produced, its wooden parts could be shipped, then assembled upon reaching their markets. Imported bentwood tables, chairs, hat racks, and baby strollers furnished Philippine houses, offices, schools, and even clubs like Club Filipino.

After 1914, bentwood ceased to be manufactured in Europe, and production stopped altogether. Entrepreneurs from San Miguel, Bulacan, met orders from Guam, Hawaii, and the United States. Instead of beech, they used rattan bent in several ways—by steaming, holding over a benzoline or kerosene lamp, or immersing in boiling water for half an hour. Rattan furniture, locally known as batibot, came in both Viennese-bentwood design and Victorian-wicker design. Black nito was also used to accentuate light-colored rattan.

The American Tradition and Local Transformations

Mass production and urban overpopulation have resulted from 20th-century industrialization. The crowding of population centers altered the Filipino concept of domestic space. Furniture became smaller to fit accessorias (row houses). Art deco-inspired assembly-line furniture sets for the bedroom, living room, and dining room were in demand.

Iron bedsteads from the United States and brass beds from Singapore competed with handcrafted wooden beds and eased these out of competition. The Cosmopolitan Company in Escolta, founded by E. M. Bachrack in 1902, imported iron beds that were sold on easy installment plans. Parson’s Hardware imported beds from Singapore. Only in 1910 were iron beds with cane bottoms manufactured in Binondo.

During this era, Philippine batibot chairs met stiff competition from bamboo chairs manufactured in the Wanchai district of Hong Kong. However, by 1938, Filipinos wrested control over the local rattan furniture business. Leading rattan furniture manufacturers were L. Provedora Inc, Gonzalo Puyat and Sons Inc, Matibay Rattan Arts and Decoration Inc, State Rattan, Quiroga Bed Factory, Rattan Adjustable Furniture, Rattan Products Manufacturing Co., Nazareno’s Rattan Craft, and Tuason and Sampedro Inc.

The Filipino blend of the Art Nouveau filtered down to domestic abodes in the 1920s up to the 1930s at the height of the American period of the country. The space allocations and plans of homes accommodated outdoor furniture as porches and verandahs became the mode of predominantly two-level and single-storey chalets (Manahan 1994). Wicker chairs and tables with rounded edges inspired by the Victorian and Edwardian periods were crafted inside prisons, which came to be known as “Bilibid furniture.” As a reformation discipline, utilization of convict labor for the mass manufacture of the furnitures was initiated. The Victorian style Peacock chair became the most in demand item coming in three sizes with varied costings (Lico 2012). By the 1930s, art-deco furniture was in demand to fill in the residential forms erected in the urban landscape.

After World War I, Filipino pensionados, sent to United States to pursue their graduate degrees and specialization, exhibited a fondness for American models in their furniture choices. The straightforward simple lines, austerity in carving and surface embellishment provided a respite from elaborate designs and exaggerated motifs. The affordability of the furniture made it a popular choice for most homeowners. Since mass production was introduced during the 1930s, machine-based aesthetics characterized the off-the-floor purchase of the Filipinos to furnish their interior spaces. The “Ambassador” or the “Quezon” sala set became a popular choice. Streamlined and ergonomically designed, it graced most homes of the period. The low chairs were characterized by boatlike forms resembling deck chairs used in cruise travel that became popular in the period. It was fashioned after chairs designed by Warren MacArthur for the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles in 1932 (Lico 2012).

Philippine Furniture 1946-2014

The 1950s ushered the massive reconstruction of buildings and homes after the destruction and chaos of World War II. The shortage resulted in a frenzy of hastily erected residences, constructed to provide immediate occupancy for the homeless residents affected by the war. Subdivision developments and walk-up apartment structures located in suburban Manila surfaced as an option for the families fleeing the congestion of the city. Furniture pieces made of painted hardwood combined with rope and cane were sold in mass-produced volume, with convenience and utility becoming the salient consideration in its design. Upholstery and more novel materials, like iron, brass, glass, veneers, leather, and marble, were experimented on. Color was infused in the decoration and embellishment of furniture. Oriental and Scandinavian Moderne pieces became unique accent pieces connoting a newfound sense of sophistication. However the uniformity of the architectural style of the homes included economical attributes affecting the choice of furnishings and furniture. The “form follows function” of the Modernist aesthetic was applied as well to the design of furniture (Lico 2012).

From the mid-1950s to the 1960s, corporate architecture promoted the contemporary look expressed in glass, steel, and leather. Furniture of this period derived inspiration from the work of Mies van der Rohe (e.g., his Barcelona chair), Marcel Breuer, Harry Bertoia, and Eero Saarinen. The look was interpreted in the Philippines by Cancio-Calma and by designers who had ventured out on their own from the Aguinaldo store team. Old furniture houses, like Puyat and Baluyot, continued to make custom pieces. Arte Español was known for wrought iron; Rattan Art, for rattan and wicker; Jaime Ortol and Pilar Zaragosa, for Spanish; Florentino’s, for Chinese; Joaquin Imperial, for French; and Nicfur, for less expensive pieces of modern furniture.

The Filipino “Dream House” concept privileged the interior designing of homes documented in local publications, such as the Philippine Arts and Architecture Magazine, Women and the Home, and the society lifestyle pages of major newspapers in the 1950s to the 1960s. One of the biggest influences during the postwar era came from a well-known department store. In 1953, Aguinaldo’s Department Store on Echague St, Manila, opened a Decor Arts department that displayed original furniture from Europe and the United States. The owner Francisco Aguinaldo hoped that local versions of these pieces could be made to reach a wider audience. The Aguinaldo’s model rooms and vignettes, created by upcoming designers and architects—among them Wili Fernandez, Ched Berenguer-Topacio, Lor Calma, Edgar Ramirez, Myrna Cruz, and Bonnie Ramos—became the ideal models of interior spaces. The interior decoration and design services offered by them eventually started the awareness of interior design as a profession. These contemporary modern styles pervaded most the interior spaces of homes and offices. Rectilinear, finely crafted, hard-edged, austere furniture were used in order to accomplish a crisp minimalist look.

In light of the nationalistic spirit prevailing in the late 1950s and early 1960s, affluent collectors like Luis Araneta and Arturo de Santos turned to Filipino objects. Pioneer decorator Rosario Luz brought into vogue the “new ilustrado” look, combining Filipino antiques with contemporary furniture. Folk art objects also began to be used, such as moriones masks, pastillas or milk-candy wrappers, and taka (papier-mâché). The trend toward reviving native artistic traditions was strengthened by the research of Fernando Zobel, Benito Legarda, Dominador Castañeda, Alfredo Roces, Alejandro Roces, and Gilda Cordero-Fernando. This trend continues in pieces such as the antique-style gallinera, kapiya, cama, tocador, butaca, aparador, platera, mesa and silla, and mesa altar.

By then, schools such as the University of Santo Tomas, Philippine Women’s University, the University of the Philippines, and the College of the Holy Spirit began offering four-year degree programs in interior design, two years of which were spent in the liberal arts. Furniture designing further developed as a unique niche of the profession. Practitioners of interior design, which included Ernest Korneld, Arturo de Santos, Phylis Harvey, Ronnie Laing, and Edgar Ramirez, began designing custom-built furniture pieces commissioned by their clients. The Philippine Institute of Interior Designers, organized in a meeting at the Summit Restaurant in Manila in 1964, was formed as an offshoot of the demand for professional interior design work.

The 1970s welcomed geometric “pop culture” supergraphics and contemporary materials, like plastic, fiberglass, laminates, and vinyl. The “Mod look” treated furniture as part of walls, floors, and ceilings resulting in built-in units in the interiors (Oliveros and Florendo 2013). Local adaptations of Hans Wegner, Finn Juhl, and the molded furniture of Charles Eames were appreciated and purchased by homeowners. The “Bagong Luma” design dictum of Rosario Luz’s “new ilustrado” became prevalent as revival reproductions of Philippine antique furniture of the 19th century. Traditional, folk, and precolonial stylistic adaptations predominated in the rendering of new versions of the forms. An eclectic blend of both endemic motifs was fused to the modern lines of the furniture.

By the 1980s onward, furniture experimentation accommodated a conciliation of international and vernacular styles. The renewed interest in indigenous local culture, craftsmanship, and materials evolved into a Filipino modern ethnic design in furniture. The award-winning Petal Folding Chair designed by Mercedes Berenguer “Ched” Topacio, for instance, was made of woven split rattan strips and hand-forged iron. It drew inspiration from a blossoming flower as it could be folded and opened as needed. It won the Roscoa International award in 1986. The fine quality of local materials such as rattan and leather provided unique experimentations in furniture and the decorative arts. The aesthetics of the postmodern era in the 1980s dictated divergent interpretations of furniture as sculpture and as an art form. Following Napoleon Abueva’s early furniture sculptural pieces using Philippine hardwood, Jerusalino Araos carved pieces of polished wood in organic shapes. Working with weathered wood, Rey Paz Contreras experimented with combined forms to craft outdoor furniture for garden settings. A chair called Making Waves by Claude Tayag is a rigid bench of joined pieces of solid wood, unprocessed and polished by hand. It was a statement of the new creative bent.

While there is a strong preference for Filipino-inspired furniture, some advocates followed a trend of abstraction influenced by the global scene. Advancing technology continued to bring new equipments and processes that streamlined furniture manufacturing and even designing. Filipino migration was a formidable factor in creating a new vernacular style in furniture designs.

The development of mega communities with high-density spaces introduced compact, built-in, and multifunctional furniture pieces to accommodate condominium living. Confronting the challenges of the global realities, Filipino designers crafted their unique solutions to the emerging concerns.

Furniture artisans infused a sustainable Filipino psyche to their designs. Locally crafted, sourced using new technologies and materials, they have become globally recognized and appreciated. Budji Layug, Benjie Reyes, Ugo Bigyan, Eric Paras, Leo Almeria, Milo Naval, Vito Selma, and Kenneth Cobonpue are some of the Filipino talents in the furniture design industry who have found unique niches to assert the Filipino’s global competitiveness with the best in the world.Written by ReneB. Javellana, Regalado Trota Jose, Ramon Villegas, and Monica Felicia P. Consing, updated by Raquel Florendo

text:
Installation refers broadly to art practice that incorporates an ensemble of objects and mediums in space. Both objects and space are central components of artworks in this category. The materials contained in space can be individual assemblages or a combination of traditional and nontraditional forms. This mode of art production results in environments that viewers can engage in physically and thus make up art that is not merely visual experience. These artworks can be reinstalled in various sites but are greatly dependent on the particularities of their location, thus they are site-specific art. Artworks that employ modes and methods specific to installation may combine painting, drawing, sculpture, found objects or ready-mades, sound, film, video, and text. They create total environments wherein a viewer engages multiple senses to experience the piece. Site specificity has to do with the integration into and alteration of the attributes of a specific location by way of an artwork. In this way, the site becomes an indispensable element of the artwork or art project.

Some installations can be reconfigured and relocated to numerous exhibition spaces; from museums and galleries to public spaces like parks, or large-scale exhibition venues like biennales and art fairs. There are pieces greatly contingent on their site, wherein specific attributes of location are intrinsic to the work. Often these artworks are installed only once. While some are permanent pieces, most others are ephemeral, assembled and later dismantled and documented through photographs and videos.

In North America and Europe, installation and site-specific art flourished as a response to Modernist claims of the primacy of the art object, the singularity of viewer experience, and the increased commodification of art. Movements such as Minimalism, Land Art, Environmental Art, Conceptual Art, and Performance Art are early influences in the formation of installation and site-specific art. They are founded on several shifts: an emphasis from art object to viewer experience, from art as commodity to art as ephemeral object, and from representation to a work’s contingent message. Installations and site-specific art also reveal not only inherent attributes of transmedia but also the material conditions of viewing. Early installations and site-specific works did not have lucrative sales potential in the art market but over the years, they and their accompanying documentation have become prominent pieces in private and public art collections. Installation and site-specific art have become ever more dynamic in material and form, as well as in modes of engagement. These attributes speak to an increasingly more complex patronage system. Often, contemporary installation and site-specific artworks refer to those commissioned by public and private entities, the state, corporations, or private foundations. Projects initiated by individual artists, artist groups, or collectives have also become more common.

Landmark pieces that now define early developments in the Philippines hewed closely to environmental and land art. They were responses to the increasing deterioration of the natural environment and the alarming depletion of natural resources. Most artists working in the vein of installation incorporated materials indigenous to site or found on location, including urban debris. They incorporated as themes traditional rituals and forms. The impulse toward nature and environment arose alongside conceptions of indigenous identity. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) supported these inclinations through the vision of its curators—notably, Raymundo Albano who was visual arts director from 1971 to 1985. However, earlier installation works by Shop 6, a group formed by Roberto Chabet, already manifested a turn toward objects and their display in space. Alan Rivera’s Room/Riddle, 1975, for instance, had as elements a rocking chair, a rusty electric fan, and a table on which was a note that said “Buy me, I am Art!” Artists’ use of ready-mades as well as their concentrated gesture of claiming that something produced by following directions on a written note could be called art underlined the fraught status of the precious art object both from the view of art institutions and the art market.

Raymundo Albano in a 1981 statement claimed that installation has its roots in the local environment, citing festivals like the Pahiyas in Lucban, locales like the jungles of Los Baños, the jeepney, and religious traditions. Early on, he asserted installation’s “intimacy with folk patterns” and its potential as novel expression of Filipino identity. In comparison to painting, which he regarded as wholly imported, alien, or foreign, Albano asserted that installations were “natural born” to Filipino artists. The installation of artist Luis Enano Yee Jr aka Junyee at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, Wood Things , 1981, combined banana stalks and kapok pods made to look like large insects crawling all over the gallery space. Through texture and play, Junyee was able to recreate the sense of unbridled growth in nature.

An early marker in the development of site-specific art in the Philippines may have been Los Baños Site Works organized by artist Junyee at the foothills of Mount Makiling in Laguna province. The outdoor exhibition ran from 10 to 30 Oct 1981 with numerous participating artists working with materials available on-site. The Los Baños Site Works was supported by the University of the Philippines (UP) Los Baños, the Thirteen Artists Program of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, and the Brotherhood of Plebeians. The public launch coincided with the UP Loyalty Day. The three-hectare site housed works by art students and more established artists, including those from the Philippine High School for the Arts and the UP College of Fine Arts (CFA). Junyee and fellow artists saw the project as departure from art meant to be displayed in gallery settings. It had as premise the incorporation of a site’s features into the installation pieces. On-site materials were used—specifically, those “discarded by nature,” with artists advised not to damage or take from any other natural resource.

Los Baños Site Works sought the cohesion of both art object and its surroundings. Vines, branches and twigs, leaves, rocks, and bamboo were positioned to appear as if sprouting from the ground, floating in air, encompassing an area, or as suspended from tree branches. Artists whose works were included in this pioneering site-specific exhibition were Ted Gagalac, Raymundo Albano, Ginny Dandan, Ileana Lee, Lani Maestro, Genara Banzon, Hermisanto, Alwin Reamillo, Marlon Reyes, Pablo Biglang-awa, Ian Victoriano, Jessie Pastor, and John Cinco; these latter six were students at the UP College of Fine Arts at the time. Professors at the UP CFA would later incorporate installation and site-specific works in their curricula. Art galleries such as Pinaglabanan and Kulay Diwa supported artists to explore installation works.

Installation is now a prominent feature of contemporary Philippine art. Contributing factors include interdisciplinary approaches to art making, a greater interest in the role of viewers to make sense of an artwork, the burgeoning of even larger exhibition spaces, and more important, a compelling need for artists to be somehow involved with communities, in various degrees actively addressing concerns through creative practice. In 1989, artist Roberto Villanueva from Baguio City created Uma ti Biag (Garden of Life) in the CCP grounds. Constructed from bamboo and reed, the piece had a hollowed center with river rocks and rice granary guardian figures. It clearly culled from worship practices of the Mountain Province in the Philippine North.

Exhibition platforms—such as the International Baguio Arts Festival, held six times from 1988 to 2002; the biennial Visayan Visual Arts Exhibition and Conference (Viva ExCon), which started in 1990; and the five Sungdu-an traveling exhibitions started in 1996—have created opportunities for artists to collaborate together in art making. The multifaceted roles of artists have positioned them as curators or community organizers, allowing them to organize venues where installation and its new forms can be made, exhibited, and engaged with. The phenomena also gave rise to artist-run spaces, such as Big Sky Mind, shifting the conditions of art production away from state and commercial institutions, fostering a creative space where contemporary artists could freely explore ideas and explore the possibilities of materials.

Other modes of engagement have since either superseded or been appended to site specificity as a distinguishing aspect of installation work. These new practices and modes include participatory art, social engagement, community projects, and relational art. These more recent tendencies consequently result in ever more varied configurations of form, methods of making, processes of engagement, and modes of display. This includes experimentation with and incorporation of new media, video and film, and exploring the Internet as engagement platform via digital technology. Technology likewise has altered the way space is experienced. Virtual space now intersects with and complements the physical spaces that art occupies.

All these have been integrated into Philippine contemporary art through motley forms and practices. Works by Santiago Bose, Kidlat Tahimik, Jose Tence Ruiz, Agnes Arellano, Alfredo and Isabel Aquilizan, Toym Imao, Mark Justiniani, Kawayan de Guia, Leeroy New, Mark Salvatus, Toym Imao, and Leslie de Chavez all illustrate the use of these varied approaches. Their projects have traveled to numerous venues: conventional spaces like those of museums and galleries, art fair venues, biennales and international exhibitions, parks, beach fronts, and other shared and unexpected spaces in a neighborhood.

Contemporary projects are also outcomes of festivals, which of late have included the Neo-Angono Public Art Festival in Angono, the Bagasbas Beach International Eco-Arts Festival in Camarines Norte, the Malasimbo Music and Arts Festival in Oriental Mindoro, and projects initiated by AXIS Art in Baguio and nearby provinces in the northern region. These new developments translate into greater examinations of identity, belonging, and being in space and time by way of the innovative lenses that art fabricates and facilitates among those encountering it.Written byTessa Maria C. Guazon

text:
Komiks (from the English “comics”) is an illustrated humorous story. This popular visual-arts form consists of a series of frames or a single frame with figures of people or animals. Dialogue is indicated by means of “balloons” containing words and is often accompanied by an explanatory text. Komiks is also called cartoon (from the Italian “carton,” sketches done on cardboard in preparation for a mural). However, in the Philippines the term “komiks” is generally used for entertaining pieces, while “cartoon” includes the editorial cartoon or the single-frame drawing that comments on current events or satirizes the foibles of leaders and institutions.

History of Komiks

In 1885 Jose Rizal, on a visit to Juan Luna, illustrated the tale of the monkey and the tortoise in 34 plates, which he drew in an album belonging to Luna’s wife. Because of these illustrations and his illustrations of five Hans Christian Andersen tales that he translated into Tagalog, Rizal is often considered the first Filipino cartoonist.

Precursor of the komiks, the editorial cartoon began to appear in newspapers and magazines of the late 19th century and were generally of critical character. Ignacio del Villar’s lively lampoons of middle-class lifestyle were published in the 1885-87 issues of Manila Alegre. These featured parades at Luneta, bullfights, fiestas, theater, courtship, marriage, and shopping in Quiapo. Other cartoons published in the same illustrated magazine were J. Arestegui’s caricatures of celebrities and F. Lazaun’s Ayer, Hoy, y Mañana (Three Ages of Woman). El Temblor of 1885, Manililla of 1888, El Caneco of 1890, El Bello Sexo of 1891, El Ejercito of 1892, and La Moda Filipina and El Telegrama of 1893 were other periodicals that carried notable examples of the genre.

Political cartoons appeared in magazines, labeled as “periodicos festivos,” “revistas tradicionalistas,” and “revistas comicas, joco y satirico.”

El Chiflado, 1885-89, published anti-Spanish cartoons. The Escuela Permanente depicted the crumbling Spanish empire in the Philippines and Latin America. Resurrexit (He Has Risen), Surge et Ambula (Arise and Walk) and La Fruta Cadaciada Oregine del Pecado (The Fruit of the Original Sin) were antifriar graphic works.

El Verde of the 1890s satirized economic progress in the country. Colonizacion (Colonization) is an enlarged drawing of a lean Caucasian figure, while other personifications are dwarfed: Actividad, a sluggish man; Industria, a Chinese balancing two pails; Agricultura, a housewife tending a garden patch; Moriencito, a tranvia pulled by turtles; Ciencia, a monkey in toga; and Prensa, a kettledrum.

El Cinefe of 1894 fearlessly published antigovernment cartoons, such as Cuestion Palpitante (Throbbing Question) and En Alza (On the Rise). Te Con Leche of 29 Oct 1898 published a work, signed Cobrian, which showed Uncle Sam entertaining with a monkey and a bag of tricks, labeled American Amusement: Always Protecting. It also published cartoons by V. Tur, such as Vida es Pesadilla (Life’s Nightmare) and La Mision de la Prensa (Mission of the Press), which attacked the censorship of the time.

La Restauracion of 1898 and El Tio Verdades in 1899 published editorial cartoons critical of national and international issues, warning the Philippines of American imperialism. In the early 1900s the politically oriented magazines Telembang and Lipang Kalabaw consistently featured cartoon caricatures of political figures. In Lipang Kalabaw, illustrators used pseudonyms, like Makabuhay, Sirom, Lipay, Makahiya, TikTok, and Tagakadlagan, to escape arrest by the Americans. Fernando Amorsolo and Jorge Pineda illustrated many cartoons for The Independent. The American colonial period saw the rise of newspaper publication due to the increase in literacy rate. Political cartoons graced the major periodicals of the day and the most active cartoonists of this period were Jose Perreira and Esmeraldo “E.Z.” Izon of the Philippines Free Press, established before World War II.

The post-World War II period was also a time when journalism was alive and editorial cartoons accompanied the major publications with E.Z. Izon drawing for the Philippines Free Press, Liborio “Gat” Gatbonton for the Manila Chronicle, Bert Gallardo and Isaac Tolentino for the Philippines Herald, and Demetrio Diego for the Daily Mirror . These cartoonists worked in diverse styles, churning out daily or weekly satires to complement the most important news. These cartoons are recognized as the forerunners of present-day komiks.

The formal history of komiks begins in 1929 when Antonio S. Velasquez and Romualdo Ramos came out with the first issue of Mga Kababalaghan ni Kenkoy (Kenkoy’s Antics). An instant hit, Kenkoy ran in Liwayway and its sister magazines until 1941 when the Japanese clamped down on all media. Liwayway magazine and its vernacular versions—Bannawag in Ilocano, Hiligaynon in Ilonggo, Bisaya in Cebuano, and Bikolnon in Bicol—were the leading outlets for other cartoonists.

After World War II appeared the first comic book, Halakhak, a 10-issue series inspired by English comic books brought over by American GIs. These combined novel writing, painting, and cinematographic elements in one work. On 27 May 1947 Don Ramon Roces and Velasquez organized Ace Publications, which put out Pilipino Komiks, featuring the komiks of Velasquez, Jose Zabala Santos, Damian Velasquez, Larry Alcala, Vicente Manansala, Tony Roullo, E. D. Ramos, Fred Carillo, A. Y. Manalad, and Hugo Yonzon. Because the komiks were so popular, Ace Publications put out other comic books in rapid sucession: Tagalog Klasiks, 1949; Hiwaga Komiks, 1950; Espesyal Komiks and Kenkoy Komiks, 1952. These comic books flourished for more than a decade.

In the 1960s, Alcala, Mauro Malang Santos, Corky Trinidad, and Danilo Dalena were most active in the field. Alcala’s Kalabog en Bosyo and Mang Ambo were very popular. Nonoy Marcelo’s Tisoy appealed to young urban-bred adults. Trinidad, then based in the United States (US), often drew caricatures of world leaders, like Ferdinand Marcos. A number of his cartoons have been collected and published in anthologies. Dalena’s searing caricatures appeared in Philippines Free Press in the late 1960s and Asia-Philippines Leader in the early 1970s. Alcala’s Asyong Aksaya was best known during martial law years. In the 1980s Jose Tence Ruiz created very insightful sketches on social problems published in the Manila Chronicle and Observer magazine. Notable cartoonists of the period include Jess Abrera, Arnel Mirasol, Esmeralda Izon, Ludwig Ilio, Nonoy Marcelo, Dengcoy Miel, Roni Santiago, Norman Isaac, Neil Doloricon, and Rene Aranda who livened up the pages of the periodicals with their witty political satires.

From the 1960s to the 1980s, the Roces clan continued to dominate the komiks industry through their publishing outfits Atlas Publishing and Graphic Arts Services Inc. A number of independent komiks came out during this period but failed to topple the Roces monopoly. An example is United Komiks in 1963, which was published by Pablo Gomez’s PSG Publishing (Valiente 2012). In the 1970s, American comic book publisher DC Comics started recruiting Filipino illustrators, such as Nestor Redondo, Alfredo Alcala, and Alex Niño whose talents were eventually recognized at the Comic-Con International’s Inkpot Award in Denver, Colorado (Valiente 2012). Ernie Chan, Whilce Portacio, Gerry Alanguilan, and Leinil Yu are some of those who lent their talents to foreign outfits. Their success and readiness to mentor and share opportunities with younger artists spurred production in the Philippines even in the midst of the waning of the comics industry in the late 1980s. In the early and mid-1980s, komiks continued to gain popularity with big writers such as Carlo J. Caparas, Elena Patron, Nerissa Cabral, Hal Santiago, and Mar Santana taking the lead (Valiente 2012).

By the late 1980s, komiks started to decline in popularity due to several factors. Komiks as a major form of entertainment lost its viability due to the availability of other forms of media, such as television. Television sets became more affordable at the time, due in part to the availability of cheaper, non-Japanese brands imported into the Philippines. Television also offered more variety in content after the EDSA Revolution when censorship became more lax. Some artists attribute the decline of the komiks industry to the Roces monopoly, which allegedly stifled creativity and diversity, and the failure of publishing outfits to give proper remuneration to illustrators. Due to the meager wages they were receiving, many comic book artists joined the advertising and animation industries, which offered more attractive pay (Valiente 2012).

The decline of komiks, however, did not spell the end of the industry. The 1990s saw the rise of independent comics, such as Flashpoint, Alamat, Zenith Graphics, Exodus, and TaekwonDoggs (Valiente 2012). Culture Crash, a comic book published by a group of Fine Arts students in the University of the Philippines, became a cult favorite in this decade. Many comic book artists of this generation appropriated styles and techniques from Japanese comics (manga), such as multiple framing, a monochromatic or “toned look,” and the cleaner and more tapered facial features of characters (Calingo 2007). Many also dealt with superhero themes similar to American comics. The rise of independent comic books saw a noticeable shift in demographics from the masses as the largest audience of komiks from the 1940s to the 1980s to a niche group of enthusiasts largely from the middle class. Unlike early komiks, which could easily be bought in newsstands and markets, these independent komiks are bought in specialty stores, at comic conventions held annually for comic book fans, or accessed online. It is ironic that while the Internet supposedly democratizes production and distribution of information, computers have remained out of reach for majority of the masses, thereby limiting access to online content, including comic books.

Komiks in the form of single or multiple panel comic strips appearing in comic books and daily newspapers—such as Larry Alcala’s Kalabog and Bosyo, 1947; Ben Alcantara’s Gorio and His Jeepney, 1950s; Nonoy Marcelo’s Tisoy, 1963; and Roni Santiago’s Baltic and Co., 1970s—were also very popular. In the 1980s, Larry Alcala’s Slice of Life, a full-page strip in Weekend Magazine, Tonton Young’s My Little Pupung, and Pol Medina’s Pugad Baboy appealed to a wide readership. In the 2000s, Manix Abrera’s Kiko Machine and Lyndon Gregorios’s Beerkada (Beer Buddies) entertained readers through their witty portrayals of everyday life. Young artists have also been counting on increased online access in the long term as they see this as a way to reach a broader audience. They continue to produce work that are no longer intended as print versions, opting to establish a presence among the geographically spread out publics who encounter their work in the virtual world.

Types of Komiks

The komiks has several formats. The first is the daily strip, usually consisting of three or four frames. The same form has also been used for long narratives parcelled out four frames at a time. The second is the full-page strip, appearing in weekly magazines. Serial novels or short completed stories, called wakasan, have also appeared in full page. The third is also full page, but rather than being divided into frames, is spread over the entire page. This kind was popularized by Alcala in his Slice of Life, and by Zabala Santos in his Lifestyle. Comic strips can also occupy several pages in magazines. This is the most common form of serialized komiks novels from which films are derived.

There are generally three kinds of komiks according to content: humorous, narrative, and instructional. The first category, humorous comics or the “funnies,” are of two groups: human caricatures and animal comics. These were both influenced by American comic strips—the first, by such strips as Dagwood, Blondie, Li’l Abner, and Peanuts, and the second by Mickey Mouse and Felix the Cat.

In the Philippines the first humorous comic strip using human caricatures was Kenkoy, which first appeared in Liwayway on 11 Jan 1929. Kenkoy included a family composed of Mang Teroy, Aling Matsay, Rosing, Kenkoy’s rival Tirso, and other colorful characters, such as Talakitok, Talimusak, and later, in separate strips, Nanong Pandak and Ponyang Halubaybay. Mars Ravelo followed suit with Rita and related characters Gorio and Tekla, Engot and Ipe.

Komiks caricature, which involves the exaggeration of physical features, is a common device to elicit laughter. This can include the manner of dressing, which can be comic or satirical. Komiks humor also stems from the language. The very names and epithets can be funny, such as Ponyang Halubaybay and Kurdapya, names that explode social pretensions. Linguistic humor can also be found in the mélange of vernacular languages, English, and Spanish, thereby reflecting the country’s long colonial experience. The comic strips of Alcala and Marcelo freely coined and popularized words, such as “pahatset-hatset” (eating away) and “jeproks” (way-out, rugged). Humor can also arise from the spelling of English loan words—for example, “bespreng” (best friend)—as well as from the manner of speech of the characters: for example, “Haya, hayik sa kamay ng yoya” (Go on, kiss grandma’s hand). Humor also arises from the situations themselves. Many situations puncture the pretensions of the characters, as when Kenkoy in coat and tie is chased and bitten by a dog.

The second category, narrative komiks, may be grouped into six kinds according to content: stories drawn from or modeled after the old awit and korido (metrical tales), such as the artist Francisco Coching’s Don Cobarde and Haring Ulupong (Serpent King); fantastic adventures in tropical jungles or in distant lands, such as Pedrito Reyes and Francisco Reyes’s Kulafu and Coching’s Hagibis; supernatural or strange wonders, such as Ravelo and Elpidio Torres’s Dyesebel; love stories, such as Gilda Olvidado and Joey Celerio’s Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You) and Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?); history-inspired stories or biographies, such as Coching’s Vibora and Fred Alcala’s Yamato, based on incidents of World War II; and realistic stories based on social problems, such as Ravelo’s Roberta. There are also special comics that were inspired by literary classics, such as Francisco Balagtas’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). Comics on the life of Christ and Catholic saints are also used for didactic purposes. Comics could also be based on true-to-life stories—for example, that of actress Nora Aunor, produced for a fandom.

The narrative or story komiks has two drawing traditions, the romantic and the realistic. The first was dominated by Coching. The style is characterized by dynamic curvilinear lines and tonal modeling with a fluid, undulating effect. The leading male characters are stalwart in build, and of handsome mestizo or Malay looks, with curly hair and rippling muscles. The female leads are mestiza, graceful, and usually with long curly tresses. It is a style that gives life to the myths and legends of yore and to fantasies of love and adventure. In Coching’s El Indio (The Native), 1952, the story revolves around the dark-skinned and salakot-wearing Fernando and his search for his true identity. A viscount turned rebel, Fernando is Hispanic yet also Filipino—a trope that found resonance with the public. Aside from Coching, Nestor Redondo, Federico C. Javinal, Mar T. Santana, Hal Santiago, Steve Gan, and Nestor Malgapo also work in this tradition.

The realist tradition, on the other hand, which deal with contemporary issues and problems or expose the true conditions of society, is prevalent in komiks. Based on personal and familial situations, many of the narratives are drawn from real life, and so are the characters who are ordinary people without extraordinary qualities. The style, even and detailed, is based on a keen observation of reality. Outstanding examples of this tradition are Ravelo’s Roberta and Pablo Gomez and Nestor Redondo’s Batang Bangkusay. Working in the realist tradition are Celerio, Redondo, Entes Magpusao, Fred Carrillo, Fred P. Alcala, and Ben Maniclang.

The third kind of komiks, the instructional cartoons are those that illustrate an analysis or point of view regarding a social or political issue usually produced by institutions and cause-oriented groups. They basically aim to develop social awareness. The drawing style may be realist or nonrealist, depending on intention. To this type belong editorial cartoons made by artists like Alcala, Marcelo, Dalena, Jess Abrera, Edgar Soller, Corky Trinidad, Jose Tence Ruiz, Arnel Mirasol, Net Billones, Norman B. Isaac, and Esmeralda Izon. Marcelo, creator of Ikabod Bubwit, still uses this character for editorial purposes. Ruiz and Dalena did insightful drawings on social and political issues, which were as powerful as their larger paintings. Abrera lampooned social issues in the Philippine Daily Inquirer. Trinidad and Soller have gone on to doing editorial cartoons for international publications. Mirasol and Izon continued to illustrate ideas in their cartoons. All in all, editorial cartoon straddles various drafting styles, from stylized animal images to sketches that have a painterly effect.

Editorial cartoons have played an important role in social movements in the Philippines. Underground papers, such as Ulos, have reproduced illustrations done by underground artists as well as aboveground artists sympathetic to their cause. Common themes of these cartoons are the oppression of the peasants and workers, US imperialism, and the Philippines depicted as a woman battling the many-headed dragon representing social problems.

In recent years, novelty comic books have also developed, such as Don’t Take a Bath on a Friday: Philippine Superstitions and Folk Beliefs, 1996, illustrated by Katti Sta. Ana.

The popularity of comic characters have also pushed the crossover to film, theater, and television. Coching’s work have been made into films. Other examples include Ravelo’s Darna and Dyesebel; Jim Fernandez’s Zuma; Ravelo and Fernandez’s Captain Barbell; Alcala’s Kalabog and Bosyo, as well as Asiong Aksaya; and Carlo Caparas’s Ang Panday. The last, like Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), has also been adapted for television. The Kenkoy character has been used for the theater musical Kenkoy at Rosing.

In 2013, digitally printed excerpts of the Nardong Tae (Nardo the Shit Guy) comic series by Louie Cordero was included in the exhibit The Philippine Contemporary: To Scale the Past and the Possible, 2013-15, at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. The inclusion of the work marks the acceptance of pop culture as part of contemporary art practice. In 2014, Francisco V. Coching received posthumously the National Artist award for visual arts. Written byAlice G. Guillermo and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Helen Yu-Rivera

text:
Leaf art refers to ephemeral works made of leaf, which may have a functional as well as aesthetic use. Leafart should be distinguished from basketry, which also uses leaves like buri palm, because baskets are made to last. Leaves are used for food wrapping, religious ritual, and modern artistic expression. The most commonly used leaves are banana, palm, and anahaw.

For wrapping food, banana and palm leaves are most frequently used. Banana leaves have a midrib and two parts of soft plant material. The ribs are usually removed. Not all leaves are serviceable; only resilient ribs are usually chosen. Banana leaves may be used to wrap foodstuffs, like the square tamales sold by peddlers, or they may be used to wrap individual servings of rice cooked in one huge pot. The trunk of the banana, which consists of layers of vegetable matter, can also be peeled off and flattened for wrapping. These may be used with banana leaves as in the wrapping of the kesong puti or white cheese. Here the soft square slab of cheese is first boxed in the strip of banana trunk, then wrapped in several layers of banana leaves, and finally tied with banana fiber. In Pangasinan, panocha or raw sugar is wrapped in banana trunk, then shaped like a gourd by tying.

More flexible and expressive than banana are palm leaves. In Batangas, buri is used for pakaskas or raw sugar. The buri are shaped like circular canisters, liquid sugar poured in and hardened, and the whole covered with buri cut into a circular shape. Stacks of these circular canisters are tied together with buri. Coconut leaf wrappers are used for suman (sticky rice cake) and puso (cooked rice wrapped in heart-shaped coconut leaf). The practice of wrapping suman with ibus (young, light unopened coconut leaves which are pliant) takes several regional forms. In the Visayas, the whole coconut leaf with midrib is laid flat, glutinous rice placed in the center, the leaf folded over it, then bound. In the Tagalog region, to wrap suman, a side of the leaf is removed from the midrib and then coiled closely to form a cylinder; one end is sealed with a piece of midrib, wet rice is placed inside, and the other end sealed. All of it is wrapped with thin strips of ibus. There are various shapes of the puso: kinasing is shaped like a heart, binaki is flat like a frog at rest, and tinigib has one flattened corner like a chisel. Woven from one or several ibus, rice is placed inside the puso and cooked. Other Visayan items that may be called leaf art are impermanent baskets for holding fruit and hats made of woven coconut leaf. In Mindanao and Sulu, the folk weave pinipig or rice-cake containers from palm leaves dyed in magenta and other hues and fashioned in the simple shape of a bird or tapering tree of life. They also weave dome-shaped food covers of palm leaf dyed in different colors.

It is in its ritual uses where the leaf assumes heightened artistic expression. Here coconut leaves are stripped from their stalk and used to line platforms, arched to decorate balconies and entrances, cut, plaited, and folded to create decorative shapes. Anahaw are usually tucked into walls and combined with flowers and paper to make bouquets. Aside from the town fiesta, there are three big fiesta clusters in the Philippines for Christianized Filipinos, each of which has its own uses of leaf: Lent, the Maytime festivals, and Christmas. During Lent and Semana Santa or Holy Week, from Palm Sunday to Easter Sunday, leaves play an important part. Temporary structures, called kubol in Tagalog and abong-abong in Ilocos, are set up for chanting the pasyon, a long narrative poem on the suffering and death of Christ. The kubol is traditionally made of a bamboo frame roofed and decorated with coconut leaves, plaited, and decorated with flowers. The kubol is similar to temporary structures built to accommodate guests for a meal at a wedding or a fiesta or to structures built in rice fields for resting or sleeping. In the kubol is an altar with images of saints before which devotees sing the pasyon. The Ilocano abong-abong uses vegetables rather than flowers for decorations.

Palm Sunday celebrates the entry of Jesus Christ into Jerusalem. For the high Mass, devotees bring their palaspas or palm leaves to church to be blessed by the priest. The palaspas are long stalks of coconut or buri palm with their fronds plaited into decorative patterns and embellished with crepe-paper flowers. A palaspas has two parts: a decorative handle and the decorated fronds from which hang the woven stars, grasshoppers and other figures from palm leaves or tiny paper flags. The decorative handle may be heart-shaped or woven like a mat or folded into overlapping bows. The fronds may be cut and folded or may be plaited to form zigzag patterns, called kidlat (lightning), espada (swordlike designs), bola (ball), ibon (bird), hipon (shrimp), and other designs similar to those found in floral offerings in Indonesia. Similar ways of decorating palm fronds are found among the Tausug who use kidlat-shaped leaves in an arrangement of fruit and flowers for weddings. The galilea, an elevated platform decorated with leaves and flowers, is built in the church patio for the choir who will sing the chants of the day. After the fiesta, the palaspas are placed on the walls, doors, or windows to drive away evil spirits and lightning.

Coconut leaves are also fashioned into children’s toys. They can be shaped as bracelets, rings, crowns, balls, trucks, or whatever anyone fancies or is able to do through folding or cutting. In Bulacan, the practice of leaf plaiting is called puni. Using fresh coconut leaves and dried colored buri leaves, plaiting involves the process of weaving the leaf strands into toys and decorations designed as birds, stars, fish, balls, hats, and play swords.

The harvest festival of the Pahiyas, held on 15 May in Quezon province, has as its particular feature the decoration of the outer walls of the houses. The word pahiyas is associated with the general Tagalog word “hiyas,” which means gem, jewel, or adornment. Its closest vernacular counterpart among the Lukbanin is payas, which refers to decoration. What primarily distinguishes the Pahiyas from other practices of the San Isidro tradition is the use of kiping (variously colored leaf-shaped rice wafers) as staple decorative material. Kiping are molded from leaves of kabal (Fagrearacemosa), a plant endemic to Lucban. Kiping are thin, translucent wafers made from rice flour and molded in large leaves and dyed with different colors. The traditional colors used for the kiping are red, green, yellow, and vivid pink. However, with the availability of diversity of choices in commercial food color, other hues such as blue, violet, orange, and white have been used for the kiping. Together with artistic compositions of fruits, bamboo branches, anahaw and coconut leaves, and products of the town, such as buntal hats and bakya or wooden slippers, kiping brighten the fiesta with their vivid hues arranged in rows or as arangya or chandeliers, flowers, wall covers, and hanging mobiles. Since they are made of rice flour, they can later be fried to make a crisp delicacy. Likewise, at the windows of the houses are hung glazed bread molded in the form of fish, horses, and other animals, along with strings of pastillas or milk candy and other sweets which are thrown down to the crowds when the andas (portable platform) of San Isidro passes the house.

In May, coconut fronds are also used to decorate the kubol carried by four persons to “house” the muses and queens of the Santacruzan procession. In Pulilan, Bulacan, on 15 May, coconut and palm leaves decorate the carabaos that kneel before the church and the carts that they pull behind them. Coconut fronds also decorate the many stages erected for performances of the komedya or the sarsuwela.

On Christmas, coconut fronds, anahaw, and flowers may decorate the houses where the panunuluyan procession may stop. The same leaves are combined with cloths of many colors to decorate the stage of the TatlongHari play in Gasan, Marinduque.

For fiestas, coconut and anahaw leaves are used to decorate the church and altar, the arco (arches) erected at strategic points where the procession of the patron saint will pass, the kubol where the loa or poem of praise will be declaimed for the patron saint, and the stage on which the play or variety show is to be performed.

The works of contemporary artists such as RobertoVillanueva, Junyee, and SantiagoBose make much use of leaves to convey ecological meanings. Leaf art also signifies a grassroots cultural context different from urban ways of thinking. Many other artists have experimented on expressive possibilities of leaf and its transitoriness, thus adding popular expression to the repertoire of the professional artist. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Pearl E. Tan and Cecilia S. De La Paz

text:
Mat weaving is the art of weaving or plaiting strips of organic fibers into mats. All regions of the Philippines have a tradition of mat weaving since mats are used all over the country as bedding material. Because mats are made from organic materials, they are cool and suitable to the hot tropical climate. They make an ecologically healthy, light, and portable sleeping surface on the slatted bamboo floors of the native huts or the wooden floors of modern houses of the large majority of Filipinos. Unlike fixed beds, they are also space savers because they are easily rolled up and stacked in a corner after use.

Most Philippine mats are made of the leaves of pandan or the buri palm, plaited to create a continuous surface. They are often decorated with strips of one or two colors, creating simple linear patterns. Mats from Capiz and Aklan are simple and delicate, with geometric designs on borders; those from Laguna are plain and softly brown.

Mat weaving is women’s work. It begins with the gathering of the raw material from plants, after which it is stripped, boiled, dyed, and woven—the whole process taking several weeks. The quality of a mat is judged from the softness of its material, the fineness of its weave, and the beauty of its design patterns. Because mat weaving in some areas has reached the level of an art, mats do not only serve the function of bedding material but are also sometimes used as medium of exchange in barter. Beautiful mats are especially fashioned for wedding rituals, and in festive occasions they may be used as carpets. Southern weavers also make them in smaller sizes to be used as prayer mats or as household decorations.

Nowadays, mats are easily bought from native stores or from itinerant woman vendors, but in the 19th century and in the early decades of the 20th century, mats were made-to-order by families and individuals to be given as gifts and to commemorate special occasions, such as weddings, wedding anniversaries, and birthdays. These commemorative mats often bore the letters “Recuerdo,” “Souvenir,” “Alaala” (all meaning, remembrance), and “Mr and Mrs” or the name of the family or individual emblazoned along its length bordered with floral or geometric designs. Double mats made of two mats joined together, the ornamented one on top and the plain one serving as lining, are the more durable and more expensive kind.

In Sulu, particularly in the small island of Laminusa off the coast of Siasi, the women of the Samal group weave colorful mats with intricate geometric designs requiring the utmost skill and artistry. These famous Laminusa mats made of pandanus fibers are distinguished by their exceptional pliability, exquisite fineness, and remarkable smoothness and sheen. So soft and pliable are they that they crumple without creasing and are thus often mistaken for woven cloth. Ornamentals like tapestries serve as beautiful wall decors. As two-dimensional art made of plaited organic fibers, they rival the op art canvases because of their recurring colorful geometric patterns. Laminusa mats are usually backed with a thicker, plain mat. An outstanding mat weaver is MaluyLasaSambolani, 1990 Manlilikha ng Bayan awardee.

Another center of mat weaving is the town of Basey, Samar, 40 km from Tacloban, Leyte. The Basey mat is made of two organic materials, the sedges of the tikog (from the family of Fimbrylisglobulosa) and buri of the Palmae family. After harvesting the tikog plant, the sedges are sun-dried moderately, then dyed. After dyeing, they are laid out in the open air overnight—pinapahamogan—to make them more pliable. The final process in the preparation of the tikog for weaving is called the paglagot in which a 10.16 cm bamboo sliver called lag-ot is used to polish the sedges; this done, the sedges are gathered into bundles of 200, a family-size mat measuring 2 m x 1.6 m using up four bundles. This takes a maximum of two and a half days weaving time, usually with two weavers working on opposite sides until they meet at the center.

The natural color of the woven tikog mats serve as the “neutral” background for the process of decorating the mat called embroidery. Strips of the buri palm are used for ornamentation. They are soaked in commercial dyes sold in small packages of five grams. The preferred colors are usually green, red, yellow, various shades of pink, and yellow green. When preparing the dyes, the amount of water determines the strength of the color; likewise, dyes may be mixed—such as green and yellow—to produce a desired hue. In order to create the figurative designs, a skilled designer makes an outline drawing on the mat with chalk or crayon. The embroiderer, again usually a woman, inserts the buri strips following the design and uses a household knife to cut them.

Existing literature on Basey mat-weaving in the late 1970s reveals that the more popular designs were the waling-waling flower, maps of the Philippines, map of Leyte and Samar, and birds such as peacocks. In the 1990s, the popular designs bore the images of the Santo Niño, the San Juanico Bridge, and flowers. The inclusion of images of the Santo Niño and the San Juanico Bridge comes from the grassroots, as both symbols are popular in the region and register readily with Samar and Leyte locals’ shared experiences. The Santo Niño icon is highly regarded not just in Tacloban City, where these mats are usually exhibited or sold, but also in Cebu and other Visayan areas. In the past, the Balyuan Festival was celebrated to commemorate the exchange of Santo Niño images between Tacloban and Basey. The San Juanico Bridge, meanwhile, plays a vital role in the lives of the people of the region as it connects the two large islands of Samar and Leyte. Basey is probably the nearest Samar town after traversing the bridge from Tacloban City. The waling-waling design, like those of maps, birds, and other flowers, were borrowed, if they were not imagined or invented by mat weavers, to suit popular tastes. Floral designs are said to have originated from the front covers of mass-produced notepads during the 1990s featuring plants grown on Western soil, indicating the appropriation of images from popular culture. The combination of traditional weaving with changing popular motifs indicates the process of transformation of Basey mats.

After Benigno Aquino Jr’s assassination in 1983, his portrait became a popular design among the embroiderers. There was a considerable demand for this design, which was followed by orders for portraits of other people, famous figures, and middle-class individuals who commissioned their portraits and those of their family and friends. One particular type that gained popularity was the portrait of newlyweds who submit their photographs for copying on the unique medium.

From these developments, it is clear that the Basey mats no longer function solely as bedding material but have assumed the function of paintings as well. The mat with the San Juanico Bridge becomes a landscape to be admired, that with the Santo Niño assumes the function of an altar painting for devotions, while portraits serve as reminders of people as well as status symbols.

It then follows that the sizes of mats have become more varied, from the standard single or double sleeping mats to smaller mats for portraits and decorative designs, such as flowers. To complete the process, the mats are framed with bamboo and hung like paintings to be appreciated on the walls. Likewise, the mat weavers and the embroiderers have become mutually independent, with the embroiderers simply buying finished mats from the market for them to design. The function of the decorative mats has even broadened to include material for bags and pillow covers, so that the Basey mat has now set its mark on interior design although on a still limited scale. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Alden Q. Lauzon
