text:
Painting is a process in which various colored pigments and dyes are suspended in a binder (like gum Arabic dissolved in water, slaked lime, linseed oil, or acrylic), resulting in a medium, which is then applied to a surface as a wet layer via a tool (such as a brush, palette knife, spatula, squeegee, airbrush, or fingers). When the medium dries, it leaves a permanent mark as in a figure upon that surface. Oftentimes, the surface, called the ground, is of a compatible substance that retains the applied medium as it adheres to it like skin. The ground is generally understood to be flat or two-dimensional, such as a wall, wood panel, paper, or piece of canvas that is stretched around a frame. However, a curved or three-dimensional ground can also be used in the case of painting done on interior vaults, and rounded objects like pottery and jewelry. This demonstrates the Filipino penchant for painting religious (and now secular) sculptures to show lifelike verisimilitude, a process called encarnacion. Fabric, meant to be worn and thus seen three-dimensionally in relation to its wearer’s body and movements, can also be painted. The distribution of a figure upon a ground is premised on either a desired decorative effect multiplied upon the entire viewing surface; or the evocation of specific imagery associated with a visual convention, or iconography practiced by the painter’s community.

The combination of both indigenous and introduced traditions of painting has made the Philippines a rich and complex source of study in the visual arts. Traditional Western painting materials, like oil on canvas or tempera on panel, were rendered using local dyes and pigments, especially during the Spanish colonial period, when importation of art materials from Europe was prohibitively costly. In the contemporary period, the rediscovery of native painting traditions alongside the latest imports from abroad have also resulted in experimentations of materials, such as the use of coffee or tea staining; batik tie-dye resist; silk-screening inks; mixed media; and organic dyes from local flora, chief among these red from the narra tree (pterocarpus indicus), blue from the indigo plant (indigofera hirsuta), and yellow from turmeric or yellow ginger (curcuma longa). The use of indigenous sources for ground have also been explored, notably katsa (cheesecloth), beaten tree bark, and banig (reed-woven) mats.

Since painting often requires a visualization of forms embedded within specific stylistic conventions and subject matter, the field of painting is often subdivided into themes—primarily, religious, historical, mythical-symbolic, portraiture, landscape, still life, figure genres, nudes, seascapes, and various stylized abstractions. Painting is also subdivided into size formats, from miniatures (less than 10 cm across), to easel paintings (less than 1.5 m across), to murals (more than 1.5 m across).

Medium, Form, Process, and Technique

The oldest painting medium is fresco. Applied directly on a wall primed with damp plaster and painted with a slaked lime formula infused with pigment, frescoes are meant to dry naturally, forming a chemical bond with the wall surface that makes it impervious to water. The traditional method of fresco in Europe is the buon fresco method, in which layers of lime plaster of increasing purity are lain on a brick or stone wall, then painted while the final wall layer is still damp. An adaptation of this method is the a secco fresco technique, in which a layer of fresh plaster is overlain on top of the dried wall, onto which changes to the original fresco design are painted.

Another traditional painting medium is tempera. A hard wood panel is prepared using gesso (a combination of rabbit skin glue, slaked lime plaster, and gum Arabic) so that it might absorb layers of paint composed of pigments mixed with egg yolk (called a size) suspended in water. The size and pigment combination is then applied to the ground via brushes. The flexibility of the pigment allows the painter to scrape overlain layers of tempera to expose underlying layers, creating a multiple pattern of colors.

Oil painting, which started in Europe in the 15th century, utilizes a thicker medium of linseed oil mixed with pigment applied on linen or cotton canvas. Due to the “fatter” nature of oil, more pigment binds to the medium, allowing the paint to thicken to a paste. This thickness is exploited to produce textures on the paint layer, which takes a longer time to harden. This longer drying time also allows the painter to rework the paint surface via a “wet on wet” (called alla prima) technique, or a thicker buildup of paint to achieve an almost three-dimensional effect (called impasto) on the surface. Oil painting can also be done thinly to achieve ethereal effects. One method employs the glazing technique, in which a small amount of paint is mixed with a large amount of oil, and then spread thinly on the surface, drying as a colored “film” on top of the paint layer. A famous technique of glazing is called sfumato, in which multiple layers of glaze produce a hazy effect on the background of figurative subjects. Another technique is scumbling, when small amounts of paint are placed on top of a dried painted surface using a dry sponge or rag. The paint is caught within the grooves of the texturized surface of the underpainting, creating “touches” of color that accent the overall look of the painting. Finally, there is a technique called chiaroscuro, where a combination of glazing and brushing produces an illusion of depth created by a combination of light and shadow. The canvas layer is prepared or primed via the use of gesso though contemporary oil painters use latex or acrylic paint to prime their canvas. After the paint layer is dried (a process that can take up to two years), the oil painting is varnished using an organic-based resonated compound like damar to protect the paint layer from damage. Accumulation of dirt in the repeated varnishing of oil paintings through the decades or centuries darkens the painting, unless restoration is done by removing the old varnish layer; and then revarnishing the painting once more. Painting tools include hand-held brushes of various sizes and shapes, a palette for mixing colors, palette knives and spatulas, a mahl stick used to support the painting hand during detailing work, and easels to prop up the painting.

Aquarelle or watercolor emerged by the 18th century, and is used as a more spontaneous or informal means of painting. A mixture of gum Arabic and water is boiled, after which finely ground pigments are added and mixed using a stone grinder until a soft paste consistency is reached. Watercolor is applied using brushes on paper, using more water as a vehicle for chromatically altering the medium. Watercolors dry as translucent layers, unlike oil that dries into an opaque surface. A later industrial version of watercolor that dries opaquely was invented by the 19th century, called gouache. Its appearance allowed more commercial applications of painting, such as poster design, to be produced inexpensively.

Acrylic paint emerged in the 1930s, but wasn’t commercially available in the Philippines until the 1960s. Acrylic uses a polymer chemical based from petroleum by-products, such as polyvinyl acetate, or other acrylic emulsion polymers. This is mixed as binder to industrial dyes to create a wide variety of acrylic colors, which are soluble in water, but have a rapid drying time. Acrylics generally dry “matte” (that is, appear flat on the surface with a dull finish), and thus require acrylic emulsion varnish to be applied on top to create luster. To thicken the acrylic color to a consistency similar to oil, acrylic gel or binding medium is mixed, with a higher ratio of paint to gel in order to preserve colorfastness and luminosity.

Genres

Philippine painting can be classified according to the subjects or themes it has had over the centuries: religious paintings, historical paintings, portraits, nudes, genres, interiors, landscapes, seascapes, still lifes, abstract painting, and folk painting.

Religious painting is the oldest and longest-lasting genre category in Philippine painting. Perhaps among the earliest surviving oil painting icons is that of the Nuestra Señora de Peñafrancia in Paco, Manila, that dates back to the 1620s, and is an altarpiece painting. Statues of saints and engravings from Europe were used as models for religious paintings. It was common to portray a favorite saint complete with a wooden stand and a pair of curtains flanking it. Well into the 19th century, religious painting stressed correct iconography rather than realistic rendering of a theme. Smaller devotional icons have been painted throughout the Spanish colonial period, from the surviving icons of Manila-based Fausto Quiotan, Damian Domingo, Justiniano Asuncion, and Lorenzo Rocha; the mural-sized works of Jose Dans in Paete; and the Stations of the Cross series from anonymous artists in Bohol during the late 18th to early 19th century. By the late 19th to early 20th century, religious painters would include icon painter Juan Senson of Angono and Cebuano ceiling muralists Canuto Avila and Raymundo Francia. Carlos Francisco and Galo Ocampo would continue the practice of depicting religious iconography in the modern period.

Styles of religious painting have often been iconic, meaning that they follow strict Church conventions regarding form and subject matter. However, historical styles do occur throughout religious painting as a result of shifts in period tastes and fashion. The painters associated with the Gremios Chinos de Santa Cruz, such as Fausto Quiotan, adhered to a more rococo coloration of bright pastel hues mixed with Qing Dynasty Chinese infusions in motifs, like Sinicized eyes and faces. Such 19th-century icons were heavily influenced by the miniaturismo style of Damian Domingo, Ysidro Arceo, and Justiniano Asuncion. Modern icons, such as Carlos Francisco’s 1957 Stations of the Cross murals for Far Eastern University adhered to a cinematic montage format using his trademark sinuous style inspired from Art Deco while Galo Ocampo’s stained glass window designs for the Manila Cathedral, 1956, combined Cubist and Revivalist Gothic styles.

In the European academies, historical paintings consisted of large-scale compositions of human figures depicting a scene from history, the Bible, Graeco-Roman scenes, or an allegory. These paintings were intended to strengthen the moral fiber of a nation; thus they often contained a lesson or praised national values, like courage, steadfastness, generosity, and patriotism. Historical paintings also extolled the virtues of great persons, real or legendary.

In the Philippines, historical and mythical-symbolic painting started in the early 19th century in the form of folk-style painting. This is best demonstrated by Esteban Villanueva’s Basi Revolt series, 1807, and expanded more fully in the mid- to late 19th century, and the first decade of the 20th century. Historical and mythical-symbolic paintings eventually became the domain primarily of expatriate Filipino artists like Juan Luna, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, and Academia painters like Telesforo Sucgang. The official style of Paris’s Ecole de Beaux-Arts, which combined Neoclassicism, Romanticism, and Symbolism, were used for this period, as can be seen in Luna’s El Spoliarium (literally “Room of Spoils” or basement of a Roman Coliseum), 1884, and El Pacto de Sangre (Blood Compact), 1885; and Hidalgo’s Per Pacem et Libertatem (Through Peace and Liberty), 1904 (destroyed 1945), and the undated El Asesinato del Gobernador Bustamante y su Hijo (The Assassination of Govenor Bustamante and Son). From the mid- to late 20th century, Fernando Amorsolo, Carlos aka “Botong” Francisco, Vicente Manansala, and Amadeo Manalad were prominent painters of historical scenes using various Modernist styles. Amorsolo used his patented academic style imaging brilliant sunlight and sensually depicted native subject matter, as seen in Burning of the Idols, 1955-60. Francisco’s Filipino Struggles through History, 1963-67, used a fusion of Mexican Social Realism with the sinuous curves and primary-secondary colors; and Manansala’s Planting of the First Cross, 1965, used his Synthetic Cubist style of careful delineations of shard-like stained glass lines.

Portrait painting seeks to capture the basic physical likeness of the subject and to show insight into his/her essential character or psychological makeup. From earliest times portraits have fulfilled different functions: as a record of a person’s physical appearance, as a souvenir of a loved one or an ancestor, as a status symbol, as a model image of a leader or prominent social personality for public edification. Before the advent of photography, the portrait fulfilled the camera’s function of recording and preserving a person’s physical likeness, but portraiture as an art has always transcended mere likeness and showed artistic insight into the subject’s personality.

In the early 19th century, portrait painting emerged in the Philippines. The works of Damian Domingo ushered in the miniaturismo (miniaturism) style. Miniaturismo is a term applied to the technique of “limning” used by 19th-century artists, in which a very fine brush was used for outlining and bringing out minute details. The artist demonstrated his skill in sharply rendering the details of costume-intricate embroidery on fine transparent cloth, jewelry, and personal accessories, like the fan and handkerchief. Work done by Domingo on ivory locket-sized portrait paintings later expanded into easel-sized works, with detailed rendering of the rich embroidery, jewelry, and furnishings of newly rich principalia families.

With the secularization of art in 19th-century Philippines, portraits as a separate genre appeared, although for some time the only portraits made were of Spanish officials and church dignitaries, such as those done by JuanArceo. The opening of the Philippines to international trade in the mid-19th century and the development of export-crop agriculture resulted in the rise of a local merchant class, afforded with social and educational advancement, who were called ilustrado. This emergent class commissioned portraits to celebrate its social ascendency.

Well-known portraitists found patrons among the elite not only in Manila but in the provinces as well. Their painstaking recording of material detail answered the elite’s desire to display its status. Among these artists were SimonFlores y de la Rosa who spent his years in Pampanga painting for churches and the rich, Justiniano Asuncion, AntonioMalantic, Isidro Arceo, and Dionisio de Castro. Masterpieces of 19th-century portraiture include Arceo’s Retrato de la Familia Azcarraga (Portrait of the Azcarraga Family), 1824; Flores’s portrait of the FamiliaQuiason, 1880; de Castro’s Soterania Puzon deQuintosyVentanilla, 1892; Malantic’s portraits of Soledad Francia and Inocencia Francia , 1876; and Asuncion’s RomanaCarillo, 1875.

On the other hand, late 19th-century portraitists like Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, who won distinctions at the Madrid Exposition of 1884, used a combination of Beaux-Arts and Academic styles resulting in somber and formal depictions of personalities, like Luna’s Una Bulaqueña (Bulaqueña Lady), 1895; or Hidalgo’s Don Felipe Agoncillo, 1988. Sometimes, however, Impressionism, with its use of textured paint, bright pastel colors, and the privileging of outdoor sunlight was also used by Luna and Hidalgo for society portraiture, like Luna’s Picnic at Normandy, 1885; or Hidalgo’s Portrait of Teresa Tuason, 1901.

During the American period, Amorsolo was the portraitist par excellence of public figures, American colonial officials, and prominent Filipinos who commissioned him to do their portraits. Not to be overlooked is FabiandelaRosa who did a number of outstanding portraits, among them, one of Pura Villanueva-Kalaw. Other notable portraitists were JorgePineda and IrineoMiranda. Examples include Amorsolo’s Portrait of Jorge Vargas, 1943, and Martino Abellana’s Portrait of Don Ramon Aboitiz, 1957. Among Modernists, Diosdado Lorenzo and Victorio Edades championed Post-Impressionist cum Expressionist styles that resulted in colorful, serenely depicted but brutalist portraits, such as Lorenzo’s Old Woman with Mortar, 1937, or Edades’s Portrait of Purita Kalaw-Ledesma , 1976. In the 1960s and 1970s, Expressionism became a major language for portraiture, with its use of exaggerated emotions, contorted poses, thickly or thinly applied paint, and agonized depictions symbolizing the alienation of modernity and the horrors of martial law. An example is Onib Olmedo’s Adele H., 1976; or Danilo Dalena’s Portrait of Roberto Chabet, 1983. Romulo Galicano uses a postmodern combination of Amorsolo-style depiction with abstracted vertical lines, as can be seen in Portrait of Felix Y. Manalo, 2014. Other contemporary portraitists like Isabel Diaz also use postmodern techniques derived from Hyperrealism and American West Coast Art, like Portrait of Frank Gehry, 2013.

Genre painting, which depicts people in everyday activities, became popular in the Philippines beginning in the 19th century. Genre in Europe flourished in Holland in the 17th century, with its lively secular baroque, and also in Spain where they were called bodegones, under such masters as Diego Velazquez. Genre is often full of movement and a sense of community life and collective activity. The changing subjects of genre reflect social and historical developments. Genre painting is perhaps the most popular and wide-ranging of Philippine painting practices. These include early examples like the anonymous (presumed to be Chinese) illustrators of the Boxer Codex, which pioneered the tipos del pais (country scenes) format in the 1590s using a combination of Southern Ming and Spanish late medieval style painting on paper. The watercolor on paper album de trajes (album of costumes) of Damian Domingo in the Newberry Library (ca 1820s) and Justiniano Asuncion’s own album of country types at the New York Public Library (1841) both derive similar characteristics from the Boxer Codex in the frequent use of blank backgrounds, but this time the depictions of the tipos del pais are done with minute detailing and clear attempts at a more sympathetic portraiture of accurate racial and physiognomic features.

JoseLozano’s letras y figuras (letters and figures), in which the letters of the patron’s name are spelled out by human figures, contains various tipos del pais of different classes and occupations executed in minute detail as in miniatures; an example is the work Andres Sanchez, 1852. Later albums of inhabitants in their costumes were done by JoseMa.Asuncion, one of the early directors of the UP School of Fine Arts. An impetus to the tipos del pais was also seen in the drawings and lithographic prints of foreign visiting artists, such as Carl Johann Karuth, C. W. Andrews, and Thomas Barker.

When the tipos were contextualized within the natural environment and social setting, genre painting began. The 19th-century Academia artists combined the need for accurate portrayal of people and places with a lighter, more lyrical use of lighting that can be said to be the stylistic equivalent to the Romantic movement in Europe. This can be seen in Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo’s La Banca (The Native Boat), 1876; Lorenzo Guerrero’s El Fuego (The Fire), 1889; and Simon Flores’s Primeras Letras (First Letters), 1890.

Closely related to genre is the painting of domestic interiors, such as the inside of a sala or a room of a house or the hall of a building. An interior, first of all, shows the disposition of space inside a house and how it relates with the outside by means of doors and windows. Much of the interest of interiors comes from the furnishings of the house, the types of furniture, and the various ornaments within. It is obvious that an interior reveals social class in the kind of house portrayed, particularly with respect to its materials—whether strong and permanent, or light and fragile—and in its furnishings and decorations. An interior also reveals the kind of people who live in it—their interests, tastes, and temperaments. Tonal values are important in interiors because they create a dialogue between the shadowed interiors and the bright outdoors, as well as convey atmosphere and mood. Luna’s Tampuhan (Sulking) is partly genre, partly interior, as the two personages are in the living room of a bahaynabato or stone house. Lozano’s letras y figuras of BalvinoMauricio shows in several sections the interior of a handsome 19th-century villa.

Contemporary artists who excel in interiors are Romulo Galicano and Sofronio Y. Mendoza aka SYM who both did a number in a fresh, impressionist style, capturing the grace and casualness of present-day houses with some traditional features, such as capiz windows, screens, and gallinera (long carved benches).

Genre painting grew in importance in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, helped by the numerous drawings and engravings of foreign visitors such as C. W. Andrews and Joseph Anton Koch. Artists were encouraged to look around and observe the folk as they went about their daily occupations. Filipino illustrator Gabino Reyes Congson produced humorous genre images of Manila’s street characters for the Philippine Magazine, from 1936 to 1941.

Genre contributed an important self-reflective quality to Philippine art, one that raised the question of national identity in a colonial era. The rural genre paintings of Fabian de la Rosa, Fernando Amorsolo, Dominador Castañeda, Toribio Herrera, Jorge Pineda, and Vicente Rivera continued the Beaux-Arts academic tradition. De la Rosa portrayed the ilustrado setting in Kundiman (Love Song), which shows a young woman singing, accompanied on the piano, before admiring guests.

The high point of genre was reached in the paintings of the Amorsolo school. Amorsolo’s RicePlanting heralded the golden age of Philippine genre. In the 1930s the dominant visual form was rural genre depicting the cycle of planting and harvesting. Based in the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, the Amorsolo school, which, aside from Amorsolo, included Jorge Pineda, Irineo Miranda, DominadorCastañeda, TeodoroBuenaventura, Toribio Herrera, and Amorsolo’s brother Pablo, contributed significantly to the development of genre in idyllic scenes of the countryside and its people.

From the mid-1940s to the 1960s, the genre works of conservatives like Dominador Castañeda, Crispin Lopez, Miguel Galvez, Simon Saulog, and Oscar Navarro would continue the tradition of academic painting that closely followed the more formulaic renditions of Amorsolo, particularly of rural planting and harvest scenes, groups of peasants at rest or in fiesta, nipa huts, and seashore communities. Cesar Buenaventura and Paco Gorospe, the most dominant members of this group during its “Mabini” Period, 1955-early 1980s, however, painted in a combination of Modernist impasto techniques and semi-abstracted Salon Cubism.

In Philippine Modern Art, genre expanded in scope and stylization. Victorio Edades’s The Builders and The Sketch , 1928, followed the American Expressionist style of The Eight. Diosdado Lorenzo’s Batalan (Washing Area), 1939, adapted the Italian Machiaioli style of Post-Impressionist textures applied unto rural genre. Carlos Francisco’s Pista sa Nayon (Rural Fiesta), 1946, used exuberant colors and curving compositional lines to expand the rural genre into mural form. Highly stylized is Hugo Yonzon Jr’s Fishermen, 1948.

With the development of modernism in the post-World War II years, new painters of genre, such as Manansala, Legaspi, AnitaMagsaysay-Ho, RomeoTabuena, and Ricarte Puruganan, discovered many new subjects in the postwar scene, such as jeepneys, barong-barong or shanty, sari-sari or variety stores, vendors of candles, flowers, and all kinds of ware. Fiestas also became a popular genre subject, as in Mauro Malang Santos’s paintings. Angono-based Francisco dealt with folk traditions in ritual and dance.

Vicente Manansala’s Madonna of the Slums , 1950, creates cubistic shards through which figure genre became “modernized” but still recognizable and noble. Cesar Legaspi’s Gadgets , 1949, combines a stylized Art Deco-inspired cubism with the newer scenery of industrial laborers that paved the way for later developments in Social Realism. From the late 1950s onward, the Expressionistic works of University of Santo Tomas (UST) graduates like Ang Kiukok, Antonio Austria, Angelito Antonio, Norma Belleza, and Mario Parial depicted folk subjects like vendors and farmers. The genre works of Jose Blanco would initially follow in the vein of the Modern muralism of Carlos Francisco’s work in the 1960s, but would eventually return to a more Classical Realist style from the 1970s to the 1990s. The genre works of Benedicto Cabrera from the 1970s onward combined his modernist gestural strokes with a Photorealist style that brought out the nostalgia of the past as in his Larawan (Pictures) series, 1972-98. He also focused on the form of vagrant women in his Sabel series, 1968-2013. Finally, the genre works of Anita Magsaysay-Ho from the 1950s to the 1990s followed a semi-Cubist orientation inspired from Art Deco as the artist focused almost exclusively on painting women. Brenda Fajardo reimagined the medieval tarot cards by drawing images of precolonial Filipinos on handmade paper, including the babaylan (shaman priestess), to reflect on the contradictions in Philippine history and society.

A major development in the late 20th century is the emergence of protest art by Social Realists like Pablo Baens Santos, Renato Habulan, Leonilo Doloricon, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Antipas Delotavo, Papo de Asis, and Jose Tence Ruiz. Social Realism in the Philippines encompassed various stylistic approaches, from the Tres Grandes (The Big Three) inspiration of Diego Rivera in the works of Pablo Baens Santos, or David Alfaro Siquieros in the works of Nunelucio Alvarado. The graphic depictions of industrial laborers, peasants, and urban workers by Leonilo Doloricon and Papo de Asis transform the German Expressionism to suit a more collective affiliation of underclass oppression; while Edgar Talusan Fernandez’s Madonna-like depictions of Inang Bayan (Motherland) figures are enriched by the Surrealism of Salvador Dali. Antipas Delotavo’s imagery of the urban poor and migrant laborers parallels the developments of 1970s West Coast Art, in its insistence on Photo-realism mixed with minimal backgrounds, while Renato Habulan’s academic approach to depicting the rural poor is framed within the Neo-Expressionistic credo.

The subject matter of nude painting is the unclothed human figure. It has a long history in Western art starting from the Greek classical period, circa 500 BC, continuing to the Renaissance in the 15th century, unto 19th-century neoclassicism, baroque, and romanticism. With the advent of modernism, the classical canons were challenged by realism, expressionism, and subsequent styles.

In the Philippines, the nude as a subject of painting was hardly found before the 20th century. The santo (religious sculpture) was often clothed, although a few exceptions were the Santo Niño, cherubs and angels, and depictions of Adam and Eve. The nude came to its own in the 19th century, when artists like Luna and Hidalgo, schooled in the tenets of the European academies, used the human figure as the subject of historical and mythical anecdotes. Hidalgo’s La Barca de Aqueronte (Charon’s Boat) writhes with the nude figures of the damned. Luna’s Odalisque and Hidalgo’s Artista y Modelo (The Artist and His Model) use the undraped female as the focus of the works. Nudes in painting have been associated with mythological figures, such as Malakas at Maganda (Strong and Beautiful). Amorsolo’s nudes often represented precolonial babaylan making offerings to the gods, although he is better known for the dalagang bukid or country maiden bathing in the river. Nude drawing and painting from life had been an academic exercise in figure studies at the UP School of Fine Arts since its early years during the American colonial period. Galleries provide venues and models for nude painting sessions. In general, nudes celebrate the female form or express the spirit through material form. However, nude paintings can also be understood as depictions of women as “objectified” by men.

Vicente Manansala, CesarLegaspi, JoseJoya, AlfredoRoces, Federico Aguilar Alcuaz, SolomonSaprid, RomuloOlazo, and PhillipVictor have painted numerous nudes. Manansala more closely followed the Salon Cubist form. The Bali nude series by J. Elizalde Navarro from the 1980s to the 1990s returned his practice to a more Art Deco sensibility of organic forms arrayed in tapestry-like composition. In contrast, the black-and-white male nudes of Jose Legaspi in the 1990s to 2000s were more in tune with the queer gaze directed at men, and had an Expressionistic character informed by psychotherapy. On the other hand, the nude male drawings of Jose Joya from 1975 to 1995 captured native muscular bodies with a degree of academic nobility and a hint of eroticism.

Landscape painting depicts natural scenery and the countryside, although there are also cityscapes or urban scenes. In general, landscapes may be realist, romantic, classical, or expressionist. The subjects of realist landscapes are actual and specific places with their distinct features. They are often done on the spot and thus often have as title the name of an actual place. Romantic landscapes are picturesque, mysterious, exotic, or awe inspiring with a suggestion of the divine spirit in nature. Romantic landscapes are also subjective, expressive of inner mood, with nature viewed through the reflecting lens of the emotions. Classical landscapes are studio pieces often following formulas of ideal proportion and conveying the qualities of balance, harmony, serenity, and permanence in nature. Expressionist landscapes may use distortion and clashing colors to convey strong emotions.

In the Philippines, landscape painting began in the mid-19th century with the secularization of art and the emergence of the ilustrado as the new patrons of art. Some of the early landscapes were done in the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura (Academy of Drawing and Painting). Hidalgo did his first landscapes in the school. They were shady landscapes of deep perspective showing a countryside with lush vegetation and a nipa hut beside a winding river. In Europe, Hidalgo did more landscapes of a romantic mood combined with an impressionist concern for delicate atmospheric effects and changing hues of the sky at different times of the day. Luna did landscapes of the many places he visited, such as the Normandy countryside; the Brittany coast and the Japanese rural scene, influenced by the vigorous Japanese sense of design. Landscapes during the 19th century focused primarily on the interaction between nature and man through farming or living off riverine environments, as exemplified by the works of Lorenzo Guerrero, Felipe Roxas, Felix Resurrecion Hidalgo, Felix Martinez, Carmen Zaragoza, Teodoro Buenaventura, and Patricio Gaston O’Farrell. Works such as Lorenzo Guerrero’s Nipa Hut, 1880, Adelaida Paterno ’s Pasig River Scene, 1896, and Teodoro Buenaventura’s Rio de San Juan, 1927, feature riverbanks filled with foliage, nipa huts on the shoreline, and boats on the river. The continued influence of academism is manifested in the use of soft modulations, and dramatic chiaroscuro contrasts in early 20th-century rural scenes and riverscapes, such as those found in Fabian de la Rosa’s River View of Santa Ana.

Landscape painting had its heyday in the American colonial period with numerous landscapists headed by de la Rosa and Amorsolo. The dominance of landscapes was primarily due to the preference of the new American patrons for countryside scenes, which appealed to them as “exotic.” De la Rosa did realist scenes in the cool light of morning, while Amorsolo used backlighting and warm colors to enhance his countryside views.

Other members of the Amorsolo school based in the UP School of Fine Arts were Pineda, Castañeda, Herrera, Miranda, and PabloAmorsolo. Collectively, the artists of the Amorsolo school created the vocabulary of the Philippine rural landscape: a rice field promising an abundant harvest, a nipa hut under a spreading mango tree, a bamboo grove, a boy on a carabao, a small stream. After the advent of modernism, artists continuing to paint in the Amorsolo style were counted among the conservatives who later set up their studios along Mabini St. These include GabrielCustodio, MiguelGalvez, SerafinSerna, and Cesar Buenaventura.

While Edades—who introduced modernism in 1928—was not a landscapist, another pioneering modernist, DiosdadoLorenzo, specialized in the landscape art in the impressionist style, done with a paint-loaded brush in direct, spontaneous brushwork. Although a modernist, he chose the same familiar barrio scenes for his subjects.

Cityscapes wracked by violence also became a predominant concern by the mid-20th century, as can be seen in wartime works like Fernando Amorsolo’s Burning of the Intendencia, 1944. Post-World War II conservative landscapes would be done by Gabriel Custodio and Martino Abellana. Modernist landscapes first emerged in Post-Impressionist or Fauvist works of Juan Arellano, such as Forest, ca 1913. Arturo Luz’s City, 1959, renders the cityscape as a completely abstracted grid of tan planes and black lines. Federico Aguilar Alcuaz’s panoramic scenes of Manila from the late 1960s to early 1980s visualize the city as a majestic, slightly abstracted vista.

In the 1960s, a group of landscapists, among them Romulo Galicano, Sofronio Y. Mendoza (SYM), TinyNuyda, IbarradelaRosa, Andres Cristobal Cruz, and Emilio Aguilar Cruz, formed the Dimasalang group. They popularized on-the-spot painting to capture the unique spirit of a place, in works generally of impressionist influence. Cebuano artists often excel in landscape due to the influence of Carcar maestro MartinoAbellana. Aside from Galicano and SYM are the brothers Godofredo and Teofilo Mendoza, GamalielSubang, Mardonio Cempron, and others. They have done landscapes of Cebu, old sections of Manila, and urban scenes of barong-barong with their patchwork roof and lines of laundry strung across their windows.

Of the Filipino landscapists abroad, Rome-based LeonPacunayen’s landscapes done in watercolor feature contrasting sharp definitions and atmospheric passages with an expressive interaction of figures in space. MacarioVitalis, residing in northern France, did landscapes of Brittany and the Philippines, of cubist and pointillist influences.

Since the 1960s landscape painting has continued to flourish. Lino Severino came up with his Vanishing Scene series, which focused on turn-of-the-century crumbling houses and landmarks in a monochrome style combining rigorous draftsmanship and tonal nuance. Ibarra de la Rosa’s city landscapes look surreal because of their fantastically vivid colors. The magic realists, such as AgustinGoy, Stevesantos, and NestorLeynes, did landscapes of meticulous detail and striking clarity of form. The landscapes of Elmer Gernale, Al Perez, and RodolfoRagodon have an underlying documentary and illustrative intent.

Later developments in landscape art are the mixed media works on cloth of ManuelRodriguezJr aka Boy Rodriguez, showing lush tropical landscapes of rich detail. ManuelBaldemor has also done landscapes of Paete, with a strong folk and festive spirit. PrudencioLamarrosa introduced the ecological theme in his magical Amburayan landscapes—a theme taken up by JonahmarSalvosa in contrasting works of tropical beauty and decay. Of the printmakers, Fildela Cruz’s landscapes are set in the forests and ancestral lands of the Bagobo and Subanon threatened by logging and landgrabbing. Seascape refers to painting or sculpture of which the sea, ocean, or large body of water is the subject. Often this includes the shore or coastline in the foreground or along one side of the pictorial field. Many artists also like to draw the sea with picturesque and unusual rock formations. Even more than landscapes, seascapes, which show a large view of the sea and the sky, convey a sense of the vastness and the infinity of the universe. The impressionists liked to capture the sunlight sparkling on the water and a sense of the ever-changing atmosphere of the outdoor scene. In a romantic and melancholic mood, Hidalgo did several seascapes titled Marina con Rocas (Sea with Rocks), with the pale moonlight shining on the waters and the rugged shapes of the rocks on the shore. Luna painted the Bahia de Vizcaya (Bay of Biscayne) in predominantly gray tones and a reflective mood.

Still life (French “nature morte” and Italian “natura morta”—that is, dead life) is an artwork, usually a painting, depicting objects—natural or man-made—forming a composition in a natural or domestic setting. Still life speaks about a people and their world and the objects with which they surround themselves. They reveal a society’s sense of beauty, its occupation and everyday concerns, its taste and fashions at a particular time and place. They display the products of a society’s industry during a particular period, such as its level of technology. At the same time, the still life also implies a social class and its manners and mores. While the still life made its appearance in classical antiquity, it was only in the 20th century, with its secular temper, when still life as a contemplation of everyday objects in their sensuous properties became fully accepted as an autonomous art form.

Still life or bodegon painting emerged in the 19th century, primarily through later Academia painters like Paz Paterno, Adelaida Paterno, Miguel Zaragoza, and Emilio Alvero. Following the Dutch Baroque convention, Paterno’s Still Life with Cashewnuts, Macopa, 1885, presents casual arrangement of cashew fruits, macopa, camachile, and melon, beside a vase of red and yellow flowers on a table. Miguel Zaragoza’s illustrations of plant species for Father Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas, 1877, were scientific renditions of plants following the Linnaean convention of the 18th century. Emilio Alvero’s bodegon paintings of the early 1900s followed late Romantic arrangements of fruits and flowers, and served as decor pieces for interior walls, such as those made for the Gen Antonio Bautista House in Malolos. Modernist still-life painters include Vicente Manansala, Hernando Ruiz Ocampo, Arturo Luz, Ang Kiukok, Araceli Dans, and Federico Aguilar Alcuaz. Manansala’s Sinigang (Sour Soup), 1950, strongly followed the Synthetic Cubism of Picasso and Braque. On the other hand, Ocampo’s Fiesta, 1957, displayed his unique synthesis of a nearly abstracted Cubist rendition of fiesta objects centered on a star parol (Christmas lantern). Luz’s Still Life with Bottle, 1953, uses a De Stijl method of rendering objects on a table, albeit still with variations of hues. Kiukok’s Ink Fish, 1964, is an adaptation of the Synthetic Cubist techniques he learned from Manansala, here used to depict a plateful of fish in dark hues. Alcuaz would utilize Synthetic Cubism from the Barcelona La Puñalada Group to render Still Life with Lemons, 1975. Since the 1980s, Araceli Limcaco-Dans has adapted an academic approach taken from Amorsolo and Irineo Miranda to render calado cloth and orchids in various permutations.

Abstract or Non-Objective Painting became dominant since the 1950s, with practitioners like Lyd Arguilla, Hernando Ruiz Ocampo, Fernando Zobel, Jose Joya, Ramon Estella, Victor Oteyza, Arturo Luz, and Lee Aguinaldo; followed in the 1960s onward by Marciano Galang, Florencio Concepcion, J. Elizalde Navarro, Raymundo Albano, Roberto Chabet, Lao Lianben, Augusto Albor, Raul Isidro, Nestor Vinluan, Benjie Cabangis, Roy Veneracion, Lito Carating, Eghai Roxas, and Allan Cosio.

As stylistic distinctions are crucial to establish Modernist reputations, each artist adapts various western Modern styles to suit their own individual body of works. The Neo-Realist group of Arguilla, Romeo Tabuena, Estella, and Oteyza either focused on distorted and Non-Objectivist renditions of folk subjects following the Lyrical Abstraction movement in Europe and early 20th century Cubist-style geometry. H.R. Ocampo’s works from the mid-1950s to the late 1970s utilized a highly cubistic variation of Futurism to depict Non-Objective works with a strong tendency toward warm and earth colors. Fernando Zobel’s abstractions from the 1950s to the 1960s focused on dramatic monochrome sprays on primed canvases using a syringe constituting his Saeta series.

The abstracted works of Arturo Luz from the 1960s to the 2010s may be said to primarily follow the linear style of Paul Klee, enriched with contributions from Hard-Edged Abstraction and Dau al Set. The works of Lee Aguinaldo segued from the Gestural or Action Painting style of Jackson Pollock in the 1950s to the Hard-Edged Abstraction favored by West Coast artists in the 1960s.

Jose Joya’s abstract paintings from the 1950s to 1960s also combined various Abstract Expressionist motifs, such as the boldly flung strokes and drips of Action Painting, and thick impastos formed by spatulas into large planes. In the 1970s to the 1990s, Joya favored a more Lyrical Abstraction style with the careful delineation of planes using handmade paper, often with a red circular element that evoked abstracted landscapes. Florencio Concepcion’s abstractions were inspired from Color-Field painting, such as that by Mark Rothko; while that of Raymundo Albano and Roberto Chabet were an ironic combination of Abstract Expressionism and Minimalism.

In the 1970s to the 2000s, the works of Augusto Albor and Lao Lianben appeared to reference the Lyrical Abstractionism of Europe to evince a more Asian approach to artmaking, with their focus on surface textures, monochrome colors, and controlled gestural strokes. The works of Nestor Vinluan brought Minimalism combined with Abstract Expressionism and Lyrical Abstraction together; while those by Roy Veneracion and Lito Carating demonstrated various permutations of Hard-Edged Abstraction or Color-Field Abstraction. Allan Cosio’s renewed interest in Abstract Expressionism in the 1980s to the 1990s was directed at depicting nature; while Eghai Roxas’s use of Abstract Illusionism since the mid-1990s blurred the distinction between Abstraction and Figuration in his use of shadowed strokes. Benjie Cabangis’s type of abstraction presents layered spaces and surfaces replete with allusions and references.

Folk painting based on expressionist and/or native stylizations could be traced to the naive religious painters of Bohol in the late 18th century. The anatomical distortions turned out by these “untutored” painters evokes a more Southeast Asian sensibility with the use of rotund bodies, sinuous faces, and earthen colors. The icon paintings of Jose Dans in Paete and Juan Senson in Angono during the 19th century also follow this convention, albeit tempered with the use of primary colors derived from natural pigments. The 20th century witnessed an explosion of modern folk painting in the works of Romeo Tabuena, Antonio Austria, Norma Belleza, Abdulmari Imao, Angelito Antonio, Vicente Rivera, and Angono-based or Baguio City-based artists who built upon their art education from UP or UST. The combination of exposure to Modernist aesthetics with the employment of indigenous or ethnic motifs continues to inform much of identity-laden works to date. Specifically, the use of the sarimanok (legendary bird) designs on Imao’s paintings since the 1960s constituted an attempt to modernize his Tausug heritage, even as he continued in the Muslim Minadanaon visual arts tradition of using bold colors and flat but curvilinear patterns derived from okir carving. The use of brilliant color combinations that typify folk art can also be found in the Vendors series of Austria, Belleza, Antonio, and Parial, most of which is taken from the lowland communities of Rizal, as well as mass culture in downtown Manila.

The Forms

Painting can also be studied by focusing on the forms, such as easel painting, murals, telon painting, jeepney and calesa painting, and collage.

Mural (from Latin “muros” or wall) may be classified as any large, wall-sized painting. Murals have a long history, going back to the landscapes and mythological subjects painted on walls of villas in Rome and Pompeii.

In 19th-century Philippines, churches were painted with trompe l’oeil effects reminiscent of Renaissance designs and with religious images copied from estampitas (printed religious images) and exuding Romantic tendencies. The impetus for the proliferation and popularity of the art form was the revivalist spirit characterizing Philippine tastes at this time. But the immediate impetus for such decorations seems to have been the work done by the Italian scenographic artists CesarAlberoni and GiovanniDibella for the SanAgustinChurch in Intramuros in 1875. After that, churches all over the Philippines were decorated with murals. SimonFlores painted church interiors in Pampanga, his best-known work being that in the BetisChurch. In the Visayas, Cebuano painters Canuto Avila and Raymundo Francia were active in the 1930s, painting church interiors in Cebu, Bohol, and Leyte. The art of painting church interiors is still alive as shown in the folksy restorations of churches, such as those in Tayabas, Quezon; Indang, Cavite; and Loay, Bohol. In the last mentioned church, painters from Jagna, Bohol, have replaced older paintings of saints with contemporary ones, such as that of San Lorenzo Ruiz.

Although murals are generally painted as frescoes, a true fresco is hardly found in the Philippines. Church murals found in ceilings have a wood and paint support over which a gesso and glue ground is laid, while those on walls are fresco al seco—meaning, painted on a dry surface.

In the Philippines, during the Marcos regime, the government sponsored the Kulay-Anyo mural project as part of its beautification campaign to boost tourism. Prominent artists were called upon to participate, among them CesarLegaspi, Jose Joya, Arturo Luz, ManuelRodriguezSr, Hernando R. Ocampo, along with some younger artists. Legaspi did a long horizontal mural in Parañaque by the bay; Joya painted an abstract in the midst of a Tondo community; Rodriguez and Luz had theirs in Makati; and H.R. Ocampo had his work in Cubao, but it was covered by a building. Schoolchildren were also given free paints and access to walls.

For the social realists who protested against martial law, murals were favored to convey messages relevant to the social conditions of society and to the urgent issues of the time. Since it was obvious that protest murals risked being effaced, a new mural form gained popularity. This was the portable mural. Large sized and made of several pieces of canvas or cheesecloth, the portable mural became an important visual part of every rally, along with streamers and banners, after which it was rolled up and conveniently stored. The murals, vividly colored and executed in bold strokes, exhorted the public to fight for their rights, honored heroes and sought justice for martyrs, condemned abuses, and asserted workers’ rights. The strong images were underlined by the slogans of the day. After the assassination of Benigno Aquino Jr aka “Ninoy,” a well-known mural that portrayed the faces of Aquino, Macliing Dulag, Dr Johnny Escandor, and Edgar Jopson bore the slogan “Justice for Ninoy, Justice for All.” Another mural was Fight for the People’s Right to Know done by the late socially committed artist Emmanuel Gutierrez. Many murals have been done by fine arts graduates in mass organizations from the Marcos regime up to the present. Often commissioned by nongovernment organizations, the murals are done collectively by a group, such as Artista ng Bayan, although a senior artist supervises it and gives it the finishing touches.

Artists in organizations have done murals in different communities through outreach programs, such as those of the Cultural Center of the Philippines with the cooperation of municipal officials. Public murals have been done in towns, such as Pasig, Pateros, Obando, and Angono. These murals have a strong symbolic aspect as they bring together the cultural symbols of the community to convey nationalist sentiments and awaken the sense of national and community identity. From 1994 to 2000, the artist group Sanggawa (One Work), composed of Elmer Borlongan, Karen Flores, Mark Justiniani, Joy Mallari, and Federico Sievert, engaged in revitalizing mural art through collective work. Among their works is Epilogo (Epilogue), 1998, a mural commissioned for the exhibition Alab ng Puso (Flaming Heart) at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, to commemorate the centennial anniversary of Philippine independence.

Among less-known artists of the cities and towns, the painting of telon backdrops for sarsuwela, plays, carnivals, and photography studios from the 19th to the 20th century was their chief source of income and visual expression. Telon paintings invariably used scenery based on landscape works of the Academia painters. Its modern equivalent throughout the 20th century were the painters of movie billboards, most of whom were from the Caloocan-Malabon area of Manila, such as the Sagmit family in Tondo. Self-taught painters produce marquees and large signage of currently screening or upcoming films. These were done using katsa and hardware paint, and were thus not expected to last. Since the late 1950s, painters based in Manila’s Mabini St area, Angeles City’s Roxas Highway, or Cebu City and Boracay have catered to foreign tourists, hotel decorators, American military personnel, and middle-class buyers who fuelled the market once dominated by the conservative followers of Fernando Amorsolo. The Mabini artists often kept to the subject matter of Amorsolo and his followers, but used a more simplified and slapdash technique that was inexpensive and efficient in producing work in vast numbers. Some Mabini artists, however, also used imported styles like those used in velvet paintings popular in American mass culture, as well as painted metal hammer-out or wood-carved reliefs.

Modes of public transportation from the late 19th to the 21st century have often been rendered in bright painted chassis to attract attention from riders. This began with the horse-drawn calesa, with its wooden-spoked wheels and single-horse carriage brightly painted in primary and secondary colors on a white base. After World War II, motorized jeepney and tricycle bodies were also painted following this calesa convention of using a myriad of painted colors, patterns, and installed motifs that reached baroque proportions of excess during the 1970s.

Jeepney painting grew from the calesa tradition. In fact, one jeepney manufacturer, Sarao, once drove a calesa. Like the calesa, the Sarao jeepney is a broad mass of color bounded by designs. A common border is the rope design and the bamboo design. The hood and the sides of the jeepney are areas of decoration. Usually a painting, logo, or number is painted near the driver’s seat and the seats beside it. More recent airbrushed paintings depict landscapes and scenes from comic books and manga. Spray-painted vignettes mounted on the chassis and applied on interior spaces also became the norm among some jeepney operators since the 1990s.

The task of painting the jeepney is divided between the artisans who lay the ground of color, who paint a picture, and who make the designs. More recent jeepneys, especially those made by Atendido, use more chrome than painting in the tradition of calesa decorative art.

Besides transportation, vendors using hand-pushed carts also painted in folk motifs became predominant. The most famous of these conveyances are the sorbetero homemade ice cream carts from the mid- to the late 20th century, their bodies painted and outfitted with the same lavish care as iconic jeepneys and calesas. Box-shaped, the cart has two decorated spoked wheels like the calesa and a pair of wooden legs at its rear to allow it to stand firmly when at rest. Like the calesa, chrome and paint is used to decorate the cart. Chrome is used for the top and the cover of the cart usually embellished with finials. Paint is used for the sides of the cart designed as a quadrilateral solid. Like the jeepney, broad areas of color are decorated with borders. The name of the ice cream company is usually written on the sides of the cart. The front usually has a landscape, like the Maria Cristina Falls in Lanao del Norte or sunset in Manila Bay.

A contemporary form of painting is the collage, which is a scissor-and-paste method of combining ready-made images by pasting bits of fabric, paper, tin foil, and other relatively flat odds and ends onto a canvas or board. The technique is usually associated with the early work of the cubists around 1918. Braque and Picasso were the first to incorporate real objects, such as pieces of newspaper, into their pictures, the objects acquiring a dual function as themselves and as elements of a picture. Artists use collage to achieve greater variety in color and texture and to expand artistic resources beyond the traditional. Since the original cubists, collage has been employed by artists to create all manners of effects. In this process, photographs, news cuttings, logos, printed texts, and all kinds of materials and objects are pasted onto the painted ground or are combined with passages of simulated texture. The cuttings and objects are sometimes selected for their associative or representational values. Sometimes, interest is primarily in the formal and textural qualities of the work. The use of collage in printmaking has been fairly recent and may have been inspired by the availability of colored tissue, a material flat enough to allow the intaglio plate to print on it.

Among local artists who work with collage are RobertoChabet, Eva Toledo, and Nilo Ilarde. ImeldaCajipe-Endaya uses it extensively in her paintings, using denims, crocheted lace, and sawali panels. Social realist NeilDoloricon uses the logos of transnational corporations.

Paintings still continue to be relevant in contemporary art in the Philippines as artists explore the human condition of the Filipino in the context of revaluating Philippine history and the shifting meanings of images in a transnational setting. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, Jeannie Javelosa, and ReneB. Javellana, updated by Reuben R. Cañete

text:
Paper art is the skillful cutting, pasting, recycling, or constructing of objects from thin sheets of material made of cellulose pulp derived from wood, rags, and grasses.

Among the examples of folk art in paper art are the taka, parol, and pastillas or milk candy wrappers called pabalat. Taka are papier-mâché animals and other figures from Paete, Laguna. In this folk art, figures of horses traditionally predominate, their bodies painted a bright and glossy red, their saddles emblazoned with white, yellow, and blue flowers framed by leaves, scallops, chains, and feather motifs. Aside from horses, there are also carabaos in gray or bright yellow, and dogs. The taka are the epitome of folk art in their bright and affirmative hues in uninhibited combinations, their simplified forms, their profusion of curvilinear and floral motifs, and their naive quality and charm.

The first step in making taka is carving a wooden mold in the desired shape, often in hard and durable narra. This is brushed with a coat of wax. Then wet scraps of paper, as many as 12 layers, are pasted with rice paste on the mold and left to dry. When the paper bulk is dry, it is cut in half, removed, then reassembled with glue, after which it is painted and decorated. In pre-World War II times, powder paint mixed with glue was used for coloring. Now, well-known brands of quick-drying enamel are mixed with gasoline to achieve bright shiny colors.

Taka-making is a year-round activity. The figures are brought to neighboring towns celebrating their fiestas where they add to the gaiety of carnivals. The old women taka makers of Paete trace the origin of the art to the turn of the century. In the household of Sofia Afuang-Afunggol, for example, generations of women keep the folk art alive.

Papier-mâché is also used in the making of the higantes (giant figures) that lead the Angono fiesta procession in November. The Angono higante (giants) are large three-dimensional figures representing humans and carabaos, propped up and carried around town by men hidden inside their hollow structures. They are traditionally composed of bamboo frame bodies covered in cloth, with detachable heads made of papier-mâché. When assembled, they measure anywhere from between 8 and 11 ft in height. Over time, higante makers in the town of Angono, Rizal, have turned to using new materials, such as resin for the head and aluminum for the frame body of these huge puppets.

Traditional higante usually represent folk characters, such as farmers, fisherfolk, and some mythological creatures. Clothes are composed of two or more pieces—a saya (skirt), baro (upper garment), and panleeg (a bib or scarf that covers the part where the head is connected to the frame body). The same costumes are worn by all higante, regardless of whether they represent male or female, landlord or peasant characters. Social classes are distinguished through facial features, such that landlords have stereotypical European features (nose with prominent bridge, rosy cheeks, fair complexion) and are almost always sneering. These are done in reference to the Spanish or mestizo landlords on which the higante were first based in the late 1800s, according to Angono town lore. Higante representing fisherfolk and farmers, on the other hand, are given traditional Filipino features (flat noses, darker skin tone). However, recent higante makers in Angono and Lucban have opted to represent characters from the working class and popular culture. These modern higante are often garbed in uniforms that indicate their respective industries. The characters always feature a comical expression on their faces as these higante are meant to entertain the audience and enhance the festive mood of the occasion.

The higante, according to oral history, are believed to have been used since the 19th century in Angono’s harvest season festivities. The first documented account of the higante is dated to the post-World War II period when Leonardo Tajan Sr created three higante representing a family of farmers around 1945. These were first paraded around town during the annual fiesta of San Clemente on 23 Nov. Other visual artists from the town who became known for producing higante were Carlos Francisco, Nemesio Miranda Jr, Jose Blanco, Charlie Anorico, Perdigon Vocalan, and the Higante Makers and Sculptors Society. Vocalan is credited for initiating the Higantes Festival in 1988, an annual parade of higante held on the eve of the town fiesta as an added attraction to the festivities.

Aside from Angono, the town of Lucban in Quezon province is also known for its long tradition of making higante that are paraded in the streets during the fiesta of San Isidro Labrador every 15 May. The Lucban higante are distinguished by hands that are hanging by the side of their bodies, while the traditional Angono higante usually have their arms akimbo. However, recent production yielded higante with static hands that appear to be doing certain gestures, like waving or blowing a kiss, or holding an object. Other higante are fitted with strings and pulleys that control their arms to perform mechanical actions, allowing them to better interact with the audience. Their sheer size calls the attention of the crowd who are lined up on the street to watch. Bystanders occasionally encourage the higante to sway as if they were dancing, get closer together to kiss, or approach children who, more often than not, cry at the sight of these caricature giants. All these are done in the spirit of fun.

While Angono is renowned for its higante tradition, other towns also feature the giant puppets in their local festivities. Higante are paraded in the streets of Gasan, Marinduque, as part of its religious playlets during the Christmas and Lenten seasons. Beginning in the late 1990s, Miag-ao, Iloilo, and Kalibo, Aklan, also began parading giant effigies they call “higante” in their local festivals. Unlike the ones in Angono and Lucban, these figures adopt themes from pop culture as subject matter and are propped up in floats.

Folk drama uses paper extensively as an ornament. Paper flags and cutouts decorate the raft containing offerings to the spirits used in the Ibanag healing ritual, atang-atang. It is used for the wings of angels and hangings on the galilea in the salubong rite, to decorate the arco (arches) for the pastores of Camalig, Albay, and as decoration for the open-air stages of folk drama.

Parol are Christmas lanterns symbolizing the star of Bethlehem. Their basic design is that of a five-point star. Its bamboo frame is covered with thin and transparent papel de japon (japanese paper); a pair of tails of the same material attached to the star move gently in the wind. Traditionally, the parol was lighted from within, using a kalburo or carbide lamp.

The giant lanterns of San Fernando, Pampanga, particularly of the barangays of Santa Lucia, Del Pilar, San Jose, Dolores, Lourdes, and San Juan, represent the high point of the art of parol making. These lanterns measure from three to six meters in diameter and can weigh a total of 1,000 kilos, with up to 2,000 light bulbs of varying wattage. Each lantern has its own generator.

On Christmas Eve they are brought to the San Fernando plaza for judging. When the bands start to play, the huge lanterns light up like kaleidoscopes. The central star pulsates with the musical beat, while shells, scrolls, golden bells, holly leaves, and trumpetlike flowers flash in alternating movement.

The design, drawn on plywood panels, serves as guide for the cutting and shaping of wires for the structural framework, which consists of two identical faces for both sides. After the elaborate lighting system is installed, the paper is then attached in sculptured layers of varying thicknesses to create subtle tonal effects, each motif of distinct and raised shape set at an angle to the adjacent elements and with transparent areas as part of the general design. Among the master parol makers of San Fernando are Ernesto Quiwa and Mario Datu.

Pabalat or pastillas wrappers, made in San Miguel, Bulacan, are paper cutouts fashioned from thin and transparent papel de japon to serve as wrapping for pastillas, soft confectionery made from carabao milk and fine sugar. In different colors, the paper is wrapped around the candy and twisted at both ends; one end sports a tail about 15.24 cm long, which is cut out in a variety of fine floral designs, often symmetrical. More complex examples may have hut-and-tree or landscape motifs with greetings, such as “Maligayang Pasko” (Merry Christmas) or “Maligayang Kaarawan” (Happy Birthday). Designs like the nipa hut, Maria Clara, man pounding rice grains, and the tinikling dance, are created by Luz Mendoza Ocampo for the pabalat. Traced into the papel de japon, the pattern is cut out using a cuticle scissor.

Kites are also examples of paper art. In the Philippines, they are made of papel de japon in different colors, pasted on a bamboo framework. Colorful paper hats trimmed with gold and silver foil also make an appearance on New Year’s Day, along with toy trumpets and buntings.

A number of contemporary artists also work in the medium of paper. In recent years, handmade paper became popular among printmakers because of its interesting textures and personal appeal. A number of workshops appeared, specializing in the making of handmade paper from different kinds of local grasses and plants, such as cogon and bamboo. Printmakers known for their use of handmade paper are GlennBautista, SantiagoBose, and Petite Calaguas. Paper has also been used by some contemporary artists to do sculpture. ImpyPilapil has made abstract sculpture by serigraphing, then cutting paper to create three dimensional shapes. In Permutation, 1979, pages were cut out, creating spaces in which to see the other pages in the book, thus exploring the translucency of paper as both material and meaning. ManuelRodriguezSr has done monoprints with paper sculpture techniques, including folding and collage. Glenn Bautista has done complex abstract compositions using paper—torn, folded, and pasted with geometric designs. Many collages have been done with plain or printed paper, such as the works of RobertoChabet and Rodriguez Sr, the latter incorporating paper bags, maps, postcards, and school texts in his work. Roderico Daroy has also done collages with reproductions of paintings on aged paper. Romulo Olazo and Ryan Villamael have explored the potential of paper as sculptural work. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Manuel Kristoffer C. Giron and Cecilia S. De La Paz
