text:
As a category of art production, performance art encompasses bodily actions or gestural work that do not fall within, and in many instances seek to challenge, the boundaries intrinsic to more traditionally movement-associated art categories. These categories include dance, music, and theater. A concrete example of the transgressing of these form boundaries is the emergence of poetry performance wherein poets not only count upon the written but spoken word, sometimes alongside the use of props, costume, and gestural and voice nuances that play into the live form as encountered by those present for these readings. Apart from pursuing the desire to explore forms of work that do not conform to what has already become canonical, some performance artists play up the time-based, ephemeral aspect of performance, which to certain degrees keeps their work beyond the reach of market forces that invariably seek objects that might be reduced to monetary and trade value. Particularly in more recent times, performance artists have also done work that crosses over into even less convention-circumscribed domains of art such as relational or community-based work, and art characterized by multimedia aspects, such as video and sound art, as well as installation wherein the movement of bodies of artists/participants navigates or intervenes within a space. In the latter, the core of a work is constituted to provoke action, or to play into the conceptual framing of an open-ended piece as this becomes subject to the contingencies of other minds and bodies shaping or disrupting what an artist may initially have planned to do within the performance site. In this case, the aspect of improvisation or the absence of a prescriptive script is upheld as important to the work.

The earliest accounts of performance art are associated with the work done in the 1960s by the Arts Laboratory loosely made up of such artists as David Medalla, Jun Terra, Lazaro Soriano, Marciano Galang, Alan Rivera, and Red Mansueto, who sought to explore art unbound to the studio, gallery, and other overly familiar and codified art contexts. Their early largely improvisational, action-based practice consisted of a range of work that could be located across a spectrum bookended by the loosely narrative to spontaneous, with form variably described as playful mass dancing to provocative, often participatory actions wherein public intervention is required for the task to progress. In most of these early instances, performances were done unannounced and in public places such as Luneta Park, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) complex open areas, in cafés and other gathering places where artists stationed themselves, or at exhibit openings where performances sometimes constituted uninvited, disruptive gestural-visual-aural interventions amidst otherwise formal and staid events overlaid by rigid social codes of behavior.

Precisely because of its highly fluid and experimental character, performance art can also be taken as displaying an ambivalence toward such notions as time, narrative, the translation of mental to bodily proposition, and thus lately, even the live presence of the artists’ body in performance. Thus, these explorations have consisted of performances that range from lightning or instantaneous, often fleeting actions to those that have required physical endurance on the part of performers doing exaggeratedly durational work that demands sustained or more committed viewing/participation from those witnessing these pieces. Lately too, with the increasingly broad access to digital technology on the net and various telecommunication platforms, artists have sought to “stage” performance in virtual space, no longer counting on the immediacy posed by the interaction of artists and audiences occupying the same physical space.

Just as the nature of performances have run the gamut from the fleeting, like Red Mansueto streaking through the CCP Main Gallery, as well as protracted actions like Rene Aquitania’s five-day hike from the Cordillera to Manila wherein he would also inevitably interact with people walking along his route, other liberties taken with form enable these artists to explore how variable physical and psychological configurations between artist-participants positioned within a space can play into the performance of transient relationships. These permutations, for instance within immersive or confrontational situations, influence the action-response cycle between those who have initiated a performance and those coming to encounter it. In a sense, this dispersing of the position of author or meaning-maker across those who enter a potential zone of participation basically determines how a work or proposed intervention could eventually take shape, and ultimately, how art is thus circumscribed. This is one of the reasons that performance artists have argued that their practice makes for a more democratic encounter of art, although the overall abstract and sometimes overly conceptual nature of their work have also elicited countercharges of audience alienation.

In some cases, performance art as practiced here is also characterized by a liberal poaching from text (which may be literary, historical-mythical, filmic, musical, pop-graphic), which functions as loose structural element of the work. This borrowing and layering over of text unto a work that is still primarily propelled by action has also opened up collaborations between writers interested in performance poetry, drawing upon both Filipino folk/oral literature and concrete poetry as spoken word takes tangible form through the artist’s use of visual and kinesthetic elements, like gesture coupled with aural flourish, dress, and objects that amplify or extend the meaning of a piece. The intersection between performance and sound art also illustrates this tendency to merge forms as the artists see fit. Thus it is no longer extraordinary to find dance artists, both choreographers and dancers, and techno-inclined sound collectives participating in performance art festivals that have been held in the Philippines since the 1990s.

The emergence of performance art as a category has also simultaneously been informed by scholarly and artistic research into performative practice across ethnolinguistic cultures and this in turn has yielded contemporary work that is rooted in ritual and alternately over-the-top and secular-sacred hybrid contexts that demonstrate the cross-genre nature of art coming out of communal events that are usually either propitiatory or celebratory in nature. This blurring of distinctions between what is primal and contemporary, what is art vis-à-vis what constitutes daily life, what is textual against what is visual/performative has given artists the leverage to expand both the vocabulary and syntax of their work.

Emphasis on the conceptual aspect as well as physicality of performance gained momentum in the 1970s in the collaborative work of Huge Bartolome, Judy Freya Sibayan, and Ray Albano whose actions often issued from a bare skeletal script made up of series of instructions, alternately abstract and colloquially poetic. Sibayan elaborates on how privileging process over product propelled them to do work that hoped to defy genres during this period. Parallel to this, on the other hand, was performance borrowing from experimental theater, such as that of Dindo Angeles’s participation in the CCP’s Black and White annual, which eventually led to his being selected by Albano to represent the Philippines at the 1982 Paris Biennale via an image/poetry trilogy in homage to Jose Rizal, Juan Luna, and Zoleta. Angeles would eventually go on to develop the pilot theater curriculum of the Philippine High School for the Arts in Makiling, and it was within this program that young artists groups like Dulaang Sipat Lawin and Anino Shadowplay would take root. Meanwhile, the minimalist aesthetic that informed early forays into performance by artists associated with the CCP continued to run through what has been described as the performance-based conceptual photography of Johnny Manahan whose images of himself playing up to a camera lens amidst incongruous contexts (lying prostrate while laid over with black plastic or blowing smoke circles through the hole of a paper bag upon his head) eventually saw him shifting to video and, eventually, television. Simultaneously during this period, art institutions, such as the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), pursued a short-lived interest in experimental art, which enabled artists to undertake installations and performance under AAP auspices. This may have additionally been fuelled not only by third-hand encounters with international avant-garde practice but also by lightning actions carried out by artist-activists mobilizing across the streets of the metropolis. For instance, a bound and shirtless Nunelucio Alvarado walked into Ayala Museum, entreating those present to participate in his unfettering.

The mid-1980s also gave rise to unannounced collaborative actions in public sites by artists, such as Soliman Cruz, Joey Macalino, and Ronnie Lazaro who enacted scenes of surveillance and militarization that could loosely be construed as precursor for the more complex collaborations later done by artists, such as those done by Jean Marie Syjuco in the early 1990s. It was in this decade that she began staging more theatrically elaborate and thematic work in places like Luneta, Quiapo, Kulay Diwa, and Penguin, the latter site specifically for a surrealist take on the phenomenon of Filipina workers being globally trafficked. Syjuco would team up with a long queue of artist-collaborators, such as Jose Legaspi, Hermisanto, Rene Aquitania, Alwin Reamillo, for the seminal Puting Uwak (White Crow) done in 1992 at the CCP Little Theater, the work particularly remembered for its grandiose projection within the still underwritten art historical narrative as well as for the inverted emplacement of audience members made to sit atop the stage as performers were positioned in the viewing section of the theater. Video documentation of Syjuco’s work shown in schools would eventually yield experimentation by a still younger set of artists who began working together in the 1990s underperformance art festival platforms, like the Philippine International Performance Art Festival and the TUPADA Action and Media Art. This streak of independent activity would run parallel to work turned out from artist-run spaces, such as Surrounded by Water (e.g., Alice and Lucinda) and Third Space under the instigation of the filmmaker-curator Yason Banal who, among other young artists, took advantage of workshops done at the Syjucos’ ART LAB, the same site that saw a brief mentorship bloom between Jose Legaspi and Vim Nadera. This overall more eclectic strain of practice encompassed performances ranging from the primarily gestural, amalgamations of neo-expressionist, surreal and Dadaist tropes, and a deliberate shift to a mode of spectacle-making the scale of which thrust practice unto heightened degrees of campy theatricalization and collaboration. Examples of the latter were ambitious all-evening improvisational performances in mainstream sites, such as at the Ayala Museum (Post curated by Jet Melencio) and the CCP (Kaka curated by Banal). This period to the present has also seen parallel development in diasporic communities, such as those done by individuals as well as groups like the now Canada-based Roy Lumagbas, United States-based Carlos Villa, Diwa Arts, Barriotics, and, more currently, Mail Order Bride made up of Jenifer Wofford, Reanne Estrada, and Eliza Barrios. It was also in the 1990s extending to the next decade when Jose Legaspi explored collaborative work with the multiethnic Godzilla West in California, while the then France-based Sandra Palomar and Gaston Damag would eventually team up to manage the artist-support site Sanlikha: Maison des Artistes Philippins.

This multiplicity of sites of practice as well as in originating impulses (from extensions of theater and/or visual art practice to the pursuit of transmedia work) similarly informs the emergence of performative work outside Manila as core sites could be drawn across the regions: Angono via the Neo-Angono Public Art Festivals; Baguio via the Baguio International Arts Festivals; Cebu initially via the school-based event Mind Works initiated by Javy Villacin, Roy Lumagbas, and Raymund Fernandez at University of the Philippines Cebu, morphing into the latter XO? street actions with younger artists, such as Russ Ligtas; and Davao-based anarchist-inspired actions organized by Fritz Balgos who gravitated around the same circles as Jong Pairez who in turn crafted the Tasaday cyber persona Jean Makisig released into the sphere of viral multi-authorship. This Pairez work thus now stands as an early indicator of interest in the performative mode of identity-formation made possible through virtual platforms.

Some strains of performance play up the artists’ embodied capacity to enact a persona. Some recurring characters, for instance, were Alan Rivera’s Non, Jose Tence Ruiz’s bandaged up man and puppet, Pepito Bosch’s Abaca Man, Jess Abejo’s Tree Man, John Frank Sabado’s Eco-warrior, Jose Legaspi’s White Man, Jef Carnay’s Queen, Jeho Bitancor’s Man-in-suit, the guitar-wielding Marlon Magbanua, comic superhero Thom Daquiaog, Sam Peñaso’s Mourner, Sandra Palomar’s Red Crow, Noel Cuizon’s Sojourner, and the Butoh-inflected figures of Martin de Mesa and Ligtas. The flexibility in form and relationship to such theatrical notions as character, narrative, staging, dramaturgy, movement, and site/space for action remain largely unbound by stringent parameters. This free-for-all climate has predictably engendered criticism particularly in regard to the lack of concern for form and resistance to evaluative criteria. Nevertheless, a desire to draw upon an essentially inclusive or total art context where loose codes of performances are drawn from inferred communal negotiation rather than inflexible aesthetic constraints could be gleaned from the work of Roberto, Ben-hur, and Bumbo Villanueva, Yuan Mor’o Ocampo, Hermisanto, Diokno Pasilan, as well as in the parodied shamanistic reference in the work of Santiago Bose and those who have further explored parallel performative modes through Bose, as was the case with Baguio-based Karlo Altomonte and Cagayan de Oro-based Nick Aca. Latent babaylan (shaman) references in the work of Raquel de Loyola, Alma Quinto, and Josephine Turalba register in this shamanistic vein as well. Analogous enactments of folk tropes have come in the form of the taho/balut (soft tofu/unhatched duck egg) vendor of Alwin Reamillo, rogger basco’s hermetic wiseman, and the penitent Rommel Espinosa. Still another recurring theme that cuts across the bodies of work of several artists includes critical commentary on globalization as seen in pieces by Mideo Cruz, Ronald Ruiz, Jevijoe Vitug, Arnel Ramiscal, Bitancor, UGATLahi, Boyet de Mesa, this alongside pieces directed at issues of gender and body politics in the work of Roselle Pineda, Bunch Garcia, Maki Calilung, Kaye O’yek, Ceej Gomera, and Christine Sioco.

The apparent catchall disposition of performative work has even further opened up the field to more diverse syntheses of seemingly disjunctive forms. This liberal criss-crossing has enabled intersections across performance and domains, such as dance, theater, sound and media art production, thus Fete dela WSK annual improvisatory sound and image festivals have morphed into a miscellany of collaborations between artists, such as E.X.I.S.T., the Gangan Ensemble (made up of Tad Ermitaño, Caliph, Malek Lopez, and Tengal Drilon), Jing Garcia/Autoceremony, Eric Calilan, Gentle Universe, Mannet Villariba, and the Sipat Lawin Ensemble.

Another pertinent discursive point that has influenced practice done over the history of performance art is how the performative mode propels a dialogic process between artists and publics. Reamillo, who previously taught at the Makiling High School for the Arts, explicitly identifies this track in his work as something he traces both to a received Situationist lineage, a Beuysian notion about social sculpture, and the natural affinities between installation art and process-based art. His work with various groups to craft a whale car and the transformation of a disused chopper into peace icon demonstrate this. There are parallels here too in the work of the artist couple Isabel and Alfredo Aquilizan who have positioned their early pieces as performance installations particularly in regard to how the accumulation of objects that eventually constitute the key elements of their installations, establishing a fleeting relationship with source communities. As in the case of installation, site and social context of a performance work may prominently play into how a performance might be devised as well as determine its capacity to initiate interaction. Such was the case in the ritual dismantling of Roberto Villanueva’s Uma ti Biag (Garden of Life) at the CCP lawn, a site also later used for Junyee’s Angud upon which members of the CCP dance corps interacted spatially, maneuvering across the stumps of trees the artist had strewn across the front lawn, in front of the prominent facade. Another example of this is how Lyra Garcellano embodied the owning and sharing of territory in the performance-installation Free Land done through the digging up, packing, and sharing of soil among those present at a juncture in her residency in Yogyakarta, Indonesia.

As previously mentioned, constituting digital media as yet another performance platform not only comes with the potentials of multiplicity in authorship but also an opening up of the reception and circulation contexts of art, particularly in relation to the viral potential of hypertextuality or the webbed associations enabled by networked information in cyberspace. Most recently, Sibayan’s Hypertext of Her(Mes) explored this track in her autobiographical accounting of a practice spanning her engagement and disengagement with art world institutions, posing her post-CCP phase as institutional critique. Written byEileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources

Legaspi-Ramirez, Eileen. 2011. “For the Record: For the Record: Agency and the Crafting of Discourse around Performance Art from the Philippines.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Sibayan, Judy Freya. 2011. “Braided Voices and Parallel Scripts: Discursive Construction of the Autobiographical Subject.” http://www.ctrlp-artjournal.org/dissertation/The-Discursively-Constructed-Constructing-Subject.pdf. 29 Mar.

text:
The use of personal ornaments is a common but diverse practice in the Philippines. It has had a long existence, the earliest evidence of which dates back to prehistoric times, long before the arrival of the Spanish colonizers. It takes various forms, which generally relate to degrees of engagement with the body as either permanent or temporary appendage. One permanent form of adornment is tattooing. The practice was documented by early observers among so-called pintados (painted ones) in the Visayas. Temporary forms, on the other hand, are illustrated by the practices of Samal and Yakan peoples living in southern Philippines. They paint their faces with rice paste during important occasions, such as weddings. The more known types of adornment, however, are realized through the putting on of objects, which may be worn or taken off at will. They are often seen as adjuncts to dress, but are generally distinct from them. The ornaments are worn on different parts of the human body, and while generally seen as decorative, may also bear other cultural meanings. Philippine languages have particular names for many of these ornaments, but whether made of ephemeral or more permanent materials, these constitute a category that may be thought of as jewelry. Filipino terms, such as hiyas (jewel or jewelry), alahas (from the Spanish alhajar, “to adorn with jewels”), and aretes (from the Spanish aretes, “earrings”), are used in reference to jewelry.

Background

Jewelry constitutes some of the most important Philippine artifacts found in ancient grave sitescontaining human fossils and grave furniture. The oldest jewelrywere found in Duyong Cave, Palawan (C-14 dated to 2680 BCE). It is in this site where a tall muscular male was found with two shell discs near his ears and another perforated disc made from cone shell (Conus litteratus) near his chest. It is uncertain whether these types were specifically used for funeral purposes, but evidence indicates that shells were a common raw material in the fabrication of ornaments used in everyday contexts. Apart from shells, organic and inorganic materials sourced locally or from outside the Philippines were also incorporated in early jewelry. Extant examples of ornaments have been found to use materials from West Asia, India, China, and Southeast Asia. To a certain degree, existing personal ornaments used by various ethnolinguistic groups may give valuable insights into the study of early jewelry.

Early Filipinos clearly had particular preferences for types of personal ornaments and the technology for procuring and fashioning them. Certain parts of the Philippines, for example, had abundant amounts of gold,found either in raw or wrought state. These were used in both local exchange and international trade. The Surigao hoard, dating from the 10th century onward, shows a wide variety of techniques and designs used for gold ornaments.

These ways of working gold, done by the skilled panday-ginto (goldsmith), continued until the Spanish period, but also became enriched by inputs from Asian and European jewel makers who introduced innovations in the repertoire of existing designs and technologies. Soon the delicate and laborious art of filigree, chasing, engraving, and casting were set aside in favor of modern styles. However, in Batanes and Paracale, Camarines Norte, goldsmiths continue to create jewelry using the traditional techniques of filigree and granulation. Ely Arcilla continued the tradition in Paracale, creating the styles of agrimon (flat necklace chain) and tamburin (filigree bead necklace) coming from the 18th and 19th centuries. There are other centers of jewelry smithing in the Philippines that have thrived. Baguio City, being rich in silver, is famous for its silver filigree. Meycauayan town in Bulacan province is another jewelry center where a platero (jeweler) can still be found in many households.

By the mid-18th century, certain districts, like Santa Cruz in Manila, came to be associated with excellent jewelry crafting. Platerias Street in the Quiapo area, near the bridge, was a place where jewelers converged. In the mid-19th century, the plateros were renowned in the craft. The town of Lipa, Batangas, in the 19th century had excellent goldsmiths whose skills were comparable to European artisans of the same period. Gorgeous diamond-studded crosses and ornaments were commonly produced in these sites. The famous coffee boom of Batangas resulted in the ostentatious display of Batangueño jewelry. Emerald-encrusted peinetas (ornamental combs), elaborate 18-carat gold chains, huge diamond rings, diamond-studded slippers, gold-covered front teeth, and three-carat diamond studs for the barong tagalogwere just some of the objects associated with the economic elite.

American colonization at the turn of the century brought a change of style in jewelry that was more streamlined. Diamonds came into vogue and goldwork was merely used as setting for precious gems. Emphasis shifted to stone. This led to the deterioration of the goldsmith’s art. This shift in stylistic preferences was also accompanied by changes in the marketing of jewelry. Previously, jewelry would be commissioned or sold by jewelers via an expanded network of relations and friends. But by the turn of the 20th century, jewelry became regular items of trade in shops. Jewelry was sold in shops in the Escolta area, which became the main commercial center during the American period. La Estrella del Norte, owned by the French-Jewish brothers Adolphe, Charles, and Raphael Levy, grew from the sale of five crates of religious medals, statues, and gold chains, which the brothers brought from San Francisco, to become the most famous jewelry store in the Philippines. Their original store was established in Iloilo. Another firm engaged in the jewelry trade was H. E. Heacock, who specialized in men’s watches and chains, and collar and cuff buttons directed at American ex-soldiers, businessmen, and Manila’s elite. It evolved into a full-blown department store in the 1930s. These stores made available not only locally crafted jewelry but also imported goods, such as branded wrist and pocket watches.

Manila and, more recently, Makati are now the trendsetters in jewelry. While modern Western designs are popular, there is also increasing interest in reinterpreting traditional ethnic and colonial designs. The work of Celia Molano, for example, illustrates this trend. Moreover, there are also noted specialty shops for jewelry. The Ocampos, Panlilios, and Velayos have been in the business for a long time. Their ateliers, together with newer shops, such as Miladay’s, La Czarina, or Orocher, continue to set directions for jewelry creations in the country. Young Filipino designers, such as Bea Valdes, Jul B. Dizon, Ericson Manansala, and Cherrie Marie de Guzman, are also making names for themselves in the world of fine jewelry, both here and abroad. The industry has also tried to enlarge its market by offering a range of products for various types of consumers—silver jewelry and costume jewelry are relatively within reach by people of all genders, ages, and persuasions.

Materials, Processes, Techniques

Personal ornaments are made using various types of organic and inorganic materials. Organic materials are mostly from plants (flowers, seeds, cotton fibers, bamboo, palms, vines, coconut shell, wood) and animals (shell, coral, pearl, tortoiseshell, bone, animal teeth, hornbill, ivory, human and horsehair, feathers) while inorganic materials include stone, glass, ceramic, metal and plastic. Processes of working with these different materials varied, and could range from simple stringing of pre-manufactured beads, to more complex filigree work.

Organic. Shell ornaments are said to be as long-lasting as diamonds. Prehistoric Filipinos used shell ornaments at least 5,000-7,000 years ago during the New Stone Age or Neolithic Period, as evidenced by the Duyong Cave artifacts mentioned earlier. Shell discs fashioned into beads were common ornaments during the late Neolithic age. For instance, prehistoric Filipinos were able to produce beads by grinding off the dorsal surfaces of two species of shell, the ringed cowrie (Cypraea annulus) and the money cowrie (Cypraea moneta). Another shell species, the nassarius or sand snail (Nassarius spp), was also used to make beads. Shell bracelets have also been found in late Neolithic excavations. One example is a type of bracelet cut from the base of the cone shell. Broader, spiral bracelets are made from the natural spiral along the shell’s shoulders, creating a natural design. Spiral bracelets may either be concave or convex. The Ifugao ginut-tu, a belt created from perforated-shell discs, is worn only by the nobility or the kadangyan class during festivities. The Ifugao kilaong or ear pendants suspended from metal rings are fashioned from the chambered nautilus shell (Nautilus pompilius). In Palawan and Samar, indigenous groups produce their own shell bracelet, called galang, ground from giant clams (Tridacna gigas) and cone shells. Even among contemporary ethnolinguistic communities,shell ornaments are still widely used.

Inorganic. Stones were used as jewelry as far back as 2000 BCE. These ancient stone ornaments were developed in Philippine prehistory during the Neolithic stage, the same period when polished stone tools were also used in agriculture. From at least 500 BCE, “true jade” or nephrite was also used as material for working tools. Apparently, jade was highly valued then for its technological and artistic qualities. Nephrite was used by ancient Filipinos for jewelry: beads, ear pendants, and bracelets. Since the Philippines is geologically young, geological deposits have yet to yield precious gems, such as diamonds, rubies, sapphires, emeralds or aquamarines. But at least 22 types of native semiprecious stones have been unearthed, among them amethyst, opal, garnet, and obsidian. The integration of precious or semiprecious stones into personal ornaments continues to form part of the practice of many contemporary Philippine jewelers.

The use of glass, usually in the form of beads, may also be traced to ancient times. Most of the beads recovered from archaeological sites are glass beads. The earliest glass beads found in the country were undoubtedly imported. Recovered from Uyaw Cave, Palawan, dating to 500-200 BCE, is a large green glass bead shaped like a cicada, closely resembling similar Chinese jade carvings of approximately the same period. In the mid-15th century, the Pandanan shipwreck in Palawan yielded thousands of imported Indo-Pacific glass beads, many of which are believed to have been sourced from Sungai Mas, Malaysia. Despite the access to imported glass beads, evidence however also indicates familiarity with bead-making processes—shaping through abrasive processes, drilling, boring, etching, application with gold foil—which could have been used for both local and imported beads.

Among traditional Philippine ethnolinguistic groups, beads also form a large part of the materials used for personal adornment. In the north, among the Bontok and the Ifugao, the rarest and most highly priced heirloom bead is the pang-aw, a cylindrical bead with gold leaf embedded between layers of clear glass. Small, round, or cylindrical monochrome glass beads, generally termed batek, are common in Bontoc province. These may be lang-at (red), impokon (white), fa-king-i (yellow), and gu-sao (black). Orange glass beads are also common. Several strands of these beads are worn around the head, or strung into bracelets or armlets. In the south, a significant number of glass eye beads among the Tboli and other Mindanao tribes probably came from “British Borneo” since most eye beads found among highlanders of Borneo and Indonesia were from England, manufactured for trade during the 19th century. During the latter part of the Spanish period, abaloryo (from the Spanish abalorio, “bead,” “glass bead,” “trinket”) or fine glass beads intended for embellishing garments and objects like slippers and purses, became widely used as inexpensive body ornaments and rosaries for the masses. In contemporary bead making, old as well as new beads may be used. Beads made from modern materials, such as plastics and synthetic crystals, are also common accessories both in everyday fashion and in haute couture.

Among the metals, gold has played a consistently significant role in personal ornamentation. Ancient Philippine gold was gintong pula or in shades of red-yellow. Several varieties were dilaw (yellow) from a mix of equal amounts of silver and copper; mapula (pink), mixed only with copper; and berde (green), mixed only with silver. Gold from local deposits was fashioned into combs, hairpins, earrings, weapon handles, eye masks for the dead, as well as images of anitos. Archaeological artifacts prove that ancient Filipinos were great goldsmiths. Excellent gold jewelry by ancient Filipino artisans exhibit expertise in the art of filigree and granulation in earrings, necklaces, wristbands, and bracelets. The height of ancient Filipino gold artistry unparalleled elsewhere in the world is perhaps exhibited by the gold sashes found in Surigao. The sophisticated method used in the magnificent sashes was the gold-weaving method that utilized the “loop-in-loop technique.” Vigan and Bantay, Ilocos Sur, became the centers of gold jewelry in Luzon for most of the Spanish colonial period. The town of Bantay was engaged in the manufacture of filigree jewelry or lacelike calado (openwork) in gold and silver, which are techniques that continue to be in use. Apart from gold, personal ornaments have also been produced using silver, brass, copper, or bronze, sourced from mines or pre-used metals, such as coins or bullets. More recently, metals like aluminum and stainless steel have also been utilized. Additional processes of working with metals also include casting, repoussé and chasing, engraving, die-stamping, inlaying, soldering and gilding. The Tboli, for example, cast brass bells that were then attached to necklaces, belts, and anklets.

Form, Content, and Function

Jewelry making belongs to the expressive and applied arts contextualized within tradition and a discipline of styles. The Philippine jewelry tradition is characterized by the dominance of symmetry and formal proportion, a strong sense of rhythm, and a distinctive rather than specific emphasis. The importance of surface textures has also received critical attention. Sizes are either oversized or minute. There is also a predominance of primary hues, achieved through use of a variety of tones associated with stone and glass beads, and the natural color of metals, especially gold. The curve is a prevailing motif combined with basic forms—the square, triangle, ellipse, and circle. On occasion, there are stylized animal or human forms.

Ancient jewelry, for example, covers a wide spectrum of forms. For example, the circle may be seen during the Spanish period in a variety of permutations—as plain or textured gold globules for necklaces, as flattened mother-of-pearl discs for pectorals, or as nephrite lobed annular ear pendants. Representational shapes, on the other hand, may be evidenced by “death masks” consisting of gold sheets, rendered either for the entire face or as separate pieces for eyes, nose, and mouth. In the traditions of many ethnolinguistic groups, there may also be observed a preference for colorful jewelry. Beads of variegated colors are used in almost all types of body ornamentation among the Cordillera and southern Mindanao groups. Red, yellow, black, and opaque white predominate this palette. While motifs are generally geometric and nonfigurative, images may be suggested by the materials used—a bird, from its bill; a snake, from its skeleton; a crocodile, from its teeth.

Christianization also brought in Catholic motifs, such as the cross; while religious images also appear in pendants, reliquaries, and scapulars. The cross was a symbol essential to the Christian faith. The earliest design of the cross ornament was the krus na baligtad, a cross functionally inverted so that when worn as a pendant, it would be right side up when one prayed. Its eclectic blend of style and technique was typical of Philippine jewelry tradition. The oldest were those in which the Christ figure was more hieratic, with the elements radiating from the figure. The figureless cross was sometimes used to symbolize the risen Christ. The veneration of saints was reflected in the religious figurines of jeweled or enameled gold—the reliquaries, rosaries, scapulars, and medals with the images of Christ, the Virgin, and the saints. The tamburin became an ornamental form of rosary. Also hanging from the gold bead necklaces were the so-called agnus dei or relicario pendants with a detached openwork panel using a lamb, cross, chalice, or monstrance design.

The various insurrections and the Philippine Revolution also engendered a distinct iconography as seen inunique military and masonic insignias and amulets. Shapes such as triangles, sunbursts, stars, ovals, crossed swords, and guns, for example, were incorporated with symbols of the Katipunan and worn on the uniforms of the revolutionaries. As the Philippines remained essentially Catholic, Christian motifs continued to be used. Increased secularization during the American period, however, expanded the range of motifs to choose from, and designs of a nonreligious nature, consisting mostly of plant and floral forms, which could be rendered naturalistically or in more stylized fashion, gained added attention. Precious and semiprecious stones were mounted on gold settings, which established the overall shape of the pieces. This entire repertoire of designs from different periods in Philippine history in fact resonates even in contemporary pieces. Yet, in modern and contemporary jewelry, a challenge to this aesthetic language is attempted through more asymmetrical arrangements, a much more expanded palette, and experiments with rectilinear and angular compositions. The jewelry of Eduardo Castrillo, for example, typifies this trajectory.

While personal ornaments are generally understood to adorn the bodies of its wearers, they have other “associative” meanings, which could actually be essential to these objects’ “beautifying” properties. In the ancient past, such ornaments were believed to have magical functions, being used as protective amulets against evil spirits or as charms to ensure fertility. The form of the lingling-o, for example, which dates to the pre-Hispanic period, survives today among cultures in northern Luzon. It is believed to have protective and healing powers, and is also acknowledged as a symbol of fertility. In the tourist market of the Cordilleras, it is advertised as a good luck charm. The ancient funerary gold masks from Oton (in Iloilo) are also theorized as having protective properties for the dead. These gold sheets covering human orifices are believed to prevent evil spirits from entering the body. Even ancient Filipinos could not deny its significance; in death, certain ornaments were expressly meant to be worn. The Christianization of the islands did not remove jewelry’s association with protection. Jewelry continued to function as a potent object to keep its wearer safe. Parents would pin medallions on babies and young children to protect them from danger, from an “evil eye,” and from usog (distress caused by strangers). The Saint Benedict medal, known since European medieval times for its “devil-chasing” properties, was especially popular for this purpose. Adults, on the other hand, would wear rosaries or scapulars. While the scapular is less worn today, the rosary continues to be used widely—ring, bracelet, and wristband rosaries have become quite accessible, serving both as amulet and talisman. This magic-like quality attached to religious objects is also attributed to anting-anting, a term for various types of amulets, which could give its wearers a range of possible powers, such as superhuman strength, invisibilty, or self-healing capabilities. Near the Quiapo Church in Manila, several types of anting-anting are being sold. Many of them incorporate esoteric elements drawn from Christian and masonic texts and iconography. Muslims have also their own versions of these amulets.

Many personal ornaments also function in the social sphere as prestige objects, signifying rank, status, and wealth. The lingling-o mentioned earlier also functions as a marker of status. The anthropomorphic jars from Ayub Cave (in Maitum, Sarangani Province) used in secondary burials are also possible clues to the importance of jewelry as prestige markers. These jars were found in an assemblage, which included glass beads, bracelets and pendants. The jars themselves had lids composed of the head and upper part of the chest (much like sculptural busts). The representation of the earlobes is interesting: some are like simple curled loops or rings attached to the side of the face, while in others, the lobes appear to jut out from the side of the face. When perforated, they might have represented large earrings, or perhaps the distension from ear plugs. Large or plugged earrings were types of jewelry associated with elite classes in some traditional Philippine societies.

During the Spanish period, the possession of religious jewelry in the form of reliquaries or scapulars, would point to the wealth and status of its owners. These ornaments were not only used as religious paraphernalia but also served political interests. The cross was a badge of pragmatic import, a password to economic, political, and social mobility in colonial society. Even in decidedly secular contexts, accessories to clothing marked differences among classes of people. Elite women wore ornaments such as combs, hairpins, chains, necklaces, tamburin necklaces with pendant medallions, earrings, rings, bracelets, brooches, and pins. The men wore gold ornaments in the form of finials for their salakot, cuff links, handles for walking canes and riding crops, and saddle decorations used during official and social functions. The fashion of the period permitted the simultaneous use of all these types of jewelry. The ladies used peinetas, gold sheets embossed, chased, or engraved, and riveted onto silver combs. Even more elaborate were combs of gold filigree, which were sometimes set with pearls or corals, diamonds and other stones. Hairpins, called pantoche or tusok, were of various shapes; they had floral designs in filigree or in chased and engraved gold, with dangling gold beads and movable parts.

Ornaments also marked ritualistic and emotional states, like happiness, mourning, triumph, celebration, and solemnity. The Ilongot, for example, could wear red hornbill earrings only if he had captured a head. The Bontok and the Ifugao, on the other hand, wore boar-tusk necklaces and armlets on the biceps after every successful war expedition.

To wear ornaments is to draw attention to the parts of the body where they are worn. But apart from an awareness of the physical attributes to which ornaments are attached, meanings may also be heightened. A necklace could reference one’s social rank; an earring, a young man’s acceptance into the world of adult men. Ornaments may also be metaphor for the powers residing in the body—the head for thought, the chest for feeling, the limbs for strength and action.

Ornamentation and the Body

Three major areas may constitute the surfaces, so to speak, on which jewelry may be applied: (1) the head and neck, (2) the upper body, and (3) the lower body.

Types of ornaments for the head and neck include headdresses, earrings, ear pendants, ear plugs, necklaces and pendants. For example, among the Bagobo and Tboli, huge earrings, 9.8 cm in diameter, signified high status among males. There are four basic types of earrings among the ethnic tribes: the plug, the chandelier, the graduated ring series, and the ear-with-bib combination. Blaan plug earrings have a piece of mirror glass framed by tiny beads while the Kalinga wear them with front ends covered with embroidered cloth, coins, or glass bits. Chandelier earrings usually consist of long tassels of beads threaded on horsehair, but among the poor Batak, they are made of tufts of wild cotton or bundles of grass. The kawat of graduated rings may be worn only if the wearer’s ears were pierced seven to eight times from top to lobe in which brass hoops are attached, the smallest at the top and the largest at the bottom. The kowol or bib earring is common among southern Philippine communities, like the Bagobo, Ubo, Tboli, and Blaan. An elaborate four-inch-deep bib made of lace, beads, glass, or metal teardrop pendants connects the two earrings and frames the face under the chin. The alluring bib catches light or quivers as the wearer smiles or speaks. During the Spanish period, earrings known as criollas, referencing the hoop earrings from the Caribbean, became quite popular. Ear pendants may be seen in the lingling-o, which may be described as a basic ring with bud-like projections on the edge of the ornament in each quarter. The jade double-headed pendant is a distinct type of lingling-o, similar to stone amulets found in the Middle East. In fact, the lingling-o finds similar forms in many parts of the world, such as India and Southeast Asia, and is believed by some to be of foreign origin.

There are also numerous types of necklaces. The Isneg menghal or warrior used to wear elaborate necklaces of capiz-shell discs to signify head-hunting feats. The Ifugao pangalapang, made of trapezoidal mother-of-pearl pieces, was worn by both males and females as a status symbol. The Tboli wore a large variety of body jewelry, among them brilliant inch-thick chokers with geometric designs, convinced as they were that an attractive appearance pleased the gods. The Mansaka had prized necklaces, called balliug, a string of beads dangling to the waist containing carnelians and crocodile teeth. The most outstanding pieces of jewelry produced by Ilocano artisans were the necklaces in varied forms, the tamburin being the most popular. Chains started out as ordinary gold links and progressed into chains of braided gold wire, ropelike chains of varied forms, intricate vertebrae necklaces, square link-chains with tiny flower decorations, and the alakdan or scorpion necklace. These were used together with pendants. Most symbolic of the pride and power of the elite was the alpahor (from the Spanish alfajor, a type of round flat cookie), a double-linked flat necklace. Goldsmiths strove to outdo each other in embellishing not only the fronts but also the reverse sides of the medallions.

Jewelry for the upper body consists of shoulder bands, pectorals, arm bands, armlets, bracelets, wrist bands, wrist clasps, and rings. Perhaps one of the most remarkable pieces of precolonial jewelry is the almost four-kilo gold sash from the Surigao hoard. It is said to be an upavita, or “sacred thread,” used traditionally among the Hindus to mark their “twice-born” state, but certainly used in the Philippines to mark elite status. Among ethnolinguistic groups, the Bagobo have their “musical” jewelry exemplified by hollow brass bracelets containing little bells. Some bracelets were used as charms; the sagay sagay of the Manobo and Mansaka were made of black coral from shark-infested waters, worn to provide warning of imminent danger to the wearer. The Mandaya are unique in having pectorals, large silver disks pinned to the chest area, as part of female finery. During pre-Spanish times, gold rings were used for barter. But they were also used as symbols of power and royalty, and served as amulets. Some rings were engraved with ancient Malay script or bore stylized representations associated with fertility and good fortune. With western culture came the popularity of rings, which were used in betrothals and marriages. Much later, more fashionable types were introduced, such as the lansadera, so-called because it resembled the shape of the shuttle (lanzadera) used in weaving.

Lower body ornaments consisted of different types of waistbands and belts, buckles, knee and leg bands, leglets and anklets. Archaeological excavations have yielded many precolonial belts and waistbands in chainwork or hammered gold. No belts of this type have been found anywhere else in the world. Among traditional communities, belts are also significant. They may be used to hold weapons or betel nut containers, and may also be indicators of rank. Among the Aeta, finely woven strands of behuco (from the Spanish bejuco, “liana,” a type of woody vine) were worn as leglets so that the wearer could have a wild boar’s strength, stamina, and speed.

The numerous types of personal ornaments indicate the importance of adornment in Philippine culture. It is an art form that serves as extensions of the body and, as such, serves to reference aspects of its wearer. Personal ornaments define physical attributes, index affiliation in a community, emphasize sexual distinctions, and imply power relations. It is an art form well ingrained in the fabric of everyday life. The objects are used in exuberant moments of celebration, as well as in the throes of grief. Written byRosalie Matilac, Jeannie Javelosa, and Marilyn R. Canta
