text:
Photography (from the Greek phos and graphein or “writing”) is the art or process of producing images through the use of a light-sensitive chemical on a plate or film.

Early History

The oldest extant photograph was taken in 1827 by French inventor Joseph Nicephore Niepce. An image of a barn and a bakery seen through the window of his study, it was set on a pewter plate covered with a solution of white petroleum and pulverized bitumen of Judea (a type of asphalt). The image was formed eight hours after exposure to sunlight trapped inside a camera (from the Greek kamera or “vault”).

From 1829 until his death in 1833, Niepce partly collaborated with his rival, painter Jacques Louis Daguerre. In 1837, Daguerre made his first successful photographs of views of his studio showing a relief sculpture. The French government bought his invention in 1839, after which Daguerre made public his experiments for making daguerreotypes. He used iodine vapor to make a silver-plated copper sheet light-sensitive. After exposure in a camera, the plate was treated with mercury vapor to bring out the picture, which was fixed in place by a salt solution.

Contemporary cameras began with the camera obscura, an instrument described by Leonardo da Vinci in the 15th century as rooted in optical principles known to Arabian astronomers in the year 1000. By the 1700s, the camera obscura’s darkened room or chamber had been changed to a box that had a lens on one side through which light could enter. When illuminated, this would project an image upside-down on a surface. The camera obscura helped artists make accurate drawings by allowing them to trace the projected picture on paper.

Over the centuries, photo-sensitive glass plates, gelatin-coated paper sheets sensitized by bromide, and flexible roll film made from celluloid were invented to make positive and negative permanent images. Gold paint and powders were applied by hand to color sepia prints. The first effective color film, Kodachrome, was introduced in 1935.

The Eastman box camera of 1888 and the first small handheld camera, made by the Leitz Company of Germany in 1925, improved the clarity of photographs and made photography more practical. Cameras currently use photocells to measure exposure time, infrared beams to focus automatically, and silicon chips to provide computerized functions.

Photography was first mentioned in literature from the Philippines in an 1841 report of Sinibaldo de Mas, the Spanish ambassador to China. Short of funds and unassisted by the local bureaucracy, de Mas reported that he had to sell his photographs—probably daguerreotypes. These pictures are still unlocated.

In 1860, a still unidentified French engineer who visited the South Seas took the earliest known photographs from the Philippines. These were stereoscopic pictures of the Tinguian of Abra. These images were later found in Paris.

The first foreign resident photographer and the first Filipino photography studio are also still unidentified though A. Honiss maintained a commercial studio in Manila as early as 1865. Access to photography equipment and supplies from abroad determined the level of activity of photographers in the country. European technology spread with the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869. According to an 1875 record, there were seven photographers practicing in the country. By 1902, there were 48 photographers—all men—in 14 studios; three in Bicol, the rest in Manila. The Dutch businessman Meerkamp van Embden, who served as the Netherlands’ honorary consul from 1889 to 1927, took many photographs of the Philippines showing his family’s career in the country in a time of growing trade. His collection presents travels in the Philippines and several infrastructure projects. His images constitute an observant look at various indigenous peoples. Felix Laureano is considered the first Filipino who made pictures of his country, and his Recuerdos de Filipinas (Memories of the Philippines), 1895, details customs and daily activities, profiles of the land and its people, and different structures at that time. These are mainly addressed to a foreign observer. Filipinos, as “new peoples” to the American public, were showcased and avidly photographed at the 1904 World’s Fair in St. Louis, Missouri. These photographs often showed the Filipinos’ unique, exotic characteristics (such as those of midgets and other physical distinctions).

The earliest exhibition of photography as art featured photographs taken by Miguel Reyes, in a section of the Asociacion International de Artistas art exhibition in 1908 in Escolta.

Rolled celluloid film, an invention of Kodak’s George Eastman, was available in Manila as early as 1900. The establishment of the Kodak-Philippines office in 1928 further increased the possibilities for local photography. In 1946, the monopoly of photo supplies was broken, easing import restrictions.

In 1980, Ferdinand Marcos’s Presidential Decree 1938 declared the first week of January as National Photography Week. This was to encourage the use of photography in developmental communications and nation building by the Professional Photographers’ Association of the Philippines (PPAP), then headed by Jose Sarmiento. The PPAP was organized by Bob Razon, Arsenio Veluz, Regalado Montemayor, and Escobar Ovejas. The National Photography Week Awards are now perhaps the most prestigious photography awards in the country.

During the National Photography Week in 1987, seven photography groups formed the Federation of Philippine Photographers Foundation (FPPF), the first umbrella association of photography clubs in the country. Its concerns include photography education, professionalization, and the availability of photography materials. There are many photography groups across the country—small and large, amateur and professional. Before the onset of more affordable digital photography equipment, commercial photographers were increasingly concerned with artistic or creative aspects of photography, while creative photographers in turn were being drawn to commercial work.

The more democratized landscape today has enabled even amateur photographers to do their own image-making. In the 1990s, the introduction of digital photography allowed the storage of image files in computers rather than printing from studios and photo shops. The production cost of practicing photography significantly lessened and enabled enthusiasts to be experimental with images using computer programs. The degree of manipulation of images affected the resulting images, prompting debates on the changing aesthetics of photography between digital and manual photography. Its inclusion in mobile phones in mid-2000 and the onset of social media dedicated to image sharing on the Internet have made photography a part of everyday life.

Photography in the country has the following primary functions: portraiture; travel, research, and news documentation; propaganda; advertising and fashion coverage; and as artist’s tool and art medium.

Research on the history of Philippine photography continues. There is also the need to develop the exhibition and commercial value of Philippine photographs. Probably the most important contemporary exhibition of vintage photographs about the Philippines was Colonial Philippines: Photographs 1860-1910, curated by John Silva and Jonathan Best for the Philippine-American Research Center, University of California, Berkeley. It was held in the autumn of 1987 at the Lowie Museum of Anthropology, USA. Exhibited were 125 original prints, selected from 25,000.

Portraiture

Photography became popular because it provided access to images that consisted of the accurate likeness of a sitter at a cost cheaper than a painting. Cartes-de-visite were affordable photos, measuring 4 x 2½ in, the size of calling cards; they were patented in 1854 by Adolphe Eugene Disderi. The tarjeta, measuring 3½ x 5½ in so that it could be mailed as a postcard, became the next affordable photo print. In the last half of the 1800s, photo studios sprouted in Manila’s business centers like Santa Cruz, Binondo, and Quiapo. Among them were Fotografia Pertierra, Fotografia Universal, Camara Fotografica, and Fotografia Enrique Schuren. By the 1930s, when photography had become a viable business, prosperous provinces, like Iloilo and Cebu, began to draw studios and itinerant photographers to set up shop.

The 19th century standardized settings for photographs to be taken, with fancy chairs, pedestals, curtains, and painted backdrops. Studios like Voigt’s advertised in print and offered the services of a peinadora or makeup expert free of charge. Photo-portraits, vertical full-frame or bust, were hung prominently on living-room and office walls. Life-size photos became status symbols. Small photos enclosed in standing frames were displayed on top of tables and pianos. Portraits were usually taken to mark graduations, weddings, coronations of festival queens, and award ceremonies. At the turn of the century, it was customary to photograph a corpse before its burial.

Photos were exchanged as a sign of friendship. Filipinos traveling abroad collected portraits of friends from foreign lands. The Lopez Memorial Library and Museum keeps a historic album of Jose Rizal. In the 1920s, a bachelorette showed special affection to a suitor by giving him her portrait. American soldiers stationed in the Philippines before the Philippine-American War in 1899 were a ready market for souvenir portraits. A popular souvenir photograph depicted an “American hero” pointing at a Filipino posed as a captured insurgent pleading for mercy, while another paid Filipinos to pose as dead at the American’s feet.

The increase in the circulation of newspapers and magazines and the improved quality of print media also raised the value of portraiture in the making of celebrity. The staff photographers of magazines gained prestige as their publications conducted beauty contests, which consisted of published portraits of both candidates and winners. Joaquin Reyes and Carlos Alcazar of the El Renacimiento, Augusto Fuster of Excelsior, and Voigt of Renacimiento Filipino were popular portraitists in the early 1900s. Star Studio was also popular during the American period.

From 1934 to 1956, EduardoMasferre photographed the indigenous groups of the Cordilleras. Prominent post-World War II portraitists include Chat Peypoch (who specialized in photography of children), Bob Razon, Arsenio and Sofronio Veluz, and Regalado Montemayor. Sonny Camarillo is known for his portraits of beautiful women, and Rupert Jacinto gained attention as a portraitist of international celebrities. Mandy Navasero takes sensitive portraits of people from all walks of life and, like many Filipinos now armed with imaging devices, documents both people and places encountered in her travels. A shift toward less straightforward portraiture playing on the physical and chemical aspects of the medium would be found, by the 1970s onward, in the work of Nap Jamir II, Johnny Manahan, Neal Oshima, Wig Tysmans , among others. A minimalist aesthetic informs artists such as Isa Lorenzo and Jake Versoza. Experimental photography in a much more broadly conceived portrait genre continues in the conceptual practices of Kiri Dalena, Gaston Damag, Jed Escueta, Lyra Garcellano, Romeo Lee, Wawi Navarozza, Gina Osterloh, Steve Tirona, and Eric Zamuco.

Research and Documentation

Early photographs recorded both the typical and the unusual for travelers, anthropologists, medical experts, and the colonial bureaucracy.

In the 1880s, the British Fox Talbot developed a cross screen to reproduce photographs with a rotogravure printing press. La Ilustracion Filipina introduced foto-litografia (photo lithography) in 1892. Los Domingos del Diario de Manila featured photographs, along with paintings and sketches, in 1896. The Cheofre Lithographic Company achieved clear photographic reproduction in their documentation of the Pact of Biak-na-Bato celebration in 1897.

Englishman Roger Fenton took the first war photos during the Crimean War of 1856. Likewise, field correspondents from the United States (US) Signal Corps, Harper’s, and Leslie’s Weekly accompanied the US Army of 1898. President Emilio Aguinaldo’s government issued press passes to local and foreign correspondents and photographers. With their equipment on horseback and carabao-drawn carts, they not only recorded battlefronts but also local lifestyles; these were printed in newspapers and books. This is exemplified in the work of Harry Whitfield Harnish, an American soldier, who opened a photo studio in Zamboanga. His photograph of Captain Alex Davis’ Child and Nurse, done between 1898 and 1907, presents a mother and child theme charged with racial and colonial tensions.

On-the-spot photojournalism was highlighted during the Tercentenary of Newsprinting celebration in 1911. Magazines published more photos than the daily tabloids. The monthly Renacimiento Filipino ran an account of the first airplane accident on the islands—that is, a full photo coverage of Mr Sevimming and his plane as they crashed outside Bautista, Pangasinan. Fires, floods, funerals, parades, political meets, banquets, countryside development, and celebrities were the staple subjects in news pictorials. For the first time Filipino readers saw how other parts of the country looked while experiencing visualized history in the making. Professional and hobbyist photographers were encouraged to submit photos. Among the contributors were Sol Naciente, S. A. Figueras, Cebu Photo Material Company, and Camera Supply Company.

The American colonial government set up the first tourism office of the Philippines in the early 1900s. It was the first initiative to promote the islands not just for curious local customs but for scenic beauty. Promotional materials as well as postcards and picture albums opened up tourist markets, providing employment for photographers. The Department of Tourism continues to promote travel photography. Sunday Tribune Magazine ran a series with photographs by Manuel Arellano, called Manila Beautiful. Current specialists in travel photography are Jose Sarmiento, George Tapan, and Francis Rivera.

From the 1870s to the early 1900s, anthropological research by Europeans and Americans supplemented by photography brought Philippine culture to world notice. Valuable photographs were taken in the ethnological expeditions led by Alexander Schadenberg, Hans Meyer, Jose Montano, Paul Rey, Alfred Marche, Dean Worcester, and Roy Barton. These were in aid of anthropometric measurements being taken by anthropologists, particularly of the human cranium in order to determine mental inferiority or superiority.

The exhibit of photographs of the Philippines displayed in 1904 at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in St. Louis, Missouri, USA, consisting of 2,000 prints, remains unsurpassed in scope and number, and the way they continue to surface in the work of scholars writing on the fraught relations of America and the Philippines demonstrates the potency of photographic images in spurring research and new thinking. Many of these images have been digitally archived for the project The United States and Its Territories (1870-1925: The Age of Imperialism), where 2,100 photographs from the Special Collections Library of the University of Michigan can be accessed and studied. Filipino anthropologists and archaeologists continue to use photography as an investigative tool. Scholar Benito Vergara Jr’s Displaying Filipinos: Photography and Colonialism in Early 20th Century Philippines, 1995, articulated how the domain of images taken by Americans to represent the country to fellow Americans is very much integrated in the colonial narrative of progress and civilization of the colonial regime. In the same manner, Jonathan Best’s Philippine Picture Postcards 1900-1920, 1994 and A Philippine Album: American Era Photographs, 1900-1930, 1998, showed how Americans saw the Filipinos. Analyn Salvador-Amore’s Tapping Ink, Tattooing Identities: Tradition and Modernity in Contemporary Kalinga Society utilized the Dean C. Worcester Pictures Collection at the University of Michigan as an ethnographic tool to provoke dialogue about contemporary tattooing practices among the indigenous peoples of Northern Luzon.

In 1911, Eusebio Nievera Sr won a competition sponsored by the American Society of Photographers, making him the first Filipino recipient of an international award for photography. In 1931, Vicente Mills Sr was awarded a diploma of honor for his photograph titled Native Architecture by the Kodak International Salon World Contest held in Geneva. In 1981, Angsin Taguibao, a still-documentary expert, received the Photographic Society of America (PSA) Diamond Star Award for consistently entering monochrome prints of high quality in PSA-recognized international salons worldwide.

In June 1922, the forthnightly Photo News: A Graphic Review in Rotogravure first appeared in Manila’s newsstands. It was the first authentic Filipino pictorial magazine. In 1925, a contest was sponsored by Denniston’s, a photo-equipment supplier. Among the winning photographs were landscapes, portrait shots of local belles, beautiful Filipinas in native dress, as well as human interest themes, like the Quiapo Church beggars.

Over the years, Philippine newspapers and magazines have prided themselves in their staff photographers whose works have competed in industry-sponsored contests. Among the prestigious competitions in photojournalism was the National Press Club–Elizalde photojournalism contest, which ran from 1954 to 1988. Early winners include Honesto Vitug, Dominador Suba, and Benjamin Roxas. Vitug documented the presidents of the Philippines from Emilio Aguinaldo to Corazon Aquino.

Well-known photojournalists are Vitug (first Filipino on the Associated Press roster), Nap Jamir Sr, Teodulo Protomartir (called “Dean of Philippine Photography” because of his interest in teaching photography since the 1950s), Nap Jamir Jr, Sonny Yabao, Fabian Roxas, Filemon Tutay, Ed Santiago, and Benjamin Roxas, among others.

In 1950, Tutay of the Philippine Free Press Magazine organized the Press Photographers Association of the Philippines (PPAP). In 1988, the Photojournalists Guild of the Philippines was formed by members of the PPAP who were protesting against suppression of the press.

Nath Guttierez pioneered cultural photography or the documentation of cultural aspects, when he became the first and sole photographer of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) from 1970 till his death in 1974. He was the first Filipino to receive academic training in photography from Germany. In 1983, the CCP sponsored a documentation photo contest to record artistic activities, such as theater performances, art exhibits, and related outdoor performances held in and outside the CCP. The competition highlighted cultural coverage as a specialized topic of photography. Among the specialists for cultural events coverage are Boaner Medina, Ernesto Caballero, and Renato S. Rastrollo.

Photographers and academic researchers also collaborated on book projects that highlight the aesthetic qualities of indigenous and traditional arts. Wig Tysmans worked with Marian Roces for Sinaunang Habi (Traditional Weaving) and Elena Mirano for Subli: Isang Sayaw sa Apat na Tinig (Subli: One Dance in Four Voices). Masato Yokohama did the photos for Roberto Maramba’s Form and Splendor: Personal Adornment of Northern Luzon Ethnic Groups, Philippines, 1998, while Wig Tysmans, BG Hernandez, and Ramon Cantonjos did the photography for Ramon Villegas’s book Ginto: History Wrought in Gold, 2004. In the performing arts, Ballet Philippines was the subject of Jaime Zobel de Ayala’s book Zobel Dancer, 1988, as well as In Performance by Doreen Fernandez with photography by Rudy Vidad.

Scientific research, like astronomy, requires special photographic skills. Underwater photography is done by specialists and amateurs for research and as a hobby. Filipino physicians, especially those engaged in laboratory or academic activities, were among the first to learn photography. Among the photographers trained abroad in medical photography is British-trained Ben Laxina, and Ibarra Deri who specializes in photomicrography.

Cultural anthropology and sociology have also been behind the stream of pictures depicting ethnographies of the everyday life of Filipinos living across and beyond the Philippines, in the uplands, to city streets, and at sites peopled by expatriate Filipinos. Artists such as Tommy Hafalla, Nana Buxani, Veejay Villafranca, Kat Palasi, and Xyza Bacani are just some of the photographers working in this vein.

Propaganda

Filipinos realized the vital role of photography as an effective communication tool when they first saw the pictorial coverage of the opening of the Malolos Congress in Sep 1898. La Independencia praised Jose Piñon’s clear photos and Pedro Chivi’s documentation of the establishment of Asia’s first constitutional democracy. Chivi’s photograph of Filipino floats on parade in Malolos, Bulacan has become iconic. Chivi’s Plaza del Conde studio in Binondo sold photos of Republican troops alongside their respective generals, as well as pictures related to the War for Philippine Independence, and of the Congressional Hall in the Barasoain Church.

Government information agencies continue to use photography for posters, brochures, and other materials which promote official programs and policies. The Government Photographers of the Philippines, composed of photographers working in government offices, was organized by Malacañan Press office photo-section chief Manuel Bulaong.

One of the most powerful civic campaigns using photographs, “Disiplina ang Kailangan” (Discipline Is Necessary), was launched at the start of the martial law government of President Marcos in 1972. The privately sponsored “Catch a Cheater” photography contest was used by anti-Marcos government groups to prevent election fraud in 1985. Agencies, like the Population Commission used visual aids in public educational campaigns.

Human rights and ecological advocates as well as charities and fund raisers for crisis situations are among civic groups that use photography calculatedly and powerfully. Such were photographs by Alex Baluyut, Luis Liwanag, Bullit Marquez, and Sigfred Balatan.

Advertising

Photographers traditionally began as commercial portraitists, photojournalists, and hobbyists. Advancements in science, technology, and marketing methods increased specialization. The role of photography in selling products, services, and personalities has steadily increased since the early 1900s, particularly during the 1970s, with the growth of the Philippine advertising industry, the public relations sector, and mass media. With the inclusion of graphic arts as a course in university fine arts programs, photography became a subject of legitimate academic study.

Advertising photographers serve on the staff of agencies and also set up their own companies. They are considered specialists due to the demands of creative conceptualizing and product lighting for print advertisements, calendars, brochures, flyers, point-of-purchase displays, posters, and even guides for billboards. Filipino advertising photographers service local and international clients. “You’re only as good as your last shot” is the unofficial policy in the advertising field. Competition in the industry has further energized photography as far as creative talent and professionalism go. As creative directors and clients make demands for creative effects, photographers have had to introduce and appropriate new photo technology. Being able to offer an advertiser that competitive edge has allowed photographers to increase professional rates. Access to equipment and expanded platforms for advertising have reinforced popular interest in photography’s potential just as this has led to overproduction and deluge of sensory stimuli.

In 1988, the Advertising Photographers of the Philippines was organized to professionalize advertising photography upon the initiative of Emil Davocol, Eduviges Huwang aka “Edi,” Nelson Rivera, Edgar Bayani, John Chua, and Bien Bautista, among others. Some of the well-known contemporary advertising photographers are Davocol, Huwang, Rivera, Chua, Mark Floro, Pio Capiral, Eddie Go, and NikRiccio. There are also some who specialize in food photography, product stills, and action formats. Foreign training in university and atelier programs offering degrees and short course certificates have enabled new photographers and upgraded local capabilities. To date, there is no collegiate degree program for photography in Philippine schools as photography is still subsumed under broader design and arts programs.

The test of an advertising photographer’s mettle are international competitions for advertising campaigns and products. In 1976, the International Multicolor Exhibitors Competition awarded a gold medal to Angelus, a posterized color photo of birds in flight by Davocol. He also received the Best Four-Picture Series Award and the Best Entrant from Asia Award. The Mongkok Photographic Society honored Davocol further by awarding his creativity at the same exhibit. In 1980, Davocol returned with a posterized evening shot titled Quiet Beacons, adjudged as the “Best Local Entrant” and awarded another gold medal. Davocol’s winning streak is credited with breaking the hiatus of Filipinos in these international competitions.

Until 1992, the highest advertising award was the CLIO Award given in the United States. Each category in the annual event would have as many as 27,000 entries from around the world. Philippine advertising agencies have been making it to the finalist rounds. Among photographic stills that have brought credit to both agency and client as finalists in the CLIO are Pampers’ Leak a Like by Dante Mara for the Ace-Saatchi and Saatchi Advertising Incorporated, 1989; Magnolia’s Why Fry Economy When You Can Fry First Class? by Chua for Ace-Saatchi, 1988 (also awarded the Best Copy for Print in the 1988 Creative Guilds Award); Philippine Airlines’ The Beauty of the Philippines: Beaches shot by Davocol for Avia Communications Incorporated, Best Print Campaign category, 1991; and Blue Diamond Nuts’ Everyday by Joey Ibay, 1990.

Other important foreign photography awards that test the advertising photographer include those given by the Asian Advertising Congress, which in 1989 awarded Philippine Airlines’ The Beauty of the Philippines photos by Bautista and Bolix Suzara the Best Print Campaign Award for 1989. In 1989 and 1990, McCann-Erickson Incorporated received a finalist citation from the New York Festival of Advertising for its Del Monte Pineapple Juice’s Label and Levi’s Black Jeans’ Ink advertisements photographed by Chua and Charlie Almonte, respectively. In 1991, McCann-Erickson received a bronze medal for the Amen advertisement photographed by Bayani for Levi’s 501 jeans.

Advertising campaigns, as well as color magazines, posters, and billboards, have increased public response to and interest in the attractiveness or impact, and aesthetic or graphic quality of photography. These have also resurrected experimentation in darkroom and computerization techniques as applied to the shooting and printing of a photograph.

Fashion has also opened up creative dimensions for photographers. Fashion coverage is an adjunct of advertising, press photography, and portraiture, and is now a separate line of specialization. Recognized fashion photographers include Sonny Yabao, Jun de Leon, Wig Tysmans, Manny Goloyugo, Edgar Santiago, and Pancho Escaler. Wedding, sports, travel, and underwater photography are other fields of commercial photography that have made the practice of photographers successful and sustainable.

Photojournalism

Photographers affiliated with Philippine and international news agencies have pushed the documentary artistic capacity of the medium to an ever-widening extent. Under American colonization, Dean Worcester’s photographs of indigenous Filipinos, described as tribal and exotic, were printed in the National Geographic magazine. Articles on the Philippines, prompted by studies in anthropology and tourism, were illustrated with images of bare-chested Filipinas, prompting curiosity and controversy. The Nov 1913 issue featured hand-colored photographic illustrations of Filipinos accompanying Worcester’s article “The Non-Christian Peoples of the Philippine Islands: With an Account of What Has Been Done for Them under American Rule,” juxtaposed the backwardness of the colonized Filipinos who were “in need” of American guidance and benevolence. By 1915, photographer Charles Matin, who collaborated with Worcester, would head the National Geographic Society Photographic Laboratory. Continuing in the long history of featuring tribal images in the Philippines, the magazine would later feature in 1972 a spurious stone-age inhabitants in Mindanao called “Tasaday,” which sparked a debate in the politics of image-making and authenticity.

Willie Vicoy’s gripping snapshot of a Vietnamese woman carrying her stricken child appeared on the front page of Time and Newsweek magazines in March 1975 and became influential in shaping international opinion on the personal cost of the Vietnam War. Albert Garcia’s death-defying photograph of a van escaping the wave of ashes coming from the just-erupted Mount Pinatubo astounded millions of viewers worldwide and was included in Time: Great Images of the 20th Century and National Geographic: 100 Best Pictures. Working for Agence France Presse, Romeo Gacad covered the 1991 Gulf War and 2001 Afghan War and was an embedded photographer with the US Army Third Infantry Division in the invasion of Iraq in 2003.

The 1986 EDSA Revolt and its sequel in 2001 involved numerous Filipino photojournalists who seized the opportunity to cover their own country and offer the world their views. The works of Andy Hernandez, Vicoy, and Noli Yamsuan were part of the book Bayan Ko !: Images of the Philippine Revolt while those by John K. Chua and Manuel B. Ferrer comprised People Power: An Eyewitness History—these two being important photographic collections on the revolution. In 2011, the business daily Business Mirror published The Human Tide of History: The Protest Movement from the Aquino Assassination to EDSA. Anvil Publishing released EDSA 2: A Nation in Revolt; A Photographic Journal immediately after EDSA 2 in 2001 to commemorate the uprising. Other photojournalists who covered the political events before, during, and after the EDSA Revolt are Alex Baluyut, Joe Galvez, Vin Toledo, Jun Aniceta, Melvyn Calderon, Mon Acasio, Bullit Marquez, and Luis Liwanag. American photojournalist Kim Komenich, who covered EDSA for the US newspaper Examiner, provides an interesting take on how a foreign eye sees sociopolitical change in a familiar-yet-strange polity.

The fast-paced nature of violence has become a challenge for photography’s capacity to still the moving image. In the 1980s and 1990s, reports on the raging counterinsurgency campaign in rural areas became staple fare in Philippine and international newspapers and magazines. Photographic documentary projects on slum eviction, illegal drugs, street crimes, gangster culture, and prostitution have been a regular subject for both amateur and professional photographers and catapulted Filipino images to international attention. Photojournalists such as Jun Sepe and Sigfred Balatan are just two examples of lensmen who consciously transgress the categories of coverage and art in their image-making focused on disaster and displacement in relation to development issues. Other notable Filipino photojournalists are Johnny Acasio, Dick Baldovino, Joan Bondoc, Sonny Camarillo, Romeo Gacad, Albert Garcia, Edwin Tuyay, and Vicoy.

The documenting of violent and tragic events has also surfaced ethical issues regarding the practice of both artists and photojournalists. Apart from the angle of the subject’s volition, safety issues also come into play. In this regard Ben Roxas of the Manila Times was photographed dying in the Plaza Miranda bombing. Vicoy went to cover the counterinsurgency war in Cagayan province in late Apr 1986 and died when the army jeep he was riding with soldiers was ambushed by New People’s Army rebels. On 27 Jul 1986, civilian Steve Salcedo was mercilessly lynched by Marcos loyalists in front of photographers, raising the question of whether the lensmen should have continued with coverage or intervened by helping the victim in such life-threatening circumstances. Martin Castor of the tabloid Pilipino Ngayon died on reportorial duty while covering the coup attempt against the Aquino administration on 28 Aug 1987.

Artist’s Tool and Art Medium

Filipino artists were early to appreciate the archival role of photography. JuanLuna and FelixResurreccionHidalgo had all their landmark works photographed. Augusto Fuster was the first painter in the country to use his camera to compose pictures as paintings. Painters, like FernandoAmorsolo, Mauro Malang Santos, and AngKiukok, used photographs of their subjects as references for paintings. Painter JuvenalSanso makes hand-painted transparencies for projection and printing. Among outstanding innovations in the social realist stream is painter BenCab’s Larawan (Photograph) series painted in the 1970s onward, inspired by photo images taken of Filipinos during colonial times. Photographs, in whole or in part, have been incorporated into collages and constructivist works. The role of photography among photorealists also cannot be overlooked.

The use of photography as primary form of individual expression has acquired a growing appeal among both professional and amateur photographers. In 1928, the first photography club, Camera Club of the Philippines, was formed under the initiative of Manuel de Cartagena. It provides camaraderie and lessons in creative photography for amateurs and hobbyists. It is also the first local camera club to participate in bilingual photography-teaching exhibits conceptualized for the general Filipino public in coordination with a Philippine art museum. Undertaken by the Metropolitan Museum of Manila (The Met), its Pilipinas Nating Napakaganda: The Ecology of Aesthetics (Our Beautiful Philippines: The Ecology of Aesthetics), opened in 1988, and was a landmark in the employment of artistic photography to promote both environmentalism and aesthetic appreciation in the country.

The PhilippineArtGallery hosted the first one-person photography exhibit featuring Nap Jamir Sr in 1954. Photography as an art form received a boost when the CCP was established in 1969. At the time, CCP’s visual arts director Raymundo Albano and The Met director ArturoLuz were proponents of modernism and contemporary experimentation. On 15 Aug 1974, Albano curated Otherwise Photography, a statement on how conceptual photography could engage artists beyond technical concerns. The curatorial charge did not even require participants to handle cameras or make their own prints. It installed print serializations, segment presentations, and “instant” photos in a manner unique for Manila at that juncture. The seven participating artists were professional photographers Butch Perez, Franco Patriarca, and Nap Jamir Jr, along with Albano, Johnny Manahan, MarianPastor-Roces, and AlanRivera.

From the 1980s, The Met, which specialized in the bringing over of foreign-loan exhibitions, exposed local artists to original photographic work by prominent foreign artists, such as David Hamilton, 1982; Henri Cartier-Bresson, 1990; John Thomson, 1991; and Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, 1992. Other museums, like CCP’s Contemporary Art Museum of the Philippines, Ayala Museum, National Museum, and commercial art galleries, like Diviana and Luz, increased their exhibitions of Filipino and Asian photographers in group and solo shows. In general, however, comprehensive photography-specific exhibitions come few and far between with only two figuring in the last decade: Swarm in the Aperture: Recent Photography in the Philippines, held at the National Museum of the Philippines, 2008; and Beyond Frame: Philippine Photomedia at the Ateneo Art Gallery, 2009.

Photographers associated with creative photography are Davocol, Tysmans, Goloyugo, Patriarca, Bautista, Baldovino, Rodolfo de Leon, Quincy Castillo, JaimeZobelde Ayala, and Francis Escaler. Patrick de Koenigswarter and Neal Oshima are foreign photographers based in the Philippines.

In this era of digital technology, today’s photographers variably manifest a concern for creative composition, lighting, and the thematics of their works. The rising expectations for instantaneous imaging and circulation of these pictures, along with the value of pictorial media, weigh against the photographer’s need not just to document but to express personal feelings about their subjects. Hybrid approaches to visualizing techniques and visual handling thus continue to challenge both artists’ and photojournalistic orientations.

Like other imaging media, photography attracts artists who take to it primarily for its formal possibilities. Ricardo Soler’s Philippine Photography: The Best of ’81, 1982, argued for the solid consideration of photography as an art form. The role of self-expression through camerawork, as well as processing, printing, and installation techniques are reflective of late 20th-century culture in which technology, cerebral conceptualization, and affective disposition interface as influences in the production of art. More recently, the Beyond Frame exhibition mounted by 12 Filipino artists highlighted the troubled history of the country by utilizing the combination of photography with installation art and new media. Earlier, Filipino, Portraits by Jaime Zobel de Ayala, 1987, depicted the “heroes” of the 1986 EDSA Revolt, from Cory Aquino and Jaime Cardinal Sin to the photographers and nuns who figured in the revolt.

This unproblematic shifting between formalist and contextual concerns may variably be seen in photography by artists such as Toto Labrador, Rachel Rillo, Corrine San Jose, and Jenifer Wofford. Questions of subjectivity and agency have been raised in regard to the work of Mark Gary and Poklong Anading. Notions of presence and absence within the photographic frame either through tactical positioning of the lens or through digital manipulation figure in the work of artists like Paul Pfeiffer. The use of the image as raw collage fodder is seen in transmedia work by Kidlat de Guia, Tita Lim, and Romina Diaz. That photographs can serve as both context-rich and installative element can be found in the bodies of work of Yason Banal, Lena Cobangbang, Nona Garcia, Katya Guerrero, At Maculangan, Lani Maestro, Riza Manalo, Manny Migriño, Norberto Roldan, Kreskin Sugay, MM Yu; or as post-process-installative document in the work of Gary Ross Pastrana; and as surrealist medium in the work of Emmanuel Santos and Frank Callaghan. This interface of form and meaning making underlines how the medium remains potent despite its potential to overpower and its associations with self-indulgence.

Of late, an explosion of photographic work on and/or by Filipinos in the diaspora have gained traction on social media as well as in more traditional exhibition platforms. The work of Ric Rocamora on Filipino military veterans in the United States is an example. Xyza Cruz Bacani, a Filipina domestic helper in Hong Kong, and her crafting of remarkable pictures of the places and peoples she traverses as overseas worker, provide an interesting view from below of the imponderable lives of Filipinos living in flux and under less than optimal conditions.

Photography Studies

There has been a significant growth in the study of photography in the Philippines—in the fields of artistry and technique, on the one hand, and history, theory, and criticism, on the other. Countless photography groups, institutions, and organizations initiate print and publications, social media discussions, workshops, exhibits, equipment sales, fairs, and festivals. Notable among these are the following: Philippine Photography Blog, Digital Photographer Philippines magazine, Pinoy Photography community (PiPho), Philippine Center for Creative Imaging Institute of Photography, Philippine Bird Photography Forum, the Federation of Philippine Photographers Foundation, Philippine Photographers (Ph Photo), ASEAN-Korea Multimedia Competition, Philippine Photo Festival, and Manila Photo (a weeklong photography festival).

Through the FPPF, and the chairmanship of Huwang, much effort has been made to increase local opportunities to improve photographic skills and creative approaches. With photographer Eliseo Casia and Celia Angeles, an art teacher interested in photography education, FPPF has pursued annual photo exhibits accompanied by workshops and seminars wherein professionals teach and interact with students. Composition and chiaroscuro are among aesthetic concerns in the basic FPPF learning modules. Picking up from earlier artist-led ventures, such as Blacksoup in Cubao-X and the defunct Photography Art Center in Makati, the artist couple Katya Guerrero and At Maculangan set up Pioneer Studios not only for professional shoots but as a converging point for photographers and other artists interested in slideviews, workshop-critiques, and talks done alongside artbooks, a distribution hub for critical literature on all of the Philippine arts. In addition, many photography contests, sponsored by local and foreign companies, nonprofit institutions, and photo suppliers, continue to uphold creativity as criterion when selecting winners. In light of the digital revolution in photomedia, other formal and informal aggrupations, such as the Digital Photographers of the Philippines and various Instagram groups, have also played into the broadened practice.

Academic institutions both here and abroad have increasingly studied photography within the disciplines of fine arts, mass and visual communication, art history, anthropology, and history. The Asian Center for Journalism of the Ateneo de Manila University offers certificate and diploma courses in photojournalism conducted by leading international photojournalists. Notable literature on photography include the following: Jonathan Best’s Philippine Picture Postcards: 1900-1920, 1994, and A Philippine Album: American Era Photographs 1900-1930, 1998; Benito Vergara Jr’s Displaying Filipinos: Photography and Colonialism in Early 20th Century Philippines, 1995; Enrique de la Cruz and Pearlie Rose Baluyut’s Confrontations, Crossings, and Convergence: Photographs of the Philippines and the United States, 1898-1998, 1998; Maria Serena Diokno’s Voices and Scenes of the Past: Philippine American War Retold, 1999; Felix Laureano’s Recuerdos de Filipinas , 1895 (original in Spanish), and translated into English in 2001; Art Studies Foundation’s The Philippines through the Lens of an American Soldier (1898-1907): The Harry Whitfield Harnish Photographic Collection, 2004; John L. Silva’s A Token of Our Friendship: Philippine Photos of Male Affection, 2011; and Mark Rice’s Dean Worcester’s Fantasy Islands: Photography, Film, and the Colonial Philippines, 2014. Written byFelice Sta. Maria and Santiago A. Pilar, updated by JPaul S. Manzanilla and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

text:
Pottery consists of functional and decorative objects made from clay and fired at high temperatures. Ceramics (from the Greek keramikos or “potter”) is also a term used, although ceramics has a wider application and includes objects for industrial use.

Pottery is divided into three types: earthenware or terra-cotta (literally, dried earth), which is made from porous clay and fired at a relatively low temperature, ranging from 1700°F to 2100°F; stoneware, which is made from a mixture of clay and feldspar and fired at a temperature ranging from 2220°F to 2230°F; and porcelain, which is made from kaolin (a pure and white clay from China), and feldspar, then fired at a temperature ranging from 2500°F to 2700°F. Pottery can be covered by a nonporous layer made from metal oxides, called glaze, or it can be unglazed.

The Process

The preparation of material for making pottery involves quarrying clay from riverbanks or clay deposits, and cleaning this of impurities by removing branches and twigs and by sedimentation, which involves the mixing of clay with water until it forms a creamy substance. The mixture is allowed to stand for a considerable amount of time to allow sand, pebbles, and stone to settle at the bottom of the mixture, thus leaving the clay body clean. Clean clay is separated from the sediments and is allowed to dry until it reaches a doughlike consistency. This is then mixed in proper proportions with other substances, including feldspar, sand, ash, and metal filings. The proportion of clay and other additives produces a specific type of pottery. For instance, burnay from Ilocos Sur belongs to stoneware and is made by adding sand to clay. This mixture is thoroughly kneaded either by machine; by hand; by foot, as in the case among the potters of Iloilo; or by an animal, such as the carabao among Ilocos burnay potters.

Once the clay is properly prepared, objects can be made from it. There are six common ways of working with clay: slab making, coiling, turn modeling or throwing, hand modeling or anvil-and-paddle method, cradling, and molding. The slab method involves rolling out the clay into flat sheets of slab and joining them together. Coiling means rolling out clay to form cylindrical strings and coiling these to form a bowl, pot, or jar. Throwing uses the potter’s wheel. The anvil-and-paddle method uses a stone or pot shard and a wooden paddle to shape an object, thin it out, and open it. Cradling involves shaping an open and shallow object by moulding it on another object, like a basket, a piece of cloth, or a leaf. Molding, customarily used for decorative works, uses a plaster of paris mold in which slip is poured and allowed to dry.

Once bone hard, the shaped clay is ready for firing. Firing removes all the moisture from the clay and renders the clay durable. Firing is done either in a kiln; a brick oven, which can be heated to high temperature by electricity, gas, or wood; or an open pit, a depression in the ground into which the clay objects are covered with flammable material, like wood, coconut husks, and fronds, then fired. The time of firing and cooling depends on the material. Stoneware takes 12 hours to fire and 12 hours to cool. Fired pieces are called bisque. Bisque can be the final stage in the creation of pottery, or it can be glazed—that is, covered with a vitreous solution that renders the piece impervious. At times, bisque are decoratively painted with enamel paints.

Terra-cotta pieces made by the different ethnolinguistic groups in the Philippines consist largely of cooking utensils, stoves, decorative items, and toys. Cooking pots are made by following three methods: hand modeling (anvil-and-paddle method), turn modeling (thrown method), and a combination of methods (hand modeling, molding, coiling, or slab building).

Hand-modeled pots follow similar methods. Starting the piece involves taking a lump of clay and putting it on a flat surface, such as a board, dish, or winnower. The lump is shaped into a ball among the Ibanag and Pampango, or an elongated shape among the Cebuano. This lump is opened by means of the thumb or fingers by the Bontok, Bukidnon, Cebuano, and the Mandukayan Kalinga. Then the body of the pot is built. The Bontok hollow the rounded clay with their hands as do the Mandukayan Kalinga. The Ibanag, Bukidnon, Tausug, Pampango, and Cebuano use a paddle and anvil to enlarge the pot and thin its wall. The anvil used by the Pampango, Cebuano, and Tausug is of stone. The Mandukayan Kalinga use their hands to shape the pot and press its walls thin, then the inside is smoothened by a curved piece of bamboo. A coil of clay is attached to the pot’s opening to form a rim; but among the Ibanag and Cebuano, a paddle is used to put out the rim. As the pot is turned once around, the paddle set at a 120-degree angle creates the rim. Finishing involves decorating or smoothing the surface of a vessel. For smoothing, a damp cloth, stone, or paddle is used.

For turned pottery, the wheel is used by the Ilocano, especially in the making of large vessels. For the making of the burnay, a wheel embedded on the ground and moved by kicking is used. The Bikol use the bayanyang, a pivoted turntable. In Masbate, the clay is put on top of a tournette made from a flat piece of wood through which a slender stick or iron spike is driven. The spike is driven through a section of a banana stalk placed firmly on the ground. The method of shaping turned pottery is similar to the hand-modeled method with the thumb making the initial opening. The body is shaped by anvil and paddle, whereas the rim is made by running a wet cloth at the opening while the vessel is on the wheel.

Slab modeling has been documented among the Ivatan. They begin with a slab of clay shaped by the hand to form a circle. The circle is then cradled inside a small round, shallow, wooden form, overlapping the edge from 15 cm to 30 cm depending on the size of the pot. The clay is taken out of the form, and the upper part is formed while holding the pot in the lap, using the anvil-and-paddle method.

Hand modeling, coiling, and molding are methods used by the Bagobo, the Manobo of Agusan province, and the Ifugao. The Bagobo begin by hand modeling the bottom of a jar or pot. It is then smoothened as it is turned on a dish. As the bottom is being turned, the potter adds coils of clay until the vessel reaches the desired size. Paddling gives the vessel its final shape. The Manobo shape the bottom of a pot by paddling a slab of clay on a round stone. Coils are then used to complete the pot. Patient paddling causes the coils to adhere well. The Ifugao mold the base on a hagappon or a round wooden base, probably a wooden bowl. To this base are added strips of clay, which are rolled then flattened. Pinching makes the clay adhere to the rest of the pot. The pot is finished by smoothing the inside and outside of the pot.

Contemporary pots tend to be simpler when compared with Iron Age artifacts. The decorative techniques of pressing, incising, and slip decoration are almost absent in contemporary works. None can match the beauty of the Manungguljar, dated to circa 800 BC, which is incised and slip decorated and covered by a lid with a sculptural rendering of the journey to the afterlife. The decline in earthenware technology is attributed in part to the introduction and easy availability of tradeware during the pre-Hispanic period.

Today, toys made of painted terra-cotta are often sold during fiestas, at the weekly makeshift markets called tabu or mercado. A common toy is a replica of clay utensils, which include the kalan (stove), palayok (pot) with a cover, and the kawali (frying pan). The frying pan is always made of metal but in its toy version is made of clay. Flowers in baskets, farm animals, women and men in native costumes, even guns are manufactured in great numbers in Tiwi, Albay. Also made are decorative items, like incised tiles, candleholders, flower-vase stands, and garden sculptures of toadstools and dwarves.

Pottery in the Philippines

Pottery presents an excellent material for archaeological study. Unlike other artifacts like cloth or textile, pottery—in the form of burial jars, jar covers, bowls, pots, and trays—does not disintegrate with time. Philippine pottery is represented by various traditions, most notable of which are the Sa-hyunh Kalanay pottery tradition, the Novaliches tradition, and the Bau-Malay pottery tradition.

The Sa-hyunh Kalanay tradition encompasses related variations of pottery found in many sites over a wide area. The name derives from the Kalanay cave site in northwest Masbate, but now refers to other potteries found in the Philippines sharing the same broad characteristics. The tradition probably developed in southern Philippines or eastern Indonesia after 2000 BC. Identifying the tradition are the decorative incisions, impressions, carvings, paintings, applications, and modelings. Incisions were marked by bordering the decorated area with punctuations or small circles, done with a single-point, a two-point, or even a three-point tool. Impressions were accomplished with an area shell. Carvings were done to remove the clay from a rim or applied flange. Paintings were meant to highlight incisions. Applications of flanges—which were later carved—were either vertical, horizontal, or cylindrical. Although rare, modeling of human or animal figures was applied to the surface of a vessel.

The triangle is the key geometric figure impressed with an area shell in variously directed diagonal lines. In a horizontal series, patterns are created around the neck or on the shoulder of a vessel. Common patterns consist of a chain of triangles, scrolls or spirals, zigzags, variations of vertical or diagonal lines bounded by horizontal borders, rectangles, chevrons, and others. Common forms include variations of the rounded bottom, flat bottom, ring foot, four applied feet, and bottomless hollow vessel. These often result in the cylindrical, the spherical, the subspherical, and others.

The Sa-hyunh Kalanay tradition subdivides into four: the Kalanay pottery complex, the Tabon pottery complex, the Bagupanto pottery complex, and the Asin pottery complex. The distinctions are fluid as there are great overlaps in form and decoration among the categories. Vessels from the Kalanay complex generally have plain surfaces and round bodies with plain, flared rims. The incisions are in a horizontal series of diagonal-line combinations bounded by straight or wavy lines. The main difference of the first from the others is the absence of cord-marked pottery. Kalanay pottery is found in Cotabato and Batangas.

The Tabon complex, named after various cave sites in western Palawan, is distinct for its cord-marked pottery in the earlier cave sites and for its simplicity in later sites. It is also distinguished for its very early dating—2000 BC. Vessels from this complex commonly have round bottoms with bodies of various shapes, such as round, ellipsoidal, and spheroidal.

The Bagupanto complex is often classified with the Kalanay complex as 17 of its vessels were unearthed at the Kalanay Cave site. Generally, they were of superior quality, material, and artistry. Vessels include large, circular or square burial jars with huge flanges. Incisions are rare. The complex presents some unusual forms: a test-tube-like vessel; an ordinary looking pot but uniquely perforated through its bottom and sides; and a bottomless cylinder with a bottom opening larger than the diameter of the top rim. Freehand-painted patterns distinguish the Asin complex, which is found in the Asin cave sites in Davao del Sur. These patterns include horizontal series or curvilinear scrolls.

The Novaliches tradition had been presented as a complex but was later reclassified by Wilhelm Solheim as a tradition. It was named after a Novaliches cave site north of Manila, but its remnants are also found in northwest Palawan and the Calamianes Islands. The tradition probably dates from 250 BC to the fourth century. Its most distinctive vessel is a well-polished bowl with a stand decorated profusely with geometric figures.

The Bau-Malay tradition or geometric pottery of south China is named after a cave site in Sarawak, Malaysia. In the Philippines it is found in coastal sites in Mindanao, Bohol, northern Palawan, and the Calamianes Islands. It is estimated that these sites have been in use since the 10th century. Vessels from this tradition have simple, round shapes with impressions that include small rosettes, triangles, and floral patterns. Some Tinguian pottery are classified under this tradition.

Earlier than the Kalanay tradition are ritual vessels unearthed at Cagayan, which are to date believed to be the earliest specimen of Philippine pottery: polished ritual vessels of Leta-leta; and eight earthenware from Ngipe’t Duldug, one of which has impressions of triangles and circles. The last two are found in Palawan cave sites.

In 1991, anthropomorphic jars from a cave in municipality of Maitum, Saranggani Province, Mindanao, were discovered. Dated to have been made in the Late Neolithic period, 29 secondary burial jars were recovered from the site featuring individuated faces of different ages, male and female, with emotions of sadness and happiness. Hair incisions are suggested by surface clay designs, with some jars featuring ears, torsos, arms, and legs.

Tradeware

Tradeware refers to stoneware and porcelain from precolonial trade with China and other Southeast Asian countries. These are mostly celadons of the Sung (960-1278) and Yuan Dynasty (1260-1368), blue-and-white porcelain of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), and Thai or Siamese pottery from the kilns of Sawankhalok and Sukhotai and Anamese ware from the area now called Vietnam. Local excavations have yielded very few pieces from the Tang Dynasty (618-906). Early tradeware was composed mostly of unglazed earthenware.

Most of the imported tradeware found in the Philippines have been excavated from graves. It was customary to furnish the dead with objects for the afterlife, so that they could maintain the prestige they had enjoyed on earth. This practice ceased with Spanish colonization in the 16th century, just when the Chinese trade was at its height. Some pieces, especially the large eight-eared stoneware dragon jar, used from the Sung to the Ching dynasty to store provisions of the junks, are among the prized possessions of ethnolinguistic groups in the Cordillera, Palawan, and Mindanao. These jars, often used for storing rice wine, are used in rituals and have been carefully guarded and therefore preserved.

Before the mid-8th century, lead-glazed ceramics appeared in a variety of colors. Chinese porcelain and stoneware were traded in the Philippines during the Sung and Yuan periods, and this trade reached its apex in the 13th century. Yuan ware were more ornate than those of the Sung, both in style and decoration. Yet these were mass-produced, and 200,000 pieces were often fired at one time. One-third to one-half of all the excavated ceramics found in the Philippines are from the Yuan period.

Up to the 14th century, Filipinos prized Chinese celadon pieces above all. The best pieces had a rich, glowing green glaze intended to rival jade, but many beautiful pieces ranged from gold to olive-green to blue-green. Changes in hue resulted from different firing methods: those from South China, which produced the soft jade-green color, used wood; while northern celadons were fired with coal and produced an olive-green color. Filipinos believed that these celadon and other tradeware were greater talismans than the local ware and deserved reverential treatment. They thought that celadon pieces changed hue when poisoned food was put on them, and that plates and bowls could cure diseases or act as vehicles for summoning powerful forces from nature.

In the 15th century, much value was placed on Thai celadon, which were slightly heavier and often less glossy. Gradually, however, celadon lost out to the blue-and-white under royal supervision in China during the Ming dynasty and in Vietnam. While most of the imports in the Philippines were celadon and blue and white, there were also great quantities of white blanc de chine ware (some with black or white decoration), plain brown ware, and monochrome ware in other colors, like oxblood.

In the mid-14th century, the Ming emperors brought foreign trade under direct control while private trade continued; it was severely restricted for several centuries. The Chinese ceramic trade generally declined, and filling the vacuum came white and unglazed black and brown ware in large quantities from Vietnam and Thailand.

Those with attribution to Vietnam are called Anamese ware after Anam and are believed to have been fired in kilns located near present-day Hanoi, Vietnam. The quality of Thai ware was generally inferior to the Chinese despite the strong Chinese influence in their shapes and potting techniques. In 1249, King Bam Kanhaeng of Thailand is said to have visited China and brought back to Thailand 300-500 master potters who began the kilns at Sukhothai and Sawankhalok. Thai ceramics from Sawankhalok were introduced into the Philippines in the mid-14th century. About 20-40 percent of ceramics found in local graves, especially in Mindoro and southern Luzon, are from Sawankhalok and Sukothai. Common are Sawankhalok pots with three vertical handles and domed lids with knobs on top. Sukhotai ware are mostly plates with underglazing and black decorations more exuberant than the Sawankhalok pieces. Production in Sukhothai kilns ceased before that in Sawankhalok possibly because their products could not compete with their rivals.

Excavated pieces reflect the complex history of trade in the Philippines. Aside from plates and dishes, covered cases, bowls, jars with or without lids, kendi or a pouring vessel with a spout, jarlets, and pots have been found. Water droppers, brush holders, and accessories for the desk of the Chinese literati entered the trades only when defective images of Chinese deities and those of daily life have been found.

Although Spanish colonization effectively ended the practice of burying ceramics with the dead, tradeware continued to be brought to the Philippines, and in turn exported to Europe. The blue-and-white porcelain of the Ming was emulated in Europe once the technique of porcelain making was made known. Blue-and-white ware in Europe included the Dutch Delfware. Ceramic pieces, glazed in blue designs or polychrome, called azulejos, were very popular in Portugal. The trade in tradeware and other goods in China inspired European taste for the “exotic”—meaning, the Oriental—thus creating a style associated with the rococo, called chinoiserie.

Since colonial times to the present, the easy availability and the cheap price of porcelain and ceramics from China made it easier to import rather than manufacture them locally, hence locally made ware were almost always earthenware, in the form of a banga (jar), palayok (cooking pot), and paso (pots for plants). But a pottery tradition in Vigan, Ilocos Sur, called burnay has survived since it was started by Chinese migrants who settled in the area, led by the Go and Ongkai family. The burnay jar is an unglazed earthen jar, using a type of clay found in the area mixed with fine sand, and fired in a ground kiln. The burnay is reputedly harder than terra-cotta jars.

Studio Pottery

Interest in contemporary studio pottery among artists started in the late 1960s. Through workshops, artists began to discover the importance of this medium. Studio pottery, the name given to handmade, usually one-of-a-kind pieces by ceramic artists became popular through the work of Manuel Ramirez, who taught ceramics at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts, and Leonardo Villaroman who also taught the craft. BaidyMendoza and AroSoriano were also most active practitioners of ceramic art during this period. However, these two painted on rather than glazed their pottery. Ceramic artists usually work with stoneware and with glazes to create utilitarian and decorative items. NelfaQuerubin, an artist from Iloilo, produced not only outstanding functional pieces from clay dug in Iloilo but also sculptural works done by the slab method. TessySanJuan and JonPettyjohn are known for their hand-formed jars, cups, plates, and dinner sets. LanelleAbueva-Fernando, who studied under the Japanese masters, produces works that are a combination of Eastern and Western traditions. She favors celadon, although recently she has experimented in using Mount Pinatubo ash. The Jaime and Anne deGuzman family—who established residence and pottery studio in Candelaria, Quezon, and Sagada in the Cordilleras—produced incised tiles and utilitarian pieces. An artist influenced by the de Guzmans is UguBigyan who combined stoneware with local fiber, roots, and branches to produce tapestries, candleholders, and salt and pepper sets. Studio pottery has but recently been discovered to be both aesthetic and functional and is avidly collected by patrons who find them in art exhibits or in stores specializing in these wares.

Contemporary potters in the Philippines come from all over the archipelago: Castora Cudal and Milagros Bernardo from Ilocos Norte; Mary Decoy from Benguet; Rodrigo Lomibao and Judith Mina from Pangasinan; Agripina Mondares from San Carlos City; Pedro Amistad from Ilocos Sur; Magdalena Hicarte from Sorsogon; Emma Ferraris from Negros Occidental; Erolly Geronimo from Bacolod City; Florentino Paul from Pari-an Sigma; Josefina Andico, Nena Egaña, Alejandro Mariano, Jerry Amar, Rolando Macajiling, Avelina Garceniego, and Shirley Garcenita from Antique; Gerardo Abadia Jr and Epifania Cacafranca from Davao City; Reidel Campo from Davao Oriental; and Rito C. Caractu from Lanao del Norte. Written byJeannie Javelosa, Monica Felicia P. Consing, Rene B. Javellana, Alice G. Guillermo, and Imelda C. Endaya, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz
