text:
Printmaking is the art of transferring images from a hard surface, like wood or metal, to a pliant surface, like paper or cloth, by means of pressure. This process, which is closely linked with the history of printing and publication, results in the mass production of art, making it accessible to a broader public or instrumental in promotion and propaganda.

Early Philippine printmaking was a facet of bookmaking and publishing, which developed as an instrument of Spanish colonization. The very first prints were thus designs or illustrations published in instructional books on catechism and prayers, which at times included lessons in alphabet, language, and practical science.

Xylography

Xylography is the Chinese method of printing from relief images cut on woodblocks. Wooden blocks are cut and planed to the size of two book pages. The surface is then coated with rice paste, on which a previously drawn design on paper is pasted. The reverse image registered on the wood is then cut. When carving is completed, the pasted paper is rubbed off. Ink is then applied on the uncarved surface, and paper is carefully impressed with a ball of cloth until the design is transferred onto the paper.

The very first print workshop using the woodblock method was improvised in San Miguel, Binondo, by the Spanish Dominican Francisco Blancas de San Jose and the Chinese convert Juan de Vera, a carver. In 1592 , they completed the Beng Sim Po Cam, a catechism book in Chinese. By 1593 they had printed three more books by the xylographic method: Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Española y Tagala (Christian Doctrine in the Spanish and Tagalog Languages); Doctrina Christiana en Letra y Lengua China (Christian Doctrine in the Chinese Script and Language); and Tratado de la Doctrina de la Santa Iglesia y de la Ciencias Naturales (Treatise on the Doctrine of the Holy Church and Natural Sciences), also known as Shih-lu.

The Doctrina Christiana en Lengua Española y Tagala is the best known and most artistic of these first books. It has for its frontispiece a portrait of Santo Domingo in symbolic array and setting. The print is unique for the Asian facial quality of Santo Domingo, the naive simplicity of the design, and its ornate frame. The same design was used for the Beng Sim Po Cam.

The Doctrina Christiana en Letra y Lengua China had on its cover an escudo de armas or coat of arms of the Dominican Order in medallion and scroll motif, said to have been taken from an emblem printed in Mexico, and printed by Keng Yong.

The Shih-lu had on its cover an illustration on the theme of Christianization of the sangley. The design shows a Dominican monk, a Chinese man in traditional costume, suggestions of the Great Wall of China, and elements of classical Western architecture.

Between 1600 and 1604, the first printing press of movable type was used in the same workshop by de Vera and San Jose. Thereafter, engravers and printers learned to cut individual letters on smaller blocks of wood so masterfully that carving of texts, ornaments, and emblems became more important than pictures. TomasPinpin, Jacinto Magarulao, Raimundo Mag-isa, and Andres de Belen are some of the names imprinted on the handcrafted books that survive today.

Some of the more notable woodblock designs printed by moveable type of the period were the Blessed Sacrament with angels on the title page of the Ilocano Doctrina Christiana, 1621, the seal of San Agustin in Arte de la Lengua Iloca (Grammar of the Ilocano Language) printed by Tomas Pinpin in 1627, the catafalque of Prince Baltazar Carlos printed by Simon Pinpin in 1649, and the coat of arms in Baltazar de Medina’s Sermon de la Inmaculada Concepcion (Homily on the Immaculate Conception) printed by Gaspar de los Reyes in 1672.

Several printing presses were subsequently established by the Franciscans, Jesuits, Augustinians, and the Ecclesiastical Seminary. But since engraving and printing during the colonial period were licensed occupations for official use, little artistry was encouraged.

Copper Engraving

The earliest known record of copper engraving in the Philippines is that of Juan Correa on the presentation of the Virgin at the Temple, printed in 1701 for the second edition of Las Ordenanzas y Constituciones de la Hermanidad de la Misericordia (Rules and Construction of the Fraternity of Mercy). Jeronimo de la Correa’s 1748 engraving of San Pedro Martyr Sanz, published in the book La Christianidad de Fogan (The Christianity of Fogan), is well preserved at the Lopez Museum.

In engraving a copper plate, a design is cut with a burin or graver. The deeper the tool penetrates into the plate, the wider the line; thus variations in tone and depth are achievable.

The 18th century is said to have been the golden era of Philippine engraving, primarily because of the work of the artists NicolasdelaCruzBagay, FranciscoSuarez, and LorenzoAtlas (previously identified as Laureano but with recent evidence seems to be Laurentius in Latin or Lorenzo in Spanish).

Among Lorenzo Atlas’s works that illustrate his masterful technique are his 1743 portrait of Fr Juan Angel Rodriguez printed in Esteban Roxas y Mello’s El Moyses Verdadero (The True Moses) and his 1749 engraving of the icons of the Virgen de la Rosa and Virgen de Paz y Buen Viaje.

It was customary to have estampas or prints of miraculous images made for distribution to devotees at their shrines. Atlas’s print of the Virgin may have originated as estampas. Smaller estampas used as markers in devotional books were called estampitas. During this era, a pasyon (a didactic verse narrative on the passion and resurrection of Christ) made its first appearance in print. This was GasparAquinodeBelen’s MahalnaPassionniJesuChristongPanginoon NatinnaTola (The Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse), which was appended to Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Calolouang Naghihingalo (Prayers of Guidance for the Soul of the Dying), first published in 1703. The 1760 edition of this Passion was illustrated with engravings by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay and FranciscoSuarez, with the assistance of Cipriano Bagay and Luis Suarez.

Felipe Sevilla, who could be the same engraver cited in Mexican prints of the same period, was active in Manila between 1789 and 1791. He also did a copperplate of the Last Supper dated 1789 and an engraving of the Carlos II funeral pyre dated 1791.

The craft of engraving was taught through an atelier system, wherein an apprentice was trained on the job by a master engraver. Often, the engraver was a different person from the printer, as inscriptions on extant prints indicate—for example, Felipe Sevilla sculpsit (engraved it) or Casimiro impressit (printed it). The atelier or guild was usually confined within the family as reflected in the common surnames of different generations. Otherwise, the friars, brothers of the religious order, and members of their community collaborated in the printmaking tasks. Other engravers and printers of the 1700s were Domingo Pauner, active circa 1702; Cipriano Bagay, active 1788-92; Luis Suarez, active 1737-60; Bachiller Casimiro de los Santos, active 1789-1798; Fr Hipolito Ximenez, active 1715-30; Fr Jose Azcarate, active 1752-72; Esteban de Sevilla, active 1790s; and Geronimo Atlas.

The 19th century saw a general decline in the quality of engravings. Most designs on religious and chancery themes were overused, perhaps an ill-effect of official standardization. A few exceptional works were those done on religious subjects by Ysidro Paulino, Bentura Javier, Vicente Atlas, Juan Atlas, and Carlos Borromeo.

Wood Engraving

Wood engraving is a variation of xylography. It developed in Europe with the use of movable type printing. This entails the use of an end block or the cross section of a tree. The hard and fine surface is not subject to the splintering that usually occurs when ordinary woodblocks are carved. Finer details could be engraved using the same tools for copper engraving. Among the finest examples of wood engraving still extant at the University of Santo Tomas Museum are La Bendicion de San Francisco (The Blessing of Saint Francis), the San Vicente Ferrer, and La Coronacion de Maria Reina de los Angeles (The Coronation of Mary Queen of Angels) by unknown artists of the late 19th century.

In the 19th century, subject matter also became more and more secular. Presses owned by businessmen and lay persons proliferated in Manila and challenged the dominance of friar-owned presses. Among the most productive of these were Amigos del Pais, Babil Sayo, and Chofre.

Lithography

Lithography, introduced in the early 19th century, proved to be a more efficient and economical method. The proliferation of catechism and novenas gave way to the more cosmopolitan journals.

In lithography, a design is done with a greasy crayon or paint on limestone. By chemical treatment based on the antipathy of oil and water, areas to be printed are isolated from areas not to be printed. Although a tedious process, results can be the most faithful duplications of pen-and-ink, crayon, watercolor, or sprayed paint texture.

Perhaps the most outstanding lithography done in the Philippines were those published in 1859-60 in the La Ilustracion Filipina, a magazine of general interest. A few line drawings were signed E. Evans and B. Giraudier. In the 1859 series, C. W. Andrews’s lithography of tipos del pais (country scenes) and landscapes were published, among them La Buyera (The Betel-Nut Vendor), El Tulisan (The Bandit), El Mediquillo (The Herb Doctor), Volcan de Albay (Albay Volcano), and PuenteColgante (Hanging Bridge).

Another publication with high-quality lithography was Ilustracion del Oriente, which serialized Cuadro de Costumbres de Filipinas, portraits and sceneries by C. Borner and C.W. Andrews.

With the introduction of photography in lithography printing for mass reproduction, handmade printmaking as a fine-art form vanished in the early 20th century.

Graphic Arts, 1946-2014

Printmaking reemerged after World War II due to several factors. The most important factor was the return from art studies of ManuelRodriguezSr and RodolfoParas-Perez from the United States in the late 1950s.

Both conducted workshops. Rodriguez Sr specialized in etching while Paras-Perez concentrated on the woodcut. Most contemporary printmakers at one time or other fell under the influence of the two. As teacher, Rodriguez Sr was exceptionally generous in imparting his skills. He was also instrumental in organizing the Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP) and introducing this as part of the fine arts curriculum of the Philippine Women’s University. Also notable is the initiative of other artists in introducing printing to artists and the public. In 1956, JuvenalSanso exhibited etchings he had done abroad. FernandoZobeldeAyala, RomeoTabuena, and ArturoLuz exhibited lithographs at the PhilippineArtGallery. During this period, HilarioFrancia, CenonRivera, and FlorencioConcepcion were also doing woodcuts. MauroMalangSantos popularized art by printing silkscreened images based on paintings by himself and his artist friends.

It is also in the 20th century that printmaking is clearly differentiated from reproduction. In the former, an artist creates the plate by hand or with the help of mechanical means. In the latter, creation of the plate and printing are totally done by mechanical process.

The fine-art print, which should not be confused with commercial reproduction, may be printed by the artist himself or may be printed by a technician under his supervision. An artist’s signature and numbering indicates the uniform quality of all prints pulled in a limited edition. When an edition is completed, the artist destroys the image on the plate.

Because prints are original artworks in multiples, it is viewed as a populist art form; hence the print became popular for expressing socially relevant themes, and could conveniently be exhibited simultaneously at various venues in traveling shows.

In the mid-1960s, a number of important printmakers emerged, among them VirgilioAviado, OfeliaGelvezon-Tequi, MarcelinoRodriguez, ManuelRodriguez Jr aka Boy Rodriguez, and LucioMartinez. Others who developed their printmaking skills while organizing the PAP were Florencia Mota, Josefina Escudero, EfrenZaragoza, Restituto Embuscado, NelfaQuerubin, BrendaFajardo, Adiel Arevalo, IviAvellana-Cosio, and Petite Calaguas.

Other artists whose print works are extensions of painting since they were painters first and printmakers second are JoseJoya, MarcianoGalang aka Mars Galang, BenedictoCabrera aka BenCab, JustinianoNuyda aka Tiny Nuyda, RaulIsidro, CesarLegaspi, RobertoChabet, and ManuelBaldemor.

Other printmakers most active in the 1970s were RaymundoAlbano, SantiagoBose, Benjamin Torrado Cabrera, OrlandoCastillo, Evelyn Collantes, FildelaCruz, ImeldaCajipe-Endaya, Romeo Gutierrez, IleanaLee, Al Manrique, Flora Mauleon, LitoMayo, FernandoModesto, Romulo Olazo, Nonon Padilla, MarioParial, ImpyPilapil, Rhoda Recto, Rey Rodriguez, RodolfoSamonte, Joel Soliven, and ManuelSoriano. Among the many printmakers who developed in the 1980s were NeilDoloricon, Jeannie Javelosa, OjengJocano, and Jonathan Olazo. Contemporary printmaking may be classified into three general categories: relief, intaglio, and planographic method.

In relief, the imprint comes from the surface of the block. Parts of the wood or metal block that are to be printed are left in relief and the remainder cut away. Impressions from the inked block can then be made with a press or even by hand. The principal relief methods are woodcut, wood engraving, lino-cut (linoleum), rubber-cut, metal-cut, relief printing, and collagraph. The collagraph is a technique for making plates involving the pasting of different materials on a base of masonite, wood, or cardboard. Lines or texture may also be drawn with the use of white glue from a fine-tipped vial. When the gluing is completely dried, the entire surface is coated with shellac or varnish to ensure smooth inking and printing.

If printed in relief method without an etching press, the degree of pictorial realism expressed is very limited. Consequently, most of such prints are highly stylized or abstract.

A variation of printing a relief is the inkless embossed print. This involves building or lowering a surface onto which damp paper can be molded and subjected to great pressure to transfer the design. Artists who have done outstanding relief prints are Rodolfo Paras-Perez, EfrenZaragoza, Manuel Soriano, and Mario Parial.

The principal methods of preparing a plate for intaglio printing are copper engraving, which includes drypoint and mezzotint; etching, which includes aquatint; and collagraph.

Intaglio refers to the printing method that is the opposite of relief; the printed image comes from the inks deposited in the grooves and lines beneath the surface of the plate. After inking a plate, its surface is wiped clean with rags. Damp paper is laid on the plate, covered with thick felt blankets and run through a press.

In engraving, an image is drawn on copperplate with a graver. In drypoint, lines are scratched with a steel needle. In etching, the plate is first covered with asphalt ground, then drawn over to create an image. This is then dipped in an acid bath to deepen the lines. Etching became more popular than engraving because the acid corrosion is considered a quicker but effective way of achieving the effects of engraving.

The majority of Filipino printmakers in the 1970s employed etching with aquatint as its versatility offered many creative possibilities. Aquatint is a method of using powdered resin for etching, which gives tonal effects similar to that of a wash drawing.

Engraving, the oldest intaglio process to be introduced in the Philippines, is hardly used today, quite a contrast from the times of Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay and Lorenzo Atlas. Engraving using machines is very much limited to the production of paper money. In mezzotint, an artist first makes use of a roulette and rocker to make a totally dark surface and to scrape white images on it. Since mezzotint is a physically demanding and time-consuming process, few artists have used it. Manuel Rodriguez Sr did a few mezzotints. Its main proponent today, Fil de la Cruz, has produced works of remarkable vision and mastery. His themes touching on ecology and survival are inspired by the tribal Filipinos who have preserved traditional Philippine culture.

A collagraph plate, if done in shallow recesses, can be printed the intaglio way. There are two advantages of collagraphy: first, the production of large and powerful images in a relatively short period of time; and second, the financial investment in plates is very small. This technique is still wide open to experimentation, since lines, textures, and tonal values can be built up in as many ways imaginable, and can have very painterly effects. Printmakers who have employed collagraphy are Romeo Gutierrez, Romulo Olazo, and Rey Rodriguez.

The planographic method includes lithography and serigraphy. A lithograph may be printed from a perfectly flat limestone slab or prepared from metal plates, usually zinc—hence the name zincography. Lithography is not widely used today because of the limited availability of limestone, which tends to crack with humidity, and the limited availability of the special press required for it. Most Filipino printmakers who have done lithographs have produced work during their sojourns abroad where presses are available. Among them are Juvenal Sanso, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, Arturo Luz, VirgilioAviado, GlennBautista, Jeannie Javelosa, Fernando Modesto, and Ben Cabrera.

The term “serigraph,” attributed to American Carl Zigrosser, was coined to distinguish art print from mass-produced silkscreened images. Serigraphy involves forcing ink through unstopped areas of silk or nylon mesh with a squeegee, a flexible rubber or synthetic blade on a handle. Rodolfo Samonte has made maximum use of serigraphy. From simple stencils of torn masking tape, he masterfully ran several repetitive layers of paint to create low-relief prints of various colors, tints, and shades. Imelda Pilapil has used serigraphy on cloth, paper, plastic, and glass. To produce the widest range of colors while reducing the number of plates and the runs used, the inking of plates was the subject of experimentation by American Stanley William Hayter in his Atelier 17. Because inks with differing viscosity or stickiness take more or less time in adhering to a surface, a single plate may be prepared using inks of differing viscosity when printed in a single run. The result is different colors placed over each other producing a third tone. Called the viscosity method, it is used by Gelvezon-Tequi for her prints.

Today, new printmaking techniques are being invented and old ones retrieved from commercial use. While photographic letterpress, photocopy offset, and computer images have become acceptable media of edition prints in the international market, the printmaker’s rule is that the artist creatively controls the making of the plate. In the 1990s onward, the revitalization of printmaking came through the reactivated PAP under the leadership of FildelaCruz and the Mariposa Workshop under the leadership of Virgilio Aviado. Scholarships in lithography have also been made available. There is increasing popularity in the use of woodcuts, rubber cuts, and serigraphy in many community craft-oriented workshops. Moreover, new printing technology has allowed work to be done on a variety of supports so much so that three-dimensional but still print-based work has become more and more possible. Examples of these are the virtually sculptural work done by Ambie Abaño and the glass works done by Benjie Cabrera. These confluences of factors and expanding practices offer richer and broader promise for the further development of Philippine printmaking. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Rene B. Javellana, and Jeannie Javelosa

Sources

text:
Sculpture is the art of making three-dimensional forms in space. Various materials and methods are employed in making sculpture. Sculptural forms can be freestanding, rendered in high- or low-relief, and may incorporate movement, light, and time as sensorial elements. Natural and synthetic materials are used through common methods modeling, casting, carving, assembling, constructing, or a combination of processes.

Three-dimensional art forms allow experience of volume and depth. Freestanding or in-the-round sculptures are viewed from all sides and surfaces with form freed from raw material. Relief sculptures, on the other hand, are hewn from surface material, portions of which remain evident. Low-relief or bas-relief sculpture has slight projections from surrounding surface while high-relief sculpture has greater and deeper incisions with forms that prominently project from the background. Some works adopt movement and light as sculptural elements. Assemblage, a putting together of three-dimensional elements and found objects, is generally a process of addition of usually unlike objects. Multimedia aka transmedia, mixed media, or intermedia works use materials that are two- and three-dimensional or both.

Sculpture employs methods of addition, reduction, or substitution. Pliable materials may be “added to” to produce form, while hard or rigid materials are “subtracted from” to reveal form. Mediums can be replaced or substituted with more permanent materials. However, contemporary sculptures deliberately use materials that are ephemeral, such as candle wax and lard, to connote temporariness and shifting meanings of the material. Malleable materials, such as clay, wax, or plaster, are shaped or “pushed into form” by hand. Often, inner support structures, called armatures, are used to keep desired shapes stable.

Carving takes away from the material to reveal form and is a technique used on wood and stone.

Casting is a replacement process. Casting involves using flexible materials for moulds to fashion forms into a more permanent medium. Metal, clay, plastics, and polyvinyl resin are some materials used for casting processes. Materials that liquefy can be poured into moulds, which function as patterns, and later used to produce works in their final form. Casting liquids are poured into the moulds, which can be broken up (lost-wax casting) or preserved to replicate works.

The Living Indigenous Tradition

Traditional sculpture of the ethnolinguistic groups of the Philippines are done using materials such as wood and stone manipulated through carving; in clay, by molding; and in metal, by casting. Carving involves removing material from wood or stone by using a metal implement, usually a chisel. Carving is found throughout the country and is used for ornamenting daily objects, like boats, ladles, furniture, and beams.

Wood carving in the Philippines is part of the ancient tradition of Malay wood carving in Southeast Asia. The art has retained its vitality through the centuries, from precolonial times to the present.

The native wood carving traditions are first of all found in the productions of cultural communities. The bulol are freestanding in-the-round images of granary gods or anito, ancestor, and nature deities. They may either be in a standing or a sitting position. If sitting, their rear ends do not touch the ground but are raised above it, their hands touching their knees or their arms resting across their knees, as in the traditional way of sitting in the outdoors when performing a ritual or simply banding together to talk by an open fire in the cold mountain air. Figures are frontal in presentation and planimetric, following the planes of the original wooden block. Facial features are simplified and lightly incised, with a geometricized tendency. There is no intention to represent a particular individual, as in a portrait, but the generalized features are deemed more appropriate in representing anthropomorphic deities of an archetypal cast. The articulation of the joints is less defined when the figure is in a standing position. Sometimes, stalks of rice, representing hair, rise from a small hollow in the head. As to its proportion, the bulol has short limbs with a big head.

An important characteristic is that the bulol are generally found in pairs, male and female. This pairing, which symbolizes the sexual principle, also signifies the value that society places on fertility, and the whole of nature—including all living things of the earth, water, and sky—multiplies and flourishes from the union of the archetypal man and woman. As granary gods, the bulol are found inside granaries. They do not only guard the harvest from insects and animals but also guarantee increasing yield.

An exception, however, is found among the Kiangan Ifugao. For them, the bulol do not come in pairs but are single figures. This is because their function here is centered on healing rituals. According to Peralta (1977), a ritual figure representing the sick person is carved, then called tat-tagu—no different in appearance and style from the usual bulol. This is consecrated and used in the healing ritual. If the person recovers, then its potency is recognized and is properly called bulol.

The same may also occur with the carved figures of animals, such as the pig, which is a common sacrificial animal. The carving of a pig is originally called binabbuy; it is later also called bulol after it participates in a successful healing ritual. Thus, according to Peralta (1977), the term bulol “suggests a generic term for types of consecrated images whether of similar configuration but differing in function or totally of different configuration and function.”

Among Cordillera houses, those of the Ifugao are the most sculptural. Wooden posts are carved with circular rat guards that prevent rodents from entering the house. Its walls and doors are of wood, usually carved with chevron patterns. Beneath the Ifugao house is the hagabi, a prestige bench owned by the affluent and carved from a single piece of hardwood. Its center is usually higher than the sides, thus forming a low arch or a squat chevron shape. The ends of the bench are carved with stylized animal heads, like the pig or boar. For the carving of the bench, the affluent throw a feast, called cañao (pagan religious feast in the mountainous regions), during which the bench is brought from the forest, where it has been carved, to the house of its owner. Other motifs carved in relief in the Cordilleras are human figures, lizards, snakes, and crocodiles.

The Tagbanwa of Palawan carve ritual animals from soft wood. Dyed black, these are incised with geometric designs, which show the natural light color of the wood. Among the Mindanao groups, the Maranao and the Tausug have a lively carving tradition. Called okir by the Maranao and ukkil by the Tausug, traditional carving shares a number of designs, although with distinct regional variations. One common motif is called sarimanok by the Maranao and manuk-manuk by the Tausug. The motif portrays a bird with a fish caught in its beak, among the Maranao, and without a fish, among the Tausug. Other Maranao motifs are the naga (snake), pako rabong (fern), the floral, as well as the star-and-bud motif.

These motifs apply to objects in everyday life. Among the Maranao, okir designs appear in the panolong or the flaring beams of the Maranao longhouse; in the giyaina-panagan (prow) of the Maranao boat; in kulintang (gong) stands; and also in tools and utensils, like the reed flattener for making mats, ladles, and coconut graters. Even the kubing (mouth harp), made from bamboo, is decorated with okir. Okir designs embellish the sunduk, the boat-shaped grave marker of the Tausug.

A traditional casting process is cire perdue or “lost wax,” a Malay technology of brass casting, which began before the 15th century in Sulu and is used to the present by a number of Philippine groups, such as the Maranao of Lanao and the Tboli of Cotabato.

The Hispanic Tradition and Local Transformations

The Spaniards introduced the tradition of carving in the Hispanic manner. Sculpture found its widest and most popular expression in the carving of santos. These were figures of Christ, the Virgin, and the saints usually three-dimensional, made of wood or ivory for religious devotions, and often placed in niches. As such, they could also be planimetric—that is, made up of flat two-dimensional planes of different shapes and arranged at angles to each other. Santos were also made in relieve (relief), which could be basso relieve (low relief), medio relieve (demi-relief), or alto relieve (high relief). Aside from santos found in church, there were santos for domestic devotions. Santos in churches were part of the retablo, the elaborate Hispanic altarpiece. In the houses of the rich, small santos were kept in urnas or miniature freestanding altarpieces; others were protected under virinas or cylindrical glass globes. During fiestas, especially in Lent, the santos were brought out of churches and homes and paraded on elaborate carrozas (floats) or andas (platforms).

The first santo came to the Philippines with the introduction of Christianity, the first recorded being that of the Santo Niño of Cebu, which was a gift of Magellan to King Humabon’s wife in 1521 and was found by Legaspi’s soldiers after their attack on the village in 1565. With the intensive activity of church building that occurred in the first centuries of Spanish colonization, more santos were needed for the retablos of the churches. During the centuries of the galleon trade, each galleon brought with it its patron image to guide and protect it during the long voyage. The most famous of these santos was NuestraSeñoradelaPazyBuenViaje (Our Lady of Peace and Good Voyage or Our Lady of Antipolo ), an image of the Inmaculada Concepcion that accompanied the galleon on several successful voyages on the Manila-Acapulco trade, and was brought from Mexico by Governor-General Niño de Tabora in 1626. In Naga, Nuestra Señora de la Peñafrancia (Our Lady of Peñafrancia) also draws large crowds to her shrine. Of the figures of Christ, among the most popular is the Quiapo Nazareno (Nazarene), an image brought from Mexico in the 1620s.

While some santos came from Spain through Spanish friars and officials, an undetermined number from Mexico, and some ivory images from Portuguese Malaca, in time most of the santos were made in the country by Filipino and Chinese santeros (carvers). FernandoZobel de Ayala suggests that the introduction of foreign prototypes occurred within a short period of time so that by the 17th century, there were enough carvers in Manila and elsewhere to meet the demand for santos. All the Christianized regions, including the Ilocos, the central Luzon provinces, and Visayan Provinces such as Cebu, Bohol, Samar, and Leyte, also had their santeros. Active centers were Paete, Laguna, and Betis, Pampanga, which have kept up the tradition to the present.

Santos carved for churches before the 19th century tended to be squat, with an accent on the face and hands, but almost always iconographically accurate. By the 19th century, the making of santos had reached a high point of artistic achievement. In Manila, particularly in the districts of Quiapo and Santa Cruz, there were excellent artisans who established shops or ateliers. Before the 19th century, santos were made by anonymous wood carvers; but in the mid-19th century, with the rise of the native merchant class from the opening of the country to international trade, higher artistic standards were demanded and a number of sculptors achieved considerable fame, such as LeoncioAsuncion, RomualdodeJesus, CrispuloJocson, and IsabeloTampinco. The second half of the 19th century saw the rise of secular themes in sculpture and the expansion of ilustrado (educated native) art patronage. Known sculptors of the time were BonifacioArevalo, GracianoNepomuceno, and Anselmo Espiritu who began a trend in genre sculpture and introduced nationalist themes, sometimes anticlerical.

By the 19th century, santos could both be found in churches and homes of the principalia or elite class. The religious sculpture were called poon by those who hold a panata (vow), which consisted of performative acts of devotion such as changing the clothes of the icon, kissing and wiping the exposed wood in the sculpture, carrying the image during processions, and singing the pasyon (verse narrative about the life and suffering of Jesus Christ) during Holy Week rituals at the home of the owner of the poon. These rituals are similar to rituals also done to the ancient bulol and other traditions for the dead in Southeast Asia, suggesting a hybridity of belief systems and cultural transformations that have continued to the present.

The art of making santos has continued to the 20th century, particularly in Paete where wood carving practiced at present owes much to the traditions established by the elders and the previous generations of Paete wood-carvers. Prominent among them are MarianoMadriñan and JoseCaancan. The former received high distinction at the Amsterdam exposition in 1883 (a year before JuanLuna won honors for Spoliarium ) when his Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother) won a gold medal over European entries, thereby drawing the attention of King Alfonso XII of Spain. It was during Madriñan’s time that the santero’s art reached its peak—with the highly realistic and expressive santos, life-size or larger.

Paete wood carvers introduced such refinements as movable, ball-and-socket joints at the shoulders, knees, elbows, and even fingers so as to make possible the portrayal of different gestures in a series of episodes, as in the passion of Christ. Delicate features and expressive, sad eyes are the hallmarks of Paete wood-carving art. Old secrets of the trade include light brown wavy hair made of piña fiber; eyelashes from monkey’s hair; and eyes of glass that are blown, shaped, and tinted in the center.

In Paete, families specialize in particular aspects of the art of wood carving, from the making of tools to the final painting and varnishing. Several generations of wood-carving families in Paete are the Madriñan, Caancan, Caguin, Cajipe, Edjawan, Madridejos, Fadul, Ac-Ac, Adao, Afunggol, Cagayat, Cagandahan, Baet, Bagabaldo, Baldemor, and Palatino.

The holy figures have their own prescribed iconography by which they are identified. San Roque points to a wound on his leg while a dog stands by his side, alluding to the ravaging plague and the dog that miraculously saved him. San Isidro Labrador stands with a shovel, at the same time that an angel works the field with a plow while the landlord gapes in amazement. Santa Lucia, who was blinded by her persecutors, holds her eyes on a tray.

The making of the polychromed santo, whether in the round or in relief, entails a painstaking process from the initial carving of the wood to its ornamentation. This involves laying on a whitish coat of gesso on the wooden surface to make it nonporous to paint or gilt. Medieval artists in Europe produced it from a mixture of plaster (dehydrated calcium sulphate) and size or glue. Santeros in the Philippines, like those from Paete, used materials, such as local kesong puti or white cheese mixed with glue. After priming with gesso, flesh-colored paint was applied directly onto the surface. In the 16th century a non-glossy matte finish was preferred in the interest of realism. Local santeros have also used the “ivory finish,” which simulated the milky pallor of ivory, considered an appropriate and precious material for the santo. For contrast, ivory was painted with flesh tones similar to those of the wooden images.

It is the process of encarnacion that maintained the tradition of giving a fair complexion to holy figures, since it defined flesh color and tone in Caucasian terms. For colonized societies, this gave both the saints and the colonial rulers a common cast and became influential in local standards of beauty. The process was applied to formal santos, particularly of the classical and baroque style; but it was not strictly observed in informal or folk santos, the characteristics of which were closer to the common people.

Occupying an important place in the history of Philippine art is the carving of ivory using elephant’s tusks from Africa and India obtained in the Philippines through trade with China and mainland Southeast Asia. Ivory carving according to the Western tradition was introduced in the last quarter of the 16th century by the Spaniards, who first commissioned carvers from Southeastern China for images of the crucified Christ and of the Virgin Mary. By the first third of the 18th century, accounts extolled the artistic skills that Filipinos learned from the Chinese. Finely carved santos imbued with Oriental features (oval face, heavy-lidded almond eyes, stiff postures) became popular gifts and souvenirs, which were shipped to Spain and Mexico. It may be surmised that the trade in Philippine ivory images was far greater than those dealing with similar ivories from Goa (Portuguese India), Sri Lanka, China, and Mexico.

Whole statues were carved in the round from segments of tusks. In many instances only the heads, hands, and feet were made of ivory and attached to a carved wooden body or pyramidal conical bastidor (frame), which was meant to be covered with vestments of cloth or metal. In some impressive examples, a wooden structure was completely enclosed in several pieces of ivory to produce an even larger santo. Perhaps the oldest dated ivory work dating from 1587 is a crucified Christ in the church of the Magdalena in Sevilla; it is the prototype of many later crucifixes, with arched back and head pointed upward. A possible early piece is the set of ivory head and hands of Nuestra Señora del Santisimo Rosario (Our Lady of the Holy Rosary) or LaNaval, commissioned in 1593, and presently venerated in the SantoDomingoChurch in Quezon City. Dated 17th-century pieces are the San Sebastian (Saint Sebastian), Ignacio de Antioquia (Ignatius of Antioch), and the image of the crucified Christ and others in the church of Santa Maria in Medina de Rioseco, Villadolid, Spain, which are masterpieces of their genre yet are unusual even for some of the atypical “open” poses of the saints; and the San Francisco and Santo Domingo in the monastery of San Esteban, Salamanca, Spain, which still manifest characteristics of the earlier, archaic style, such as elongation and the graceful curve of the body following that of the tusk from which it was carved. A still extant set of 12 ivory figures for a choir lectern, including a Nuestra Señora de la Asuncion (Our Lady of the Assumption) and various saints, reached Mexico circa 1770 and was a gift to the cathedral there from the archbishop of Manila. Among the most talented of the ivory carvers were JuandelosSantos who carved the flawless crucifix in the SanAgustinChurch, and Leoncio Asuncion, who worked in the artistic enclave of Santa Cruz, Manila. Like his colleagues, he also carved in wood. Two of his religious works may be seen at the Ayala Museum in Makati. Graciano Nepomuceno was the last of the “old school” of ivory carvers whose works express sophistication of technique. Today, occasional ivory statues are done by a few artists, like FredBaldemor and EsmeraldoDans—both from Paete, Laguna.

In his study of religious art, GaloB.Ocampo classified santos into formal and informal types. Formal types were the santos found in churches, which thus showed a high level of artistry. Large in size and richly ornamented, these were done under the strict supervision of friars with respect to correct iconography or prescribed content and manner of representation in order that no “pagan” or heretical element was introduced. On the other hand, the informal santos, usually smaller in size, were used for private devotions and were freer in execution, thus showing folk qualities.

Fernando Zobel de Ayala (1963) classified the santos into classical, popular, and ornate. Classical santos either came from Europe or were done locally with a strong academic influence. Often carved in wood, these observed the classical proportions of 7½ to 8 heads to the standing figure. The representation of drapery was in regular, symmetrical folds; the general appearance of the figure was one of formality, balance, and restraint. In a style different from the classical, the ornate santos also showed strong European influence from the school of the Spanish artists Pedro de Mena and Alonso Caño who emphasized emotionalism and realistic detail. Of wood or ivory, they were more richly embellished and more expressive than the classical. The third group, the popular santos, did not observe classical proportions; thus they often had big heads and squat or elongated bodies. Their features were more native than the classical and baroque types, which were of a Caucasian cast with their deep-set eyes and aquiline noses. It is possible that the early folk santos continued the precolonial sculptural tradition in the carving of anitos marked by animistic vigor.

Jose (1991) proposed that the santo be classified according to the scheme found in church inventories—that is, de bulto (from which is derived the Filipino term for the statue rebulto), for fully carved figures including drapery; de gozne, for figures that were dressed but had articulated hands; and de bastidor, for figures that were a mere head and hands on a frame.

Another instance of a local response to the presence of religious sculptures is the urna tradition in Bohol. This is a small carved shrine for religious images, joined by wooden pegs and features a wooden screen door (Jose 1991, 212). The urna’s basic parts are the following: the niche where the religious image is placed; the forward tilting crown, the topmost decorative element; the arbotantes, a pair of decorative volutes flanking the niche; and the gradillas, a pyramidal structure of small steps where the main body of the urna is mounted. An urna may be considered the miniature counterpart of the church retablo, the decorated backdrop of the altar where images of the saints are usually placed. The urna is designed for small places of prayer, such as chapels, convents, and home altars.

Aside from the santo, more mundane types of carving were the result of Hispanic heritage. Carvers in Pakil, Laguna, make the pahiyas-tambag (ornamental toothpick trees and fans) through the process of kayas (wood whittling or wood shaving). The Tree of Life centerpieces have detachable branches to embellish colorful rice dishes, tufted birds, and airy butterflies with curling antennae, which are arranged in tapering, graduated tiers above a circular base like a symmetrical spreading bouquet. The fans, in natural ecru like the trees, are carved from palo sapis, a single block of softwood, with thin and even blades spreading out in feathery grace. The fan sports a chain of two complete rings with a pendant bird at the end of the handle, all made from the same single bar of wood. The local names of the variety of softwoods used in kayas are lanite, batikuling, amlang, and quetana. Prior to World War II, townsfolk created a hair ornament called payneta, perhaps the local version of the Spanish peineta worn by the elite. A few families, such as that of Emeterio San Gaspar, still practice the tradition, albeit with a redefined purpose as souvenirs for tourists, weddings, and other celebrations.

The Betis carving tradition comes from an old precolonial practice of matenakandadaras or boat carving in Pampanga. Over time, thestyles, medium, designs, and techniques of Betis carvers(known as mandukit) have evolved because of cultural amalgamation and exchanges with the Chinese andSpaniards. In the Spanish colonial period, productions were done in response to Spanish religious commissions to createreligious icons and interiordesigns for the Santiago Apostol Church aka Betis Church. The retablo or thefront altarpiece bears resplendent floral ornamentation with some parts covered with gold leaf. The religious statues follow Western classical form and iconography. The main doorway has its own carving depicting the stairway to heaven—that is, anallegory drawn from the story of Jacob’s dream as found in the book of Genesis, where angels ascend to heaven through a flight of stairs. Betis carving practices also have along history of transpacific maritime trading and exchanges with the Europeans during the colonial period.

Betis has produced important sculptors through the years, operating local studios and workshops that sustained families and community members during difficult times. Juan Flores (1900-92) is considered to have revived the wood-carving practices of Betis. He isknown to be one of the key carvers of the ornaments at Malacañan Palace during the Marcos period. He has also served as the mentor of several generations of carvers in Betis. Carlos Roque Sr is known for his detailed wood carving and craftsmanship in furniture making. Wilfredo Layug is known both for his ecclesiastical work andcontemporary sculptures. His works often consist of hyperrealistic designs and figures. After the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in 1991, a few sculptors experimented with lahar or mudflow to produce sculptural pieces.

Wood carving also plays an important role in furniture making, as seen in furniture made in Betis, Pampanga. Its high moments were in the mid-19th century with the advent of cash-crop agriculture, and in the 1960s when it benefited from the National Cottage Industry and Development Authority program promoted by the Philippine government to uphold the development of cottage industries. Wood-carving tools, so important to the art, are produced in Apalit, Pampanga. The woods used are narra, of the red and yellow varieties, and acacia. Carvers who begin in their teens, execute design patterns on cardboard cutouts. The shops produce gallineras (benches), aparadores (cabinets), console tables, coffee tables, and headboards. The gallineras of Betis show the furniture at its most refined development: the narra in two tones, polished and varnished to a high sheen; and the square panels featuring carved rosettes flanked by small, neatly turned balusters for the backrest and the enclosure below. More colonial aspects are the tables and the armoires with motifs derived from European period-furniture styles. Recognizably baroque are the motifs of the unfurling scrolls meeting at the center, the concave shells everting delicately around the edges, the medallions and cartouches, and the occasional broken pediments and Solomonic columns. These motifs are found in conjunction with elements of local origin, such as rosettes and other organic curvilinear motifs, as well as the row of small balusters. Betis wood carving is distinguished by the motifs and figures carved in bold relief or intricate openwork as the hardwoods permit. It likewise exhibits a heavy, opulent character from baroque influence.

During the Spanish colonial period, sculpture in stone were often used to ornament facades. These were made into escudos or stone reliefs of coats of arms usually ornamenting the main portal of a building. A striking example of stone relief is the Rendicion de Tetuan (The Surrender of Tetuan) found in the San Joaquin Church in Iloilo and the relief of San Cristobal, amidst a tropical landscape, found in the facade of the Miag-aoChurch in Iloilo.

Metal casting, although to a limited degree, was also practiced in colonial times. An effigy of King Carlos IV, cast in the foundry of Manila, was installed in front of the ManilaCathedral where it still stands today. Silver was a material used for casting or chasing small figures like reliefs that decorated the portapaz (a small tablet, generally of silver, with a religious image in relief in front and a handle at the back). A rare example of silver sculpture is the image of San Pedro de Alcantara found in the Nagcarlan Church in Laguna. Folk works that use brass casting are the anting-anting (talisman). Rooted in the Spanish period’s religious traditions, brass anting-anting take various forms, such as medals, triangles, crosses, the crucified Christ, and the Santo Niño. Often a script in corrupt Latin is found on the faces of the medal-type anting-anting. Cavite and Batangas are the two provinces where brass anting-anting are made.

The American Tradition and Local Transformation

With American colonization at the turn of the century, new influences in sculpture appeared: classicism, art nouveau, and art deco. IsabeloTampinco pioneered in the local art nouveau idiom by introducing indigenous motifs like the pineapple and the anahaw leaf for his carvings. Art nouveau’s curvilinear style and art deco’s geometric lines, applied to furniture and to all kinds of functional objects, proved to be a lively creative stimulus to local carvers.

By the beginning of the 20th century, sculpture projects commissioned by the state would be exemplified by Rizal Monument, 1913, by Swiss sculptor Richard Kissling. The bronze work is done in the classical style with the national hero Jose Rizal at center, flanked by allegorical figures and obelisk. However, the period is dominated by the classical sculptures of GuillermoTolentino exemplified by the Oblation , 1935, and its bronze cast versions installed at the University of the Philippines campuses. His Bonifacio Monument , 1933, is done in the Beaux Arts tradition of classicism and romanticism, wherein Bonifacio stands resolute in the middle of the group of Katipuneros depicted with strong emotions and movement. Other artists who carried on this tradition are AnastacioCaedo, Ambrosio Morales, Froilan Madriñan, and JoseMendoza. TingPingLay is among the modern figurative sculptors most active in the 1950s, while Fred Baldemor emerged with his classico-romantic portraits in wood and ivory in the 1970s. JulieLluch, AgnesArellano, DanRaralio, and Peter de Guzman are among the later generation figurative-expressionist sculptors.

The introduction of modern sculpture is associated with the work of NapoleonV.Abueva who dominated modern sculpture for several decades. Abueva used the so-called noble material—hardwood, metal, and stone—for sculpture, whether these be in relief or in the round. He lent sculpture the quality of living fluidity and the impression of movement and action.

Bronze casting, practiced extensively during the pre-World War II period by sculptors who made public sculptures for monuments, is hardly practiced by contemporary artists because of its prohibitive cost. AbdulmariImao was known for his cast works depicting modern interpretations of traditional okir motifs, like the sarimanok.

The traditional methods of creating sculpture by carving or casting have been augmented by contemporary techniques or forms—such as welding, assemblage, and the construction of mobiles using nontraditional material, like glass, plastic, bamboo, and even vegetable matter and earth.

Welded sculptures involve making objects by bonding together sheets of metal by electric or acetylene torch. EduardoCastrillo dominated the field of sculpture in the 1960s and the 1970s by creating monumental and environmental sculptures, in the abstract and figurative idiom, and some with social and historic meanings, in the medium that became his trademark—welded metal. Monumental public sculptures are exemplified by Castrillo’s Katipunan, 1974, at the Pinaglabanan Shrine, San Juan, and People Power Monument, 1993, at Libis, Quezon City, which celebrate heroic themes. Kublai Milan has also done monumental sculptures in Mindanao, such as The Durian , 2003, done in concrete, for the Davao International Airport, appropriating the image of the halved native fruit incorporated with motifs evoking the multiplicity of ethnic identities in the region. IldefonsoMarcelo did abstract works in concrete and stone in the 1960s. SolomonSaprid, J.ElizaldeNavarro, and VirginiaTy-Navarro also use welded bronze. ArturoLuz created abstract pieces using painted metal pipes.

The mobile is a three-dimensional work of sculpture that, instead of being made to stand on the ground or on a horizontal base, is suspended from the ceiling or from a projecting element. It usually consists of one or several balancing rods, principal and secondary, from which hang a number of elements, figurative or nonfigurative, in varying lengths. American sculptor Alexander Calder was the first to create mobiles, inspired by simple organic shapes. He was followed by the constructivists who worked in chrome and plexiglass, with their transparent and reflecting qualities.

A mobile can be considered a simple form of kinetic sculpture or sculpture in motion because it moves with the wind or vibrates with the surrounding air. Furthermore, its suspended form casts moving shadows and light reflections on the environment. As such, an essential character of the mobile is that it creates a continuous interplay of the sculptural form with its surrounding space. This interaction of solid and space is part of the concept of mobile sculpture in which the work is viewed not only in terms of its solid mass but also in terms of what is called its “virtual volume,” as space becomes a positive value.

Castrillo has done mobiles in chrome and plexiglass with modular elements. RamonOrlina has also done mobiles in painted metal. Simpler and more familiar types are wind chimes that have the additional element of sound. Popular mobiles of Philippine folk art are the colorful kiping chandeliers called arangya, which are made of rice wafers decorating the Pahiyas festival in Lucban and Sariaya, Quezon.

Contemporary sculptors continue to experiment and develop new materials. Lamberto Hechanova introduced in his works colored metal and plexiglass. Anatascio Caedo, a classicist, experimented with “cold casting,” a process involving the use of marble dust and polymers. Orlina pioneered in glass sculpture, where glass blocks are shaped by abrasives and adhesives to form prismatic or anthropomorphic shapes. FranciscoVerano used bamboo for sculpture, while ImpyPilapil uses glass with serigraphed patterns, stone, iron rods, galvanized-iron sheets, and screens for her sculptures, some of which are decorative as well as functional, like her furniture pieces. Kinetic sculpture, which adds movement to the art form traditionally presented as static, had its earliest expression in the performance artist DavidMedalla’s BubbleMachine. Earth art is produced through the modifying and positioning of material like poles, windbreaks, or walls, that may be dug up or rearranged. In the 1970s, Raymundo Albano advocated this among artists of Mount Makiling. Junyee is also among the foremost practitioners of this art. RobertoVillanueva’s maze, made of runo and other local reeds, is also an example of this type of sculpture.

From the 1990s onward, many artists have used installation as a means to explore postcolonial perspectives in understanding Filipino faith and identity. For example, the traditional sculptures such as the santo are reimagined by Riel Hilario to evoke issues of memory of place and sense of displacement, as he works with wooden furniture from his hometown. On the other hand, the bulol is recontextualized by Gaston Damag’s reflection of claimed identities in diaspora, in one instance using candle wax to effect the transformation of the bulol figure, which eventually melted inside the museum. Leeroy New, Gerry Leonardo, Rodel Tapaya, Kawayan de Guia, and Toym Imao have also explored installations invoking motifs from pop and folk culture, and history as they have employed materials from everyday life. Alwin Reamillo recuperates objects, such as an already grounded military helicopter, to invoke the notion of “social sculpture” participated in by children from internally displaced communities. Agnes Arellano and Julie Lluch continue to work on themes touching on questions of gender and subjectivity in their sculptures. Gender issues were also explored by Francesca Enriquez when she used soft lard in her past work. Alma Quinto uses recycled clothes for her soft sculptures, while Marina Cruz created sculpture from casts of baptismal dresses to reflect on handed down memory via objects that embody societal structures. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, Santiago A. Pilar, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, and Regalado Trota Jose, updated by Tessa Maria C. Guazon, Cecilia S. De La Paz, Dino Carlo S. Santos, and Clod V. Yambao

text:
Sound art or sonic art is an art form that covers a wide range of activities wherein sound is utilized as a medium. It is inherently interdisciplinary and may draw elements from the traditional visual arts, music, performance, media arts, and installation, among others. Many sound-related activities and works are related or influenced by music, but it is also possible for them to have nothing to do with music at all. It is also not necessary for these to take a physical form.

However, the term “sound art” in the Philippines is also often used interchangeably with experimental music. It is possible to distinguish practitioners who are musicians, but venues, events, and audiences are often shared. Most exhibitions that highlight sound art have performance activities of sound artists and experimental musicians woven together. Performances do not necessarily involve the exhibiting artists creating sound themselves. Their work may feature a lineup that have features parallel to musical events. The boundary between sound art and music is further blurred by frequent collaboration between sound artists and those more commonly described as experimental musicians.

The composer and National Artist for music Jose Maceda, also known for his work in ethnomusicology, is considered a major influence on sound art in the country. Cassettes 100, 1971, his first attempt in using electronic devices in a composition, involved 100 participants carrying cassette tape recorders that played an assortment of sounds. Ugnayan, 1974, on the other hand, consisted of prepared music getting played across 20 radio stations. In 1975, Roberto Chabet assisted Maceda in Udlot-Udlot by designing the ground layout for performers.

The collaborative group Liwayway Recapping Co., composed of Roberto Chabet, Ray Albano, and Boy Perez, held the exhibition Illumination in 1970. It was one of the first attempts to incorporate sound within an exhibition context. The group mainly designed sets for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and in this exhibition referenced that function.

David Medalla also created sonar sculptures and sonic installations that utilized different electronic devices, which included tape recorders, microphones, megaphones, loudspeakers, and oscilloscopes. An example of this was the participatory artwork Listen to the Sonar Trees, 1972. Medalla’s performative work, however, has been mostly performed and shown outside the Philippines.

Agnes Arellano has called some of her works “sound sculpture” and “music composed through sculpture.” With a musical background as a singer in her younger days, her soundworks have representations consisting of Western musical notation and staff, and are sometimes accompanied by their interpretations recorded on a cassette tape or compact disc. Examples include Music for Watching the Moon Rise, 1983; Music for Making the Sun Rise, 1987; and Lingga Mantra, 1990 (Guillermo).

Other artists who have experimented with sound since the 1980s are Orville Tiamson, who conjured “paintings” meant to be seen in the mind of the audience by playing music on his synthesizer; Cesare Syjuco, whose work included radio and telephone soundworks; and Jean Marie Syjuco, whose series Toys for Grownups also incorporated sound (Gatbonton et al. 1992).

In the early 1990s, Baguio-based Shant Verdun, inspired through meditation, released under his Lampas Isip Productions (literally, Beyond Imagination Productions), recordings on tape that blended indigenous instruments, experimental music, and recorded environmental sounds. “Lampas Isip” also refers to consciousness or soul, thus he used sound elements and musical modes that have meditative and healing effects on the mind.

A venue for music gigs, Red Rocks, later Club Dredd, was a venue for two groups that became significant in the development of sound art in the Philippines. Intermidya, founded by Lirio Salvador in 1986, was the first group to highlight homemade musical instruments. They used sound-producing assemblage works called Sandata (Weapon) but have since become more associated today with the band Elemento, founded by Salvador in 1996. The individual sandata since the mid-2000s have become popular as exhibition pieces. In 2012, a show in Vargas Museum featuring the sandata was dedicated to the by then immobilized Lirio Salvador.

Children of Cathode Ray had its first performance in Red Rocks in Nov 1988. Its members were also habitués of the place: Regiben Romana, Magyar Tuason, Jing Garcia, Tad Ermitaño, and Blums Borres. Three of the members, Romana, Tuason, and Ermitaño, also went to the Mowelfund Film Institute, which explains how experimental film was a major influence for the output of the group. Initially only creating sounds, a visual component was later added using Ermitaño’s projector and digital manipulation and algorithmic intervention.

Some sound artists employ monikers, thus Jing Garcia aka autoceremony, Tad Ermitaño, and Blums Borres aka Loom would eventually perform as individual sound and media artists taking on the names they adopted to this later practice. Ermitaño, now a known media artist, has created sound works that do not require him to perform, such as Robot Gamelan Quartet, which was included in the main juried exhibition of the 2008 International Symposium on Electronic Art (ISEA2008) and exhibited in the National Museum of Singapore. Quartet was a generative installation that any member of the audience could interact with as a “conductor” of its virtual musicians.

Salvador’s Intermedia and Elemento, and Children of the Cathode Ray eventually also performed in art spaces like Mag:net and the CCP. These groups continue to have performances, although which specific members would be playing at a specific event can vary.

In the mid-1990s, Poklong Anading, Kaloy Olavides, and Jose Beduya formed the group Gitaw while they were still students at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts. All three played around with sound art at that time, but Olavides later emerged to be the most active in it. Olavides, soon after their disbandment in the late-1990s, would also join Elemento as a member. In recent years, he formed PastilanDong!, recruiting fellow visual artists Pow Martinez, Costantino Zicarelli, and Alvin Zafra as his bandmates. The band also incorporates noise in their sound work.

The label Documento was formed by Ernest Concepcion and Mads Adrias in 1999. It was grant-funded by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and its first project was framed as a spoken word undertaking. The first release of the label was Uno Documento Compilo, a compilation compact disc that included an eclectic mix of artists that had “one similar ability, they could produce ‘sounds.’” This compilation included Gitaw and Elemento.

Surrounded by Water, the alternative art space founded by Wire Tuazon, operated from 1998 to 2004. It annually celebrated its anniversary on 29 Mar with a “ Sound Art ” event, unaffected by the art space’s location changes. Tuazon had already been working with sound in his individual art practice and organized these annuals to encourage other visual artists to extend their practice by using sound as a medium as he asked for submissions of audio recordings.

Experimental music events also became venues for sound art. Around 1999-2001, Malek Lopez and Noel de Brackinghe, who together also make up Rubber Inc, organized a series of events called Recitals that were held in a place called Kemistry in Malate. Arvin Nogueras, Caliph8, a popular hip-hop DJ with a tendency toward the abstract side of the genre, held his first Subflex event in Verve Room, Malate, in Jan 2001. He would hold succeeding ventures in various places before it became a monthly event at B-Side at The Collective in Makati from 2009 to 2013, though it has been on hiatus since. Nogueras also organized Expansions with Mark Young aka Mark Zero from 2006 to 2010. It was held in different venues but most frequently at Penguin Café in Malate.

The setting up of Experimentation in Sound Art Tradition (E.X.I.S.T.) was instigated by Salvador in 2002. It is a loose organization of sound artists and musicians, but the core group is made up by Salvador’s Elemento bandmates and others based in Cavite and Marikina, such as Erick Calilan aka Ugong, Roger Lopez aka Inconnu Ictu, Jon Romero aka Aurora Borealis, and Chris Garcimo aka Blend:er of the band Gentle Universe. E.X.I.S.T. aims to inform and educate people about sound art as an interdisciplinary form. They have sought to do this by exploring and manipulating found objects, environmental sound, and analog and digital audio technologies. In 2002, their first sound art exhibition was held with performances by Elemento and Transitory Form in Club Sound Experience, Makati. They also released a split album CD of Elemento and Transitory Form at the same event.

SABAW Media Art Kitchen was founded by Earl “Tengal” Drilon and Pow Martinez in 2005. In contrast to E.X.I.S.T., SABAW’s scope of interest covers the wider picture of media art. It is not as concentrated on sound as medium. Drilon’s space, Terminal Garden in Mandaluyong, was often used as an event venue, work lab, hacker space, and temporary homestay for visiting artists until 2015. SABAW produced monthly experimental music events at Mag:net Café, Katipunan, in the last quarter of 2005. This led to the release of an anthology of noise, electronic, and experimental music in CD format, 2006.

Drilon’s practice as an interdisciplinary artist parallels this scope as the range of his work has included new media, sound, music, video, cinema, and performance. He is also the progenitor of the Gangan Ensemble, a loose improvisational performance group composed of sound and video artists. Ermitaño also plays a key role in the group by creating digital visualizations that function as notation for the performance. The other collaborators include Malek Lopez, Arvin Nogueras, and Blums Borres.

Prior to establishing himself as a painter, Pow Martinez undertook sound art projects as Nun Radar. He was also part of Nasal Police, working with Donna Miranda and Ria Muñoz as they combined sound performances with contemporary dance.

The development of the sound art scene has thus far progressed through the formation of E.X.I.S.T. and SABAW. Both groups were instrumental in building networks between sound artists and disseminating their work. Meanwhile, in 2007, sculptor Reginald Yuson was commissioned to create artworks in Bonifacio High Street and this enabled the making of sound art in an accessible form for a broader public. Yuson’s work Presence, consists of large freestanding chimes, while another work called Hearsay, is made up of pipes partially buried in the ground. The structure is set up to allow sound to travel from one point of the ground to another.

From Oct 2007 to Feb 2009, Children of the Cathode Ray members Borres, Jing Garcia, and Ermitaño organized events under their group New Media Arts Manila. It came after Borres’s return from Australia, where he did volunteer work in Melbourne for Liquid Architecture, an Australian organization for artists working with sound. The events they organized included three editions of their Electrostatic Sound Conferences, Minus Ten Decibels, and Field Trip. By the time of Field Trip, however, their name was changed to Media Arts Manila.

In 2008, SABAW held a small two-day festival called Fete dela Wasaque, later Fete dela WSK. The name is both foil and pun on the popular French music festival Fete dela Musique, which at one juncture failed to materialize in Manila temporarily. By WSK organizers’ own accounting, however, the festival was not taken seriously even by its own proponents until 2010, when its name was changed to Fete dela WSK, and further shortened to WSK in 2014.

The 2010 edition of Fete dela WSK had activities spread out over 10 days and had an exhibit component that focused on sound art. Dubbed From Here to Ear, it was held in Outerspace Gallery at The Collective, Makati. It featured works by Ermitaño and Kawayan de Guia. The edition the following year also exhibited works in Ronac ART Center, NOVA Gallery, and Light & Space Contemporary. This edition was more diverse in its elements with installation works that were not sound-based, video art, digital art, and Internet art. The sound art that was exhibited included a work by Claro Ramirez and a collaboration between Salvador and Neil Arvin Javier, A.lien.

The first institution to hold an exhibit dedicated to sound art was the Lopez Museum in 2011, through an exhibition curated by Claro Ramirez and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez. Reverb featured works by Eric Ambata, de Guia, Ermitaño, IC Jaucian, Diokno Pasilan, Ronald Tomas, E.X.I.S.T., and ethnomusicologist Dr Christine Muyco. It had an off-site component in SM Mall of Asia, Pasay City, that was also part of Zero In’s museum consortium art festival in 2011.

Listen to My Music, an exhibition dedicated to Jose Maceda, was curated by Dayang Yraola in the Vargas Museum, 2013. It had a section of works by sound artists influenced by Jose Maceda. The artists included Calilan, Drilon, Ermitaño, autoceremony, Paolo Garcia aka Pasta Groove, Garcimo, Malek Lopez, Armi Millare, Nogueras, and Romero.

Later that year, Yraola and Lian Ladia co-curated the Manila leg of Media/Art Kitchen, a series of media art events supported by Japan Foundation. It had an installment at the Ayala Museum that featured sound works by de Guia, Renan Ortiz, and Manny Montelibano. It also opened with performances: Mel Araneta collaborated with Bani Haykal from Singapore for a performance using handmade improvised or do-it-yourself (DIY) instruments; Calilan and Paolo Garcia’s collaboration featured noise and samples in audio and video formats; and Nogueras and Mannet Villariba together created a performance combining sound, performance art, and video.

Media/Art Kitchen in Manila also collaborated with Fete dela WSK in 2013 to create WSK.FM, a pirate radio station set up in Green Papaya Art Projects, Quezon City. This aimed to explore analog and digital radio as both a means of distribution and medium for sound art. WSK.FM would support Radyo Itim, a component of Jong Pairez’s CIV:Lab, which saw a more activist use of radio within the context of contemporary art. Along with Pairez, Radyo Itim was co-founded by Randy Nobleza and DJ Seitan.

Many sound artists are inclined toward experimentation and invention. Garcimo, who creates musical instruments using coconut shells, began to organize Musiko Imbento events at Sev’s Café, Malate, 2013. He designed this to function as part mini-workshop for the use of DIY musical instruments and also partly as performance platform for sound artists and experimental musicians. Participants have included Garcimo, Elemento, Jean Paul Zialcita, Harvey Vasquez aka Wiquwi, Inconnu Ictuo, Pasta Groove, Gentle Universe, Calilan, Joe Estimo, JP Hernandez, Joon Guillen, Modulogeek, Ros Veluz, Ermitaño, autoceremony, Romero, and Richard John Tuason. Written byIris de Ocampo, with notes from Merv Espina
