text:
Tattooing is a process of marking one’s skin permanently with ink or pigment made of plant dyes applied by sharp instruments like needles or thorns. These inking implements pierce the fleshy membrane to create designs and patterns that may signify various meanings and symbols to the wearer or to the society to which he or she belongs. The term tattoo is derived from a Polynesian noun: ta-tau of the Samoan, and ta-tu from the Marquesan, which means to mark the skin with pigment. Western voyagers identified this term during imperial transcontinental journeys made in the mid-18th century. However, the traditional practice of tattooing has much earlier roots in ancient civilizations as evidenced in archeological finds, which include tattooing tools, implements, and preserved mummies with markings on their skin. Tattoos had several functions and meanings orally relayed to generations of people during ancient times and even up to the current period. Some of these were to serve as a form of adornment, to enhance physical appearance, to function as a form of representation of religious beliefs, to protect against evil spirits, to show a mark of bravery of an individual or group, to identify a group or ethnicity, to document significant events in one’s life, to categorize one’s vocation, and to symbolize one’s social status.

The practice of tattooing in the Philippines predates the writings of the Spanish chroniclers who encountered and witnessed firsthand the culture and society of the Pintados (Painted Ones) of the Visayan Islands during their initial contact in the mid-16th century. The Boxer Codex, 1590, includes the image of the Pintados of the “Bissayas” (Visayas). The bodies of the two figures are covered by tattoos from their heels to their faces. The male’s tattoos are displayed frontally while the female’s tattoos are shown from the back. The elaborate tattoo designs feature geometric shapes contouring to the shape of the wearer and showing similarities with indigenous textile motifs. If the images in the Boxer Codex can be considered a tipos del pais (country scenes), the tattoo of the Pintados may be seen as a kind of clothing during that time.

The process of tattooing among the Pintados required a highly skillful tattoo artist to execute the markings and designs on the skin using black soot as outline before embedding the sharp comblike thorns that served as the needle to puncture the skin. This allowed the soot to be absorbed by the epidermis while the wound is still fresh. The process was done gradually for it sometimes caused the tattooed individual to get infected. Their tattoos signified the skill and bravery of the victorious warriors who engaged in wars and battles. Elaborate designs of lines and geometric patterns were marked on the skin. Tattoos were added only after successful battles, thus increasing the markings from the ankles, to the legs and thighs, until the hips. Chest and back tattoos were rendered when the warriors defeated the enemies in another battle. Tattoos on the face were reserved only for the fiercest and bravest warriors (Scott 1994). Women were tattooed as well. Their arms were adorned by intricate crisscrossing of lines, geometric shapes and motifs that signified their status in the society. This tattooing tradition among the Visayans is hardly practiced anymore, having been replaced during and after the Spanish period by anting-anting or amulet tattoo with Christian icons as popular motifs.

While Spanish colonization and the propagation of Christianity sought to obliterate the custom, tattooing also persisted on a limited scale for the purpose of indicating brotherhood among the revolutionary peasant movements from the mid-19th century to the 1930s and 1940s. Such was the case with the Pulahanes of Samar and Leyte, so named after the pula or red headband they wore. Like anting-anting, tattoos are believed to endow the wearer with invincibility, even invisibility, against bullets and bladed weapons, as well as immunity from illnesses caused by witchcraft, harmful spirits, and epidemics.

Among the revolutionaries, tattoos featured orasyon (prayer) with esoteric symbols on arms and other parts of the body. While orasyon, in its widest sense, refers to any prayer of the Roman Catholic Church, in folk oral tradition it also refers to incomprehensible words in pig Latin believed to possess magic powers that can accomplish positive or negative effects when uttered or written down on paper or cloth, or tattooed on the body. Such prayers are written down in a small book, called librito, and jealously guarded by the shaman, in Waray known as paramatbat. These might be placed in a container and worn as a pendant but, for fear of losing the powerful prayers, some have them tattooed on their bodies.

The orasyon tattoo is received as part of the initiation rites among the different cults in the Visayas and Mindanao, such as the Amahan-Inahan cult, the anti-communist Alsa Masa, or the Philippine Benevolent Missionary Association. In Leyte, the tattoo is the culmination of a series of ritual and sacrificial acts done by the pamaratbat. The initiate is tattooed using a wand, which may consist of 24 needles joined together with wax, the pointed ends slightly projecting and forming a slight arch. The wand, constantly dipped in indelible ink, is held vertically in puncturing the skin, with the first series pricking the skin and the second deepening the wound. Certain taboos—such as abstaining from pork, chicken, yellow sweet camote, sweets, cigarettes, sex, heavy manual work, and entertainment—are imposed by the shaman on the initiate to ensure the tattoo’s efficacy.

Tattoos are of different kinds. There are panlalaki tattoos worn exclusively by men because they transmit manly powers, and the pangontra, which provide protection against evil spirits. The purpose of the tattoo may be related to the wearer’s occupation; thus tattoos for farmers safeguard them against the evil spirits of fields or forests, as well as snakes, scorpions, and bats. The tuba (fermented coconut water) gatherer wears tattoos for invulnerability against bladed weapons, such as the sharp knife used by tuba gatherers for collecting coconut nectar. The icon tattoo may depict the solo mata, an open eye enclosed in an equilateral triangle and the symbol of the Christian Trinity; images of Mary, like the Perpetual Help; images of Christ, like the Nazareno, the Cursillo Christ called “The Eye,” and the Sacred Heart. Geometric figures—such as the circle, square, triangle, and pentagon—as well as variations of the cross may also be used. Some of the many cross designs used are the Latin cross, singly or on top of a three-stepped base; the cross of Santiago, also called Cursillo cross; the haloed cross; and the cross on an arched base. Pig Latin ciphers, words, or phrases usually accompany these motifs.

Traces of the traditional tattooing, however, can still be seen among the indigenous groups in the Philippines. Various local words that denote a traditional tattooing practice are found among several indigenous groups in the country. These include batuk (Visaya), patik or fatek (Bontok), batek, batok, whatok (Kalinga), and hakang (Tboli). The tattooing process of the Pintados is almost similar to the practice among the people in the Cordillera region. Sharp thorns from the lubfan tree are used as needles to prick the skin. Three to five pieces of thorns are prepared; and as they puncture the skin, lines and geometric shapes are formed using black soot pressed onto the fresh wound. In Kalinga, particularly in a remote village of Butbut (Salvador-Amores 2013), the traditional practice of tattooing is still being performed by a manwhatok (tattoo practitioner) using gisi (stick with a thorn) as the main tattoo instrument used via a continuous hand tapping on the skin. Apo Whang-Od of Buscalan is a manwhatok or mambabatok, reputedly the last holder of traditional knowledge in batok tattooing previously associated with the outlawed practice of head-hunting.

Although the designs and patterns vary in different groups and regions, there are common and shared motifs. Labid refers to the thick lines and wavy lines that can denote a snake. Ablay is a tattoo on the shoulder. Dubdub refers to one on the chest going upward to the neck. Bangut or langi is the term used for a tattoo on the face. Hinawak refers to a tattoo from waist down (Scott 1994). In Ifugao, the tattoo motifs are kinabu or dog usually placed on the chest, the tinagu or man, and the ginawang and ginayaman or centipedes. Men and women in the region, particularly in Kalinga, Kankaney, Ibaloy, and Ifugao, have their bodies inked with figurative designs of snakes, centipedes, frogs, rice grains, fern plants, interspersed with geometric motifs of zigzag lines and shapes, which reflect their landscape covered with mountains, rivers, and rice paddies. There is also a diamond-shaped motif that signifies rice, a staple food in the region. In Bontoc, women have their arms tattooed for social acceptance. These are applied on the arms since these are the most visible and exposed body parts when women perform their traditional dance during ritual celebrations, such as courting. It is believed that men would not court them if their arms were not tattooed.

In contemporary urban areas, tattooing is performed using either traditional or manual methods or with the aid of a machine. For the manual method, around 14-24 small and thin needles are tied on a stick or joined together with wax. These are used to slightly puncture the skin and embed the ink in the wound. Initially, the preferred design is drawn and outlined on the skin using a single needle with ink. Shadows and shading are then achieved when several needles are pricked on the skin to apply colors or to fill in the preferred design. This method of tattooing was previously linked to the subculture of street gangs and prisoners. Tattooing is known as a prisoner art form with its own repertoire of motifs and designs. Tattooing in prison can be a sign of membership in a prison gang, a way of remembering loved ones, a sign of machismo, or simply an exercise to relieve boredom. Prison tattoos may be done on the biceps, forearm, and chest of a person. Some prisoners are tattooed all over the body. The most common or popular images in prisoners’ tattoos are portraits or names of wife or girlfriend, children, and best friends; dragons; flowers and hearts; snakes; eagles; and religious icons. The repertoire of prison tattoos can take the shape of religious symbols as in the orasyon tattoo. The “Don Juan” or “Love” tattoos consist of portraits of a loved woman or a scantily clothed girl. Similar motifs are found in the tattoos worn by the maton (tough guy). In fact, some maton have their start in prison and display tattoos received in jail as signs of machismo. The snake usually tattooed on the body is common, as it denotes sexual and physical prowess.

Machine-rendered tattoos are the most commonly used method in contemporary tattooing. Several needles are attached to the tattoo gun depending on the tattoo artist’s intended interpretation of a design. Tattoo designs are catalogued according to themes and motifs. Clients sometimes ask tattoo artists to create an original design for them based on their preferred style, content, or meaning. Linear or outline rendering is used to define the shape and form of the tattoo. Detailed rendering of colors, form, and shadow can be achieved when using a round three-needle tip. Magnum needles, on the other hand, are used with five-needle points to apply various colors on the design. This machine-operated tattooing apparatus can create various images with numerous styles and design treatments as preferred by either the clients and/or the artists. Written byAlice G. text:
Textile weaving is the process of making cloth by means of interlacing a series of parallel longitudinal threads, called the warp, at right angles with another series of lateral threads, called the weft or woof. Weaving textiles is an ancient art in Southeast Asia. In a funerary site in northeastern Thailand, fragments of colored hemp fiber in a plain weave were found, dating to about 1000 BC. The earliest example of textile found in the Philippines in Banton, Romblon, is a 13th-century piece of ikat-dyed abaca cloth. Textiles may be plain or decorated by dyes, embroidery, and appliqué.

The Process

Traditionally, the entire process of weaving cloth, for daily use or for ritual, has been the work of women. The production of a piece of cloth entails a number of stages. It begins with the cultivation of the plant—such as cotton, abaca, and pineapple—the fibers of which will be used for weaving. The fibers are extracted from the leaves of these plants and prepared by carding, twisting, spinning, and winding by means of a spindle into thread. Warp threads are carefully counted and measured before they are attached to the beam of the loom and weft threads are evenly wound onto bobbins. Also part of the preliminaries is the gathering and preparing of naturaldyes. After the threads are soaked in dye and dried in the sun, weaving on a loom can begin. Weaving may follow decorative dyeing techniques, decorative weaving techniques, or supplementary thread techniques.

In the Philippines, there are a number of plants producing fiber for handwoven textiles. Cotton was once a major crop in the Cordilleras and Ilocos regions, and was also cultivated in the Visayas. Ramie is a shrub that yields a tough, white, and lustrous fiber from its stems. It is woven commercially into clothing and table linen primarily in central Philippines. Abaca, a variety of banana grown in central and southern Philippines, produces long and pliant threads, which the Tboli weave into their tie-dyed tnalak. The sword-shaped leaves of the pineapple plant produce a fine, lustrous fiber from which piña, a diaphanous, off-white fabric is woven and made into exquisitely embroidered handkerchiefs and altar cloths. Jusi, another fine sheer fabric, is made from pineapple or hemp warp in combination with a silk, cotton, or fine abaca weft. It makes elegant material for the richly embroidered barong tagalog. At one time, buri, which produces a raffia-type fiber, was woven into clothing, sails, and mosquito nets in central Philippines.

Most dyes come from vegetable substances. They have to be gathered from the forest and prepared by chopping, pounding, squeezing, soaking, boiling, and evaporating in earthenware vessels. To these are added mordants to fix the dyes and add tone and luster; often these include lime, salt, urine, mud, and leaves, which contain alum and iron compounds. Since no two dye shades are exactly the same and an element of unpredictability is always involved, many folk beliefs and taboos have surrounded the dyeing process.

From indigo is derived shades of blue-black, royal blue, gray, lavender, and even pink. Orange-red is derived from annatto or achuete seeds and from sappan, a low, thorny bush with yellow flowers. Dilaw or yellow ginger gives a mustard yellow color, which can be modified into bright yellow with the addition of tamarind or citrus juice; langka (jackfruit) bark also produces yellow. Brown dyes are derived from the talisay tree and the katuray. In recent times, chemical dyes have largely replaced vegetable dyes.

A loom is used for weaving. In general, the warp threads run vertically in parallel lines from the warp beam to the breast or cloth beam, which is close to the weaver. The weaver uses a heddle rod to raise and lower the odd and even warp threads, creating a space or shed through which is passed the shuttle with the weft threads.

Still widely used throughout Southeast Asia, including the Philippines, is the backstrap or body-tension loom, the oldest and simplest type of loom. A backstrap consisting of a pad of leather, woven matting, or wood is attached to the breast beam by a string or rope. The weaver sits on a mat with her feet outstretched supporting the warp beam, with the breast beam on her lap and the backstrap passing around the small of her back. She shifts her weight forward and backward while weaving in order to control the tension of the warp yarns.

For manageability, the width of the backstrap loom usually falls within the arm span of the weaver, while the length of the cloth is determined by the length of the prepared warp threads. Although the width of the cloth produced in this loom is not very large, blankets and malong (tubular skirts) are made by skillfully stitching together two or three separately woven pieces with care in matching designs. In other kinds of body-tension looms, the warp beam is secured to a house post or tree and the weaver supporting the breast beam sits on a stool, or the warp beam may be slotted into an upright wooden frame. No longer dependent on body tension, frame looms have a bigger and more complex structure and may even include the weaver’s seat.

To create designs in handwoven textiles using the backstrap or frame loom, there are three kinds of processes: the decorative dyeing techniques, the decorating weaving techniques, and the combination techniques.

The decorative dyeing techniques include the different kinds of ikat. Ikat is a process done before weaving in which a specified number of threads or fibers are bound or knotted together at different intervals with dye-resistant material following a preconceived design before soaking the entire mass of knotted threads in a vat of prepared dye. This may be repeated several times, the knots unravelled and other areas knotted in turn, depending on the complexity and number of hues of the design. Ikat is characterized by a softness or blurriness of the design because of a slight bleeding of the dyes around the resist bindings. There are three kinds of ikat: the warp ikat, the weft ikat, and the combination ikat. In warp ikat, the warp threads are knotted together, thus the design has a vertical orientation. It is primarily applied to cotton fibers, as in the exquisite blankets of the Cordilleras. In weft ikat, the weft threads are knotted together, so the design has a horizontal orientation, as in table runners. Unlike warp ikat that is used for cotton fibers, weft ikat is applied to silk threads, as well as cotton with rayon, producing weaves of fine quality. Double ikat is an even more complex technique that requires the dyeing of both warp and weft threads.

The Tboli tnalak and the Mandaya dagmay use the ikat technique on abaca fiber to create numerous bird, snake, and other animal and human motifs.

To make tnalak, fiber is extracted from the mature, fruit-bearing, wild abaca plant while utmost care is taken to preserve its length and silky appearance. Then the fiber is evenly stretched on a bamboo frame and the dye-resist patterning technique is executed by binding numerous small sections of the warp with thread treated with wax following a preconceived design. When the entire mass is immersed in dye, only the exposed threads absorb the color. The resist bindings are removed after dyeing and another combination of threads are bound in turn until the entire design is completed after several bindings and saturations. Traditional tnalak has three colors: deep reddish-brown, black, and white. Black dye is derived from the leaves of the k’nalum tree (a type of ebony) and red dye from roots of the loko tree. After the dyeing process, the dyed and dried warp fiber is carefully set and woven following the design on a back-strap or body-tension loom kept taut by the weaver’s own weight as she reclines back against the strap slung around the small of her back. The finished cloth is rubbed with a bone of the cuttlefish to give it a silken luster. The basic design of tnalak is the sigul or zigzag forming triangles from the ancient tumpal motif of the early Asian Dongson culture. Within this are particular motifs, such as the crab, the mythical bird, the frog, the shield, the python, and the man in his house, along with geometric motifs. These designs are also found in the colorful embroidery on women’s blouses and in body tattoos (Casal 1978).

In the decorative weaving techniques, the designs do not result from the dyeing process but from the weaving process itself. Thus, these entail different kinds of weaving patterns. The simplest of these is the plain or tabby weave in which individual warp and weft threads are interlaced together. If the warp and weft threads are of equal size and are equally spaced, this results in a “balanced weave.” If the warp threads are visually dominant over the weft threads, which are largely concealed, it is a “warp-faced weave.” On the other hand, if the weft threads dominate over the warp threads, it is called a “weft-faced weave.” Plain weave is decorated with stripes and plaids using bands of different colored threads for the warp and weft. Examples of these are the sarong or wraparound skirt, the tapis (wraparound overskirt), and the patadyong (tubular dress).

Tapestry weaving produces complex, mosaic designs by weaving with discontinuous weft threads in many colors. In this case, the weft threads do not pass through the entire area of the warp, but they are assigned to small areas of a particular design. The result is a symmetrical, usually square tapestry consisting of areas of different designs, usually with a large central design bordered by smaller areas. The Maranao malong features tapestry weave in the langkit bands that join together the large sections of solid color. The pis, the large colorful headpiece of the Tausug, is an excellent example of tapestry weave.

Aside from the decorative dyeing and weaving techniques, there are the supplementary thread techniques used in Southeast Asian textiles. These make use of special threads, such as brightly colored yarns or metallic threads of gold or silver, to supplement or complement the design of the plain weaves, which is the basic ground.

In the supplementary weft technique, the special threads are inserted into the weft but are made to float over a section of warp threads to form patterns of color and texture contrasting with the ground. When the supplementary threads extend over the entire width of the product, they are said to be “continuous,” but when they are worked back and forth in small areas, they are “discontinuous,” which is often favored because the snagging of long floating threads is avoided. Yakan cloth owes its particular beauty to the supplementary weft technique. Itneg blankets also use the supplementary weft technique in their designs of horses alternating with human figures.

In the supplementary warp technique, the appropriate supplementary warp threads appear on the surface as part of the design; otherwise, they make a continuous float on the reverse side. Weavers of northern Luzon sometimes make supplementary warp stripes as in the tapis and the bahag (G-string).

Other decorative techniques include the “float weave” in which the warp or weft skips two or more threads in its path before it is interwoven. Decorative twining in which pairs of adjacent elements are twisted around each other is often used for the borders of textiles to prevent fraying.

Aside from these, there are combination techniques involving embroidery, couching, appliqué, and beading to embellish the cloth. The Bukidnon, Bagobo, and Mandaya of southern Philippines decorate their ikat weaves with appliqué, colored wool, gold and silver thread, shells, mica chips, and panel beading. The Cordillera groups of the north also embellish their weaves with mother-of-pearl slivers of shell. Decorative knots have also been used to enrich the texture of weaves. Bagobo abaca bags patterned with narrow warp stripes are embellished with small brass bells and colored glass beads. Tboli and Bagobo blouses are richly ornamented with embroidery, sequins, seeds, glass beads, and tiny mother-of-pearl buttons. These costumes have a distinct religious and ritualistic significance.

Textiles, as clothing, may be untailored or tailored. Due to the warm climate, much of Southeast Asian clothing is untailored. A rectangular piece of cloth may be folded, draped or wrapped around the body to a snug fit, such as the sarong, the malong, the tapis, and the patadyong. There are the loincloths or bahag, the shoulder cloths or alampay, sashes, belts, and headcloths—such as the pis and the tubao or large handkerchief. The most common form of tailored clothing may be jackets, vests, caftans, and pants. Aside from their practical function, handwoven textiles have also been associated with traditions and religious rituals.

Philippine Textiles

Textile continues to be woven among the cultural communities of the Philippines and the Christianized lowland groups. Among the Cordillera groups, blankets, loincloth (called binulan or wanno among the Ifugao), blouses, skirts, and bags are woven. The Itneg dinapat blanket features stylized human forms, while their binakol has repetitive op art patterns. Ikat decoration is also used in more expensive textiles. The Ilocos is known for its sturdy abel (blanket) weave. Woven on a frame loom, abel can be multicolored with checkered or striped patterns or can be plain white with embossed patterns in tapestry weave. Also woven are pillowcases, towels, napkins, and place mats often decorated with supplementary weft at the fingers. The Mangyan of Mindoro generally use bark cloth for daily wear but also weave a dark blue denim-like skirt used by women.

In western Visayas, Aklan is known for its piña cloth. Since the process of preparing the thread and weaving piña is so tedious, weaving of the cloth suffered a decline until rediscovered by haute couture. Piña is woven into cloth for tailoring, handkerchiefs, napkins, and fine altar linen. Similar to piña is pinukpok—woven from banana fiber, then pounded to make it more pliant. The cotton patadyong is woven in Miag-ao, Iloilo. Compared to the Maranao malong, the patadyong is shorter and less ornate, its typical decoration being stripes of contrasting color. The patadyong is complemented by a kimona, a blouse of fine piña, sinamay, or synthetic material. A textile shared by many western Visayas provinces is hablon, meaning weave, which combines silk and cotton to produce a gloss smooth textile for clothing. Other woven items from the western Visayas are blankets, pillowcases, and mosquito nets. In eastern Visayas, Cebu is noted for its blankets, which come from the town of Carcar. Generically called habol, the blankets are woven in frame looms like the abel of the Ilocos. Similar geometric, checkered, and stripped designs found in the abel are also seen in Carcar weaves. A special type of weave, called kinarnero (sheeplike), has a high nap and resembles the wool of sheep. Bohol has a long tradition of weaving. During the Spanish period a strong cotton canvas cloth was one of island’s exports. Called lampotes, the cloth was used for making sails. Because of the easy accessibility of textile from other places, the weaving of textile in Bohol has declined, although still woven is the saguran, a raffia cloth used for bags, wallpaper, and covers.

Mindanao has strong weaving traditions especially among the cultural communities. The malong woven by the Maranao who live along the shores of Lake Lanao and the Maguindanao is a large wraparound cloth, about 165 sq cm. Two pieces of cloth are sewn together lengthwise along the edges to form a square, after which it is sewn up on one side.

The Maranao malong woven from cotton or silk is of different kinds. For everyday wear, stripes or plaids are commonly used. The landap is for ceremonial occasions. This may be of one solid color, although often in two alternating colors in broad bands. Red, purple, yellow, and green are preferred colors; dark red is favored by the men, and yellow by the women. The special feature of the landap is the langkit, which is a band separately woven in tapestry weave and sewn onto the malong. The broader band, a 15 cm strip called lakban, is sewn vertically along the front of the malong, while a number of smaller bands, called tobiran, are sewn at right angles to the lakban along the boundaries of the areas of solid color. Intricately designed in several colors, the langkit contain okir motifs of flowers, leaves, and vines, or a stylized tree of life.

Another kind is the andon malong, which features ikat motifs in the warp and weft techniques. These geometric motifs—such as small stars, triangles, squares, diagonal crosses, and circles—may be found between checks or stripes. Malong decorated with tiny motifs between bands of many colors are called babalodan. A rare kind of malong contains overall floral geometric designs, while the central area or kepala features two vertical rows of facing tumpal patterns, a row of adjacent narrow triangles that frame a series of simple geometric motifs.

The landap is not found among the Maguindanao. Instead, the Maguindanao malong is covered by recurring designs, sometimes put on by supplementary weft. A simple malong consists of bands of alternating colors, or stylized stars and recurring geometric patterns may be liberally sprinkled on the cloth. The malong for a special occasion may be woven from silk and decorated with gold thread to form stylized Tree of Life designs that originate from either edge of the cloth in a jagged pattern. Also woven is the tubao or headpiece, which is a square cloth about 60 cm long and wide. The tubao is decorated in a manner similar to the malong.

The malong is a versatile garment for both men and women, which can be simple for everyday wear and regal for special occasions, such as weddings and funerals. Aside from its regular use as a tubular garment covering the large area from the upper torso to the feet, it serves a number of different purposes—as a modest screen for shielding the body while doing ritual ablutions in the lake, a cloth for carrying a baby on one person’s back while doing chores, a hammock for the injured, a protective covering against the rain, a blanket or bedcloth, a cigarette case or purse, a sack for carrying tubers and foodstuffs, or an instant curtain for privacy.

As a garment, the women roll and tie it around their upper chest or knot it around one shoulder from which it falls in graceful folds. The men often tuck it around their loins and knot it at the waist. A traditional Maranao dance, called kapamalongmalong, gracefully illustrates the many different ways of wearing the malong according to its functions (Fraser-Lu 1988).

Other Mindanao groups that have vibrant weaving traditions are the Tboli, Mandaya, Bagobo, Yakan, and Tausug. The Yakan weave multicolored scarves and belts with recurring geometric patterns. The Tausug male gird themselves with a colorful waistcloth, called kandit, and wear the pis or a headcloth of recurring geometric patterns.

The coming of the Spaniards brought new traditions of clothing and tailoring textile. Embroidery became a requisite element of lowland native costumes, such as the barong tagalog and the maria clara with its butterfly sleeves, made of fine transparent material like jusi or piña. It flourished in the 19th century with the patronage of the fashion-conscious ilustrado (educated) class, as can be seen from their portraits detailing their material refinements. Because of the increasing demand, there emerged communities of bordadora (embroiderers) in Malate and in the provinces, such as Batangas, particularly the towns of Taal and San Nicolas. Characteristic of Philippine embroidery is the calado, fine openwork combined with solid areas of design.

Embroidery is done not only on costumes and church vestments but also on table linen, bedspreads, veils, and handkerchiefs. However, it is the wedding trousseau with its demanding and elaborate needlework covering large areas of the bridal gown in its entire length and the matching embroidery of the groom’s barong that have challenged the bordadora to produce masterpieces of design and artistry.

The rich textile weaving tradition of the Philippines is an important cultural link to Southeast Asia, Taiwan, South Asia, and the Pacific cultures. The weaving processes that have been passed on from generation to the next have been recognized as an intangible heritage that embodies the social, economic, and spiritual beliefs of Philippine communities. Textile weaving is also considered a signifier of the high status of women in indigenous communities as they were also considered as leaders, healers, and keepers of traditional knowledge. The following textile weavers received the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (National Living Treasure Award): Tboli tnalak weaver Lang Dulay and Tagabawa Bagobo inabal weaver Salinta Monon, both awarded in 1998; Tausug pis syabit weaver Darhata Sawabi, 2004; and Ilocano abel weaver Magdalena Gamayo, 2012. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

text:
The use of video as a medium in Philippine visual arts began in the 1970s. However, such use was sparse until the mid-2000s, primarily due to the limited access to video equipment. Owing to artistic preference or the lack of apparatus, artists at times simulated the movement of images by montaging a series of photographs hung sequentially. Notably, many artists who now use video as a medium have a film or television background, which makes them more sensitive to how moving images may be used to make meaning.

Artists who use video rarely do so exclusively. Usually they work with and in other media as well, particularly installation. While there is frequent use of single-channel video, video art is more often exhibited as installation presented in multiple-channel formats, using specific display equipment, lighting conditions, and objects related to the themes of the work. While cathode ray tube television sets were the default option in the 20th century, flat-screen TVs and projections have become a popular display option since the mid-2000s.The format of video art has changed with the development of technology, at the time of the work’s creation and the artist’s own aesthetic tastes. The technological range includes U-matic, Hi-8, VCR, VCD, DVD, and HD video. Digital formats, which are easy to use, more accessible, and much cheaper, have led to an increased number of video works done by artists. At times though there is no recorded image involved, with artists using direct feed from the video camera to the display screen.

Because of the medium of video, the making of video art requires a collaborative effort, which may be simple or otherwise depending on the complexity of production, editing, and installation involved. Artists may not necessarily shoot the video themselves, deploying others to shoot the video for them or using already existing footage as elements of the final work. An example is Yason Banal ’s two-channel video work Chop-Chopped First Lady and Chop-Chopped First Daughter, 2005, which consisted of excerpts of Kris Aquino from a slasher film screened side by side with documentary footage of a real-life attempted assassination of Imelda Marcos. Both sets of images were screened on a loop. The video component of Bomba (Soft Porn Movie/Bomb), 2010, by Kawayan de Guia, used brief clips from over 60 films, selected by de Guia mostly from the bomba film period, and edited together by another artist, JJ Villamarin.

Video art has been used for many different functions because of its documentary attributes. It is repeatedly used in a performative context, with video being an essential part of the work and distinguished from simple documentation of a performance. This is exemplified by Johnny Manahan’s I Will Breathe, Scale in Time:1:27, Components: Plastic Bag Covering Head, CO2,O2, 1972, where he recorded himself with a plastic bag over his head for a certain amount of time. The performance Three Pieces, 1976, by Judy Sibayan, Huge Bartolome, and Ray Albano, involved the audience seeing themselves on live-feed television sets as cameras surrounded them. In Jean Marie Syjuco’s work See Me, See You, 1986, the reactions of gallery visitors to her interactive work were also seen through live feed, but this time, watched on a television set by audiences in another part of the exhibit venue. Kaloy Olavides’s The Elements, 2001, also played up this contrast between live action and recorded image through the screening of a video of an overflowing stream on a monitor set next to the artist’s body as he lay covered by soil while breathing through a straw.

Like photography, video is a fitting medium for works that focus on social, historical, political commentary or observation. This can be seen particularly in the works of Kiri Dalena, like Washed Out , 2012, which examined the devastation wrought by typhoon Sendong in Iligan. Manny Montelibano’s Red Wake, 2006, painted a disillusioned portrait of Philippine politics, with video of then-president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo screened from within a coffin. The three-channel video, Gilubong ang Akong Pusod sa Dagat (My Navel Was Buried in the Sea), 2011, by Martha Atienza, intimated a sense of the relationships of those who live from the sea like traditional fishermen, children deep-sea divers, ship workers, and other seafarers.

Artists also make use of video’s time-based aspect in their works, employing it as both mode and as subject. Gerry Tan’s Apparition, 1999, used time to reverse playback the slow melting of a candle shaped like an image of the Virgin Mary. The interchange and cycle of time is made apparent in several layers of video within a video in Poklong Anading’s Dusk and Dawn, 2003, a work shot on the specific site over several days. Tad Ermitaño’s /mutation, 2005, involved a computer program editing in situ various available video clips, resulting in a narrative structure algorithmically determined and thus generating variable versions of a story in each sequence. It is an example of how video is also used in media art, which typically involves a more complex use of technology.

As audiovisual material, video also employs the element of sound. The sound may be inherent to the actions captured or it can be added on as another layer to evoke or intensify a certain atmosphere. Sound can also be used for irony as in Maria Taniguchi’s Untitled (Crystal Palace + Gauguin), 2009, which pairs images of dinosaurs with the audible commentary of different voices describing works by Paul Gauguin. Written byClarissa Chikiamco
